reviewText:
This is not a very good game. The NPCs and their dialogue are boring and lack character, they're little more than placeholders to guide you to the next quest, which is unfortunate because Fallout 1 and 2 had such interesting NPCs and conversations.

There is no perk system. Attributes other than strength and intelligence are pretty pointless. Levelling isn't exciting since there's no reason to diversify your skillset, so you wind up dumping all of your skill points into one or two different skills.

There is WAY too much combat. In fact, this game is almost exclusively combat focused, in my time playing it is very rare to move the story forward without a lengthy combat sequence. While this isn't ideal, it'd be fine if the combat were at all interesting. There's a cover system, but it's hardly used and most combat takes place without being around any cover. There's no bonus to pincering an enemy, so there's not much point to moving around during combat. Gone is the Fallout system of targetting different body parts to cripple them, or make them drop their weapon, the only option you have now is to take a headshot for two extra AP at -50% chance to hit for 200% weapon damage (which is never worth doing since your chance to hit will never be above 95%). The jamming system has replaced the critical failure system. Now you can have a weapon that has a 1 in 10 chance to randomly jam up, wasting your turn.

Using skills is tedious. After combat you will want to heal your rangers, which requires using first aid. Each use of first aid requires watching a cross fill-up over 5 seconds, and most rangers require two first-aid packs to fully heal. With a party of 6, healing after battle requires about a minute of not being able to move around or do anything else in the game. Almost every loot container is locked or booby-trapped, oftentimes both, which requires watching some other animation that lasts 5 seconds to fill up. Waiting for animations to complete gets very tiring.

One of the strangest design choices was to have a rotating camera. The camera is VERY annoying, you'll frequently miss important items, people, and entrances and exits because your camera wasn't pointed the right way. Designing the levels from the ground up to have a fixed camera perspective would have made a lot more sense.

Lastly, the game just doesn't have much character. So far it's a lackluster wasteland without the zaniness, wonder, and humor of the classic Fallout games.

I hope they do a lot better with Torment...
voteText: 28 of 47 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've never played the original Wasteland so I had no particular expectations about this game.
I hold Fallout 1 and 2 in high regard and I can say that Wasteland 2 is what I would have wanted a different Fallout 3 to have been. A PC-centric isometric turn-based cRPG through and through; detailed stat sheets, lots of options, lots of skill and much room for exploration. This game has a learning curve, it doesn't hold your hand in the way many modern AAA RPGs do. It's also long. Very long. Depending on how thoughrough you are with side quests and exploration it may take between 40-60 hours to complete. The many choices you have in the game does offer replayability, but the gameplay is quite combat-oriented.

But it also has some problems though:
1) Pacing. This game requires a lot of patience. It takes a while before the story gets off the ground. The skill checks eat up time as well. I needed to take a break from the game about half-way through (I found some of the areas midways somewhat uinteresting and the combat was becoming repetitive) and then come back to it again after a couple of months. However the second half of the game feels better. I almost think it would have been better if the developers had cut some of the content to make the game more focused.
2) Armor system. This is just badly designed. Armor comes with a armor threshold. Weapons come with armor penetration. If weapon penetration exceeds armor threshold then armor does nothing. And it so happens that most enemies you encounter use weapons with armor penetration that just about match the best armor you can get in that part of the game. And later in the game more enemies use energy weapons which deal increased damage to high armor ratings. Thus you find yourself in situations late game were your armor is either detrimental or useless. This really calls for a major balance rehaul patch.
3) Graphics and animation. This game would have looked good ten years ago. The animations are fairly rough and stiff at times. Many backgrounds are nice, but the overall impression is very mediocre.

But these issues should not deter you if you're into long and involved turn-based cRPGs.

reviewText: Absolutely great!  As someone who recently went back and picked up Fallout 2 only to realise it was a LOT better in my memory, than in my 2014 spec PC reality - Wasteland 2 is exactly what I needed. OK so sure, I hear what some reviewers are saying - as far as tactical combat goes, this is not XCOM. Nothing is. But the game has all the elements I used to love in the original Fallout series; gritty humour, no imposed moral code, diverse skill system, crafting and more. Definitely gets my crystal clear recommendation to anyone who loved the Fallout originals. If you've only ever played modern RPGs (and therefore is not struck by nostalgia like myself), try it anyway - and maybe catch a glimpse of what all the rave was about.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a good game. If you want an old school RPG, you will probably enjoy this.
Unfortunately it has some flaws. The graphics aren't pretty (I think it's getting an overhaul though), the combat could be more polished, the AI was frustrating at some points regarding followers you can't control, and I didn't like the way certain skills worked, for example you could have a lot of points invested in lockpicking and still have a high chance to fail at it, encouraging you to save and reload.

Despite all this, the reason why I recommend this game is because it's a true RPG. Choices matter, many things change depending on how you act, I found many quests and places in the world to be interesting and made me think if what I was doing was the right thing to do, and what consecuences those actions would bring. The story is decent for a video game, the writing is good and many NPC's were very unique.

Now that it's been some time since I've finished it, I can say that it was a very memorable experience.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is CRPG set in a post-apocalyptic world.
Coming from the mastermind behind Wasteland and Fallout, Wasteland 2 closely follows the traditional Fallout approach to the gameplay.
Incredibly detailed world gives hours worth of exploration, that you'll spend chasing all the tiny secrets available.
Turn-based combat is mechanically simpler than it was in Fallout, but that is covered by a fact that you have to manage a team of rangers, not just your character. And as well by a very nice level design that almost always gives you a set of opportunities you can use to engage with enemies.
Add an intriguing storyline, some nice voice acting, years of waiting for a good fallout-like game - and you'll get Wasteland 2. Totally worth it!

You can have a look at some gameplay with commentary in the video:
http://youtu.be/wwEDZ_mK8a4
voteText: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a game that encourages you to sink many hours into. That's neither a good nor a bad thing. It encourages RP, which is not usually a factor in most RPGs. (eg. most JRPGs just have characters with their own stories and motives, while this game encourages you to tell your own story of your 'rangers'-- that's not to say there aren't already characters with detailed backstories) Some may love this; others, not so much. But the RP is not mandatory, and generally does not affect gameplay.

One of the main selling points of the game is the story. The story of the world is pretty huge and detailed. It really brings out the RP in RPG. If you liked the fallout series for its story then you'll love this game. There are plenty of similarities in story. The plotlines are also very interesting and compelling.

However, the game itself doesn't feel complete. It feels very unpolished, with unappealing and often reused graphics and character models reminiscent of playstation 1 games.

The gameplay does trump over the ugliness. The exploration and combat system is quite fun and actually works well with the graphics and semi-isometric gameplay.

The menu system works well and does not feel cluttered, in fact may be a bit simplistic. The item system is also pretty straightforward.

The soundtrack is decent, and the sounds and voices are really good, at least when they are present (and it would seem to me that voicing is actually missing from quite some text).

There is no fast travel, so maps with one exit will be a pain to get out of. As well as travelling between destinations.

I would compare this game with xcom mixed with runescape, placed in the fallout universe. Overall I would say it's merely a decent game. Personally, I cannot recommend this game; at least not at full price. That being said, I don't think I would categorize this game as a kickstarter flop. It really does have something nice. But it just feels very unpolished.

Good to know that the developers are actually still very passionate about the game with updates still coming out from time to time.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a tactical RPG sequel to a very old text-based game.  While I had never heard of it before, it was the inspiration behind the well-known Fallout games.  To have a sequel come along after 27 years is unheard of, and thankfully they did a very good job with it.

While the game was released in a pretty buggy state, inXile diligently released patches to fix everything.  When I played it, I didn't run into any significant problems and there is a director's cut special edition coming in the near future to improve the game even further.  While I feel bad for those who bought the game at release, I'm very glad that inXile stuck with it rather than leaving it a buggy mess like many companies would.  Hopefully their future projects will be released in better condition.

As for the game itself, it is a top-down squad RPG with tactical turn-based combat.  There is a metric ton of text dialogue, with the main story being voiced.  The writing and voice acting is ok, nothing special, though there is a lot of humor and references to many other games and old technology which I found enjoyable.  I would prefer more voice acting since I get tired of reading text pretty quickly but I understand that inXile wanted to stick to a similar style to the original game and at the same time having the whole game being voiced would likely be too expensive.  The pathfinding is some of the best I've ever seen in a game with your squad able to easily navigate all the way across large maps with a single click.  Unfortunately, traversing these large maps can take a long time and you will be doing a lot of this, especially if you want clear out your inventory which I will go into later.

Wasteland 2 has its own unique RPG systems, with a standard stat system providing bonuses to various skills.  Each character will only get enough skill points to be competent in a couple skills so specializing is required.  There are even special skills that can only be acquired by finding specific skill books throughout the game.  Several of the skills deal with unlocking containers and doors and this is where one of my sticking points comes in.  Even with maxed out skills, your characters have a very low chance of succeeding (and an accompanying high chance of critical failure) and these objects can only be repaired once.  Following a second critical failure they can never be accessed again.  I believe it's meant to convey a sense of permanence to decisions but I feel like it just encourages save scumming.

The combat could be a sticking point for many people, though it's not an issue for me.  Everything functions as you'd expect but later in the game, tactics becomes less and less useful.  Arranging party members behind cover can get tedious and isn't necessary later in the game since as you level up, enemies are less dangerous.  At the very end of the game however, it becomes necessary again.  My only real complaint about the combat is that at the very beginning of the game, it is extremely difficult.

The game's biggest problem though is inventory clutter.  The game is filled with the greatest variety of junk items I've seen in a game.  Most of these are just sold to shops but some have a shining effect indicating that they are useful in some way but you don't know how.  Unfortunately the sell all junk" button includes these shiny items so you have to manually remove them from the shop each time.  In addition to the junk there are tons of miscellaneous items
date: each of which can be given to a specific NPC for a reward.  There are tons of these items and tons of NPCs with no hints about who wants them other than remembering what NPCs may have told you when talking to them.  It's a royal pain trying to deal with it all but can be ignored if you aren't a completionist.\n\nThe game makes good use of the Unity engine with DX11 support and pretty good graphics
recommended: though unfortunately due to using Unity it does not support fullscreen mode.  This led to significant performance problems for me.  I'm really hoping that the update to Unity 5 for the director's cut version will fix this particular problem.  Regardless
hoursPlayed: the game does seem to require much more power to run than it should for the type of game it is.  It seems to be a common problem with Unity games that aim for high graphical fidelity in my experience.\n\nDespite a few problems
voteText: Wasteland 2 is a fine game.  It has all the RPG depth you'd expect and plenty of content to play through.  Having skipped most of the dialogue due to not wanting to read so much
helpfulPercent: it still took me more than 50 hours to beat the game.  Wasteland 2 is a game I can highly recommend to RPG fans."

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a great take on post-apocalypse. It's very similar to Fallout 1 & 2 and should appeal to anyone who loved those.

Game's a mix of RPG (both character development in terms of skills and attributes, and choices in story and consequences). The story is again similar to Fallout series, with a dose of humor and typical post-apocalypse madness. It was definetly entertaining and motivating to find out, but could have been slightly better written to enhance the immersion. The world in Wasteland 2 is huge and allows a lot of exploration, but is not entirely open: you have to progress the story to gain access to certain areas. The world itself is highly detailed in content, and is therefore fun to explore. My favorite part of exploration is that you can find interesting and weird stuff where you least expect it. Here I rather mean finding weird characters and in most cases items, and not unique new quests or adventures like you do in the newer Fallout games.

I was somewhat disappointed by the graphics. The details of certain objects and buildings were non-existent. I wish the game simply was sharper and more detailed, which would farther help increase the atmosphere. The voice acting was in most cases pretty good, but not always convincing, and to compare to Fallout 1 & 2 lacked some of the uniqueness in the characters you meet (i.e. like Marcus), but only to a lesser extent: there are lots of weird people out there.

In general the game is absolutely worth your time. Strongly suggested to Fallout fans (especially 1&2) and those who are into post-apocalypse in general, or just someone looking for a game that can draw you in for at least 50 hours. I spent 80 in the end, and still hadn't explored every corner in the wasteland and finished all side quests.

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game, the promises that it makes and the potential of this game are amazing, but it quickly becomes obvious that it's built around a good idea with really poor implementation. The fact you move your characters around in real time before a combat start oftens leaves you're characters all huddled together before you can start the combat, as at least 2 or 3 members of your party are out of cover. The combat soon turns into a waiting to see if you're lucky enough to hit as the AI just charges forward or stays still shooting at you. The options in combat for crouching, headshots and ambushing just aren't enough or actually useful, the combat is really stale it really could have done with copying xcom wholesale.

The game hides the fact of which skill to use on particular objects, which left me to go to the internet to figure out that the demolitions skill allowed you to disable traps. The uses for the various skills are fairly pointless, you need perception, demolition, lockpicking, first aid, surgeon and safecracking, then you need to invest heavily in combat skills to stand a chance of hitting anything.

The conversation system could have been wonderful and added much needed depth to the game, it is generally well written, but it turns into a case of just clicking every single option to find out all of the information the uses for social skills tend to be few and far between. There are apparently hidden key words in the conversations, I tried asking about lots of different options and none of them came up.

The camera also is pretty limited and hides things, you'll end up pressing z almost constantly whilst exploring to see stuff to interact with.

reviewText:
I remember playing the original Wasteland on my dads computer 13 years ago and I was clueless as to how the game operated and I spent no more than 2 minutes with it and never went back to it until last year.
I played through Wasteland and found myself pleasantly suprised by the depth the game had and how enjoyable and how much I got attached to my custom made rangers.
So now we have finally come to Wasteland 2 a game which has been patiently waited for by fans of the series for over 25 years (You give Half Life fans a run for their money) and it's return is glorious.
The story of Wasteland 2 is as follows, You and your group of rangers(All of which you can personally customize) are tasked with regulating the hostile wastes of Arizona and later Los Angeles from raiders, mutants, robots, cyborgs and more.
One aspect of Wasteland 2 is choice, like most games that have cropped up recently Wasteland 2 is no acception to choice based gameplay.
One of the first choices you make is decieding whether to save the town of highpool from raiders or saving an agricultural facility from mutants.
It was great to see that this choice had a lasting effect, as I choose the AG Center first, Highpool was destroyed and taken over by raiders as a result.
The gameplay is similar to the original Wasteland but thanks to the advancement of technology we now have gameplay which will be more remeniscent of the games which Wasteland inspired allah Fallout with it's turn based gameplay and chance based combat, this means you have action points which are used in combat and anything from movement, attacking, healing and reviving all take up points.
This means you have to be strategic and choose your actions carefully so 2AP for crouching, 3 for moving into position and 3 to take a shot.
Weapons all have different AP usage rifles typically use 7AP and using pistols and fists takes up 3AP.
Now onto the graphics.
Wasteland 2 uses the unity engine and it does a pretty good job of capturing the look and feel of the post apocolaypse with run down buildings, sandy plains and nature taking back the enviroment with green plantlife and vine covered roads and buildings.
It's been a long time coming and it does not disappoint in the slightest.
If you are a fan of the original Wasteland, Fallout or stories set in the post apocolaypse Wasteland 2 is one that will kick you to the ground, stick your head into an irradiated toilet and keep you invested until the bitter end.
voteText: 13 of 20 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. But i can't. I love isometric RPGs and i played them all. I even replay both the original Fallouts once every three years or so. Sadly, the Wasteland 2 fails on so many levels that the few that are actually good won't save it. And the fact that Divinity: Original Sin and Shadowrun: Dragonfall came out recently and are superior on almost every level makes this game look even worse.

Combat:
Total letdown. Almost no tactial options. While in Divinity i would use my rogue to sneak behind enemy lines and start with an ability that costs a lot of AP and is therefore only useful as an opening getting bonuses from backstab as well as from attack from stealth. After that i will use the artifact and teleport my tank to the rogue and make him knock down the most dangerous foe while my mage will teleport oil barrel near the enemies and ignite it. While my tank has fire resist over 100% so the flames actually heal him.
And in Wasteland? I open with a shot. After that all my other characters shoot. Some use the weapon ability to shoot multiple rounds as it has the best dmg/Ap. Then all the enemies shoot, now all my characters shoot. When you are skilled you can try for a headshots (And that just causes more dmg, no penalties to the enemy or anything and you can't aim for any other bodypart) Sometimes you can use verticality or cover (that has been clearly added to the game as an afterthought as it is not possible in most of the fighths) And THAT IS ALL! No abilities, no gadgets, no skills, no perks. NOTHING!!!

Character progression:
There is none! You have attributes and skills. Attributes can be minmaxed as some are clearly better than the others. Skills are just your percentual chance to do stuff. You will NEVER gain new ability or perk or anything. Nothing that will change the gameplay. You will just know how to open a box better. Mainly because boxes near the end of the game are harder to open than the boxes at the beginning of the game. Yes, the same boxes...

Quickloading:
As the game desing is bad you will load very often. In fact you will memorize the loading screen very well. You see, everything is percentual and dependant on your skill. Luck based. You see a locked box with a trap and an alarm. You have 50% to disarm the alarm, 40% to disarm the bomb and 70% to pick the lock. So disarm - fail - disarm - fail - disarm success - alarm - fail - alarm - fail - alarm - success - pick - fail - pick - critical fail - LOAD and repeat.

Graphics:
Amazingly bad. I mean really bad. Much worse than Fallout 1 or 2. It is technically bad (low res textures, low poly models) and aesthetically bad (repeating of assets, assests with different textures next to each other, the same mood everywhere, the same models everywhere). You don't even have much of an avatar picture choice when creating your characters. And some of that pictures are later used in the game on other characters! The graphics are much worse than in The Fall: Last days of Gaia which is old, low budget german post-apo game from noname developer.

Story
Here it isn't bad. The story is quite good. Sadly it is told via big chunks of texts. I like to read in games. Planescape Torment is one of my most beloved games and it has much more text. But the text in that game is exciting and relevant. Here most of the things that people will tell you are things that you have already heard milion times from others. But you have to read it all because sometimes in this ocean of text there is useful information.

Choices
The choices are a mixed bag. You are often presented with multiple choices and you actually feel the consequences. That is very good. But sometimes the choices themselves seem illogical. At the beginning of the game you have to choose to save one of two settlements. Either the superimportant one that feeds all the surrounding settlements (including your ranger base), or the other superimportant one that provides water to everyone. You as a new recruit. One ranger of many. And after you do that you suddenly hear the other rangers chat on radio. How they helped to save some merchants or how they saved some cows. Yea, but they couldn't save the superimportant settlement...

Conclusion:
This review might seem too harsh but if someone asked me what game to play - Wasteland 2 or Fallout 1, the game that came out 17 years ago, i would recomment F1 without hesitation. And that tells you something about this game...
If you want to play good modern isometric RPG, play Shadowrun: Dragonfall or Divinity: Original Sin.

reviewText:
Let me preface this review with the following: Do not buy this game unless it is $15 dollars or less. In this game Armor actually kills you and you have to strip down to actually beat some encounters or you will die!

Spoilers will be in here.

So after 70+ Hours I think I have played enough of this and gotten the mechanics down to write a review. Now I get this is supposed to be a classic styled game. I loved Wasteland and the Fallout series which is why I had to play this. I went in expecting some pretty decent gameplay ala Fallout 1 & 2 style. While the base game has some decent overtones and it looks extremely polished. The feel and amibiance are fantastic game looks and feels great and just oozes style. However the mechanics are what destroys this title or should I say lack thereof.

Unpopular Mechanics: How the Waste was made.

So lets get this started you have Attributes which give you various bonuses to derived stats and a lot of skills. Every skill or stat goes from 1 to 10 including the  equipped armor stat, but more on that later. Now most of your stats are straight forward extra skill points on level up or higher crit chance on in particular is interesting Combat Intiative". Seems pretty standard it makes you act sooner in combat right? Well partially right
date:
it allows you to act faster in combat. Meaning you can go two or even three times more then a character with a low score. Making it a godly stat if you get enough of it. Also the average of 13-15 is considered low by the game. Enemies have average 17-19 meaning they go first and sometimes twice before you do.

That leads us into the mess which is Wasteland 2's combat system. Lets start with weapons and see what does what.

Assault rifles: High damage
recommended: wonky stats between rifles as some higher tier ones do horribly low damage and most have a solid three round burst mode. This is the go to weapon for most situations the only draw back is they have accuracy penalty at point blank range and if a enemy moves next to you a further aim on all shots is inccured. Also the enemies WILL do this every chance they get to cripple your snipers even if they don't attack them.\n\nPistols: high crit low base damage. Early ones fire for a pittance of 3 action points a shot allowing you to do some damage. Later higher but not assault rifle damage ones are typically 4 AP a shot. A decent side arm for using 4 ap you can't shoot with a rifle as you switch between guns
hoursPlayed: not particularly effective though
voteText: As you can rarely get a third shot off late game.\n\nHeavy Weapons: These are joke level
helpfulPercent:
they waste huge amounts of bullets to fire large bursts of VERY low damage shots that combine up to equal a couple good assault rifle shots. Bonus joke is you start with a broken M2 .50 caliber machingun rechambered in 5.56 if you select this skill at start. Even though you get .50 BMG ammo later on there is apprantly no real M2 that uses it. To put it in perspective a assault rifle using the same round does 44-70 damage for the 20-30 damage of a heavy weapon. Both of which will be reduced by enemy armor making even a minigun barrages damage miniscule. No mods can be used so they will jam or not have great chance to hit/Hit your own dudes.

Submachine guns: These are to pistols what heavy weapons are to assault rifles. Low damage bullet wasters.

Energy Weapons: Now we are talk here is the games central gimmick and one of things that breaks the game utterly. The more armor the target has the more damage it takes from energy weapons. Late game enemies use energy weapons and melee weapons that go right through your armor. There is a ambush later in the game where synthetics attack you from all directions
votesHelpful:
I died after 2-3 turns and retried this encounter many times and went back and leveled up and did stuff I might have missed. I was level 34 at my highest character and still died. Solution? I took off my armor before entering the location and the 120 damage hits I was taking turned into 15-20 damage hits. I completed the whole fight with no one under 80% health and having done NO healing during the fight.

Totally disgusting as all my power armor and cool gear I worked for actually slowed me down and made me take MORE damage. Also Explosives do straight damage ignoring armor so a pipe bomb always does 50 damage and a frag grenade does 100.

To reiterate I had to take off all my armor in order to progress through the game or I would die if they I wore armor.

Shotguns: Laughable for a good eighty percent of the game. Enemies will often kill each other with the low damage cone effect. Later ones gain burst fire but insane accuracy penalties where they will either do maybe a shot of assault rifle damage or triple shot remove late game enemies.

Sniper rifles: High damage and long range
votesTotal: Keep enemies back or lure them in for close combat. The best gun in the game is likely the .50 caliber sniper rifle you pull out of the dump as it can and will crit for 250+ oh and like pistols these have a high base crit and rarely miss when in range.\n\nOh and uh melee weapons: they do more damage based on levels you put into them even though it apprantly doesn't say that. Anything with AP 2-3 is extremly viable especially against rifle using enemies who will run away from you. If you max these out early they are absurd like no other. Especially as later ones have very high armor pen and status effects. Do not trust the listed damage

Skills or how I learned to extend play time through save scumming. Every skill besides first aid (unless surgery on npc's) has a critical failure. Even a easy 92% check has a chance of going HORRIBLY wrong and maiming your character or breaking whatever you were interacting with. This can straight up break entire quests as you break a lock and are unable to progress in that chain. Frequent saving and loading on critical areas is advised. reviewText:
Edit: they've patched the game a lot since I wrote this and I don't know if its more fun now than it was on launch

As a Kickstarter backer I got this game for $15, but if I had paid $40 for it I probably wouldn't be happy at all.

The whole way the game interacts with you is ripped out of 1987 in the worst ways.
There's no fast travel, you watch your party walk for ages, because that's the only way out of the labaryth maps, walking back to the entrance, slowly. And there is plenty of mandatory back tracking.
The combat is boring, and the RNG makes it an annoying chore, but most of the time you can't avoid it. Put points into outdoorsman and flee every random encounter.
There's no cool stuff like reverse pick pocketing a land mine into someone's back pocket, or shooting their legs off so they can't flee. Just aim, and miss or get jam or whatever.
The character creator is super unintuitive and weird and kind of horrible. INT doesn't help with wisdom skills
date:
charisma has nothing to do with your ability to influence people in dialog, and strength has no bearing on your ability to break down a chain link gate. Why not? Because!
There is an over-world, but don't think that it's open, you need to follow the linear plot.
There is lots to see, but the game moves ridiculously slowly, ie level 5 and done with the first dungeon in ~12 hours.

The story is really decent and the game delivers a lot of it's old school" promise
recommended: but honestly most of that is the bad things from the old days that should have been forgotten. For $40 I wouldn't buy it

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is an amazing game and instant classic. It's very much like Fallout 1 and 2 (which were based off the first wasteland game), with lots of differences.

First of all, you start by creating a party of up to 4 people (and can have a party up to 7 from npcs recruited in game), there a tons of different skill to choose from for each character, ranging from mechanical repair, to computer science to assault rifles, pistols, shotguns, outdoorsman, smart ♥♥♥/hard ♥♥♥/kiss ♥♥♥ (3 dialogue skills that vary on attitude), etc.
There is also a decent attribute system, much like the SPECIAL from fallout, except this one is called CLASSIC (coordination, luck, Awareness, Strength, Speed, Intelligence and Charisma), and the attributes have a huge impact on characters and what they can do.

The battle system is much like DnD or any D20 system, grid turn based combat, using initiative to choose when people act. If you've played X Com then it's much like that, except more in depth (then the newest x com) in terms of mechanics and what you can do. As opposed to the two move system from x com or D20, this one is based off action points (like the original fallout games), you have so many action points (depending on your speed, strength, awareness and many more) that you can do in a turn. Walking 1 square requires 1 action point, shooting different weapons require more as well as other various actions.

Travelling the world map, again is very much like the original fallout games. You have the map, and your icon traverses across it as you may run into random encounters, there are oasises everywhere that give you water (as you gotta refill water to keep traversing the map), and you can run across various settlements this way. There are also radiation clouds that you must watch out for, you can go through them but you need radiation gear otherwise your party will get killed while walking through  it.

On top of the game mechanics and battle systems, the quests themselves are very intriguing, lots of side content and missions to do, and A LOT of choices to do in those missions. You can do missions so many different ways, from sneaking into a fort and killing some dudes to negotiating with them and allying them with you, to poisoning their food and killing them off.
The main big missions usually have various different outcomes in the missions, each giving you a drastically different faction running an area, or having you liked or hated by another faction, and even unlocking different potential companions depending on how you finished the mission.

The game itself sort of gears you to be a good guy"
date: in that you are a team of rangers that are supposed to be a police force in a post apocalyptic wasteland - but you don't have to be. Though the game would be MUCH harder being a bad guy
recommended: there's nothing stopping you and you can kill anyone you feel like for any reason. Though your NPC characters (that arent created by the PC) usually dont like when you go around double dealing guys

reviewText:
Ultimately, Wasteland 2 is an average game that scratches a particular nostalgia itch for many gamers and is receiving praise beyond its merits.  Quite frankly, the Turn-based strategy genre has been in a drought for nearly a decade and fans are dying of thirst to the extent they'll lap up contaminated water riddled with disease and ask for seconds.  They're so enamored with a sub-standard product they don't recognize they're dying a most dishonorable death from dysentery.

Combat - The combat is lackluster and is not tactical nor strategic in any sense of the fashion.  OK Corral gun duels might be more appropriate, except slow and with none of the skill involved.  If you want a game with good combat, just replay XCOM2012 or Xenonauts.

Character building - No skill tree, no perks, nothing to be found except redundant skills to simply dump your stat points into every time you level up.  If you're looking for the complexity and fun of a D&D style character sheet, keep looking.  If you're looking for a Fallout perk system... keep looking.  Even Diablo 3, which the avid fans of W2 seem keen to mock, has a far more indepth character building system.

Story -  Glaring plot hole at the beginning of the game that most people seem to overlook or simply not notice.  Even if you look past that, the only clever aspect of the entire game is the little Easter Eggs you'll occasionally find.  However, finding kitty litter, a condom, or big black didlo for the 15th time is just sad.  It's funny the first time, but like any good joke, you have to know when to quit effing telling it.  If you want a game with a good story, reboot Mass Effect, BG, Fallout... pretty much any other CRPG.

Characters - Easily forgettable and none that will be remembered.  No Minsc & Boo, HK-47, Commander Shepards, Irenicus (best villain ever), Tomi Grin Undergallows etc.  No Delita or Ramza to be found here.  For the most part, they're as bland and lifeless as the Arizona wastes you'll wander around for the first half of the game.

Exploration - Some of the environments are interesting, but with the terrible combat and random loot, much of the fun is taken out of it.

Graphics - The game wasn't trying to inspire us with graphical prowess or eye porn, but what it delivered is unpolished and ugly.  Some will argue it's stylistic or gritty, but to each their own.

Sound - Ok, but no gripping musical scores to be found here.

At the end of the day, everything W2 set out to do has been done before (obviously), but done far better.

reviewText:
I got this game in early access. I tried to play and like it but was frustrated at the learning curve and didn't really have the time to invest in it. This winter/spring I finally had the time and was rewarded with a terrific experience. Like every game I have played, it has a few warts. That's expected and if they are warts you can live with you will absolutely love this game. So let's talk warts first.
Very convoluted plot lines for a few important quests. I didn't find the solutions intuitive and resorted to a walkthrough because while I had extra time, I didn't have THAT much time to constantly reload and try all of the different permutations.
I did not like the mechanics of weapon stripping. Could just be my luck but when it said I have a 20% chance at a tactical scope...it never worked out that way. But honestly, the system could be better. Realistically, a weaponsmith takes a gun or whatever and removes the non damaged parts...right? At level 10 weaponsmithing I expect to be able to choose what to take and, assuming it's viable, I should have a 100% chance of removing it. I own firearms in RL, have stripped them and cleaned them too many times. A better approach would be a predetermined roll on what attachement(s) is/are undamaged and then based on your WS skill make the roll. Frankly, a Tactical scope is still a scope, and if undamaged, would be just as easy to remove as my old scope I had on my .22.
I started recording my skill checks and at the end of the game, for those checks of 65% or less, I averaged half that. One time it took me 23 tries on a 28% lock. So, my point is, I wasted a lot of time reloading instead of playing. Accuse me of OCD? You'd be right but it still interfered with the game to a level that I thought, disturbed the immersion.
So, the good stuff? EVERYTHING else is fantastic. The combat tactics are brilliant. The skill and attribute systems perfect for this game. The atmosphere, the music, the diverse characters you meet and sometimes recruit...love you Scotchmo. Story, excellent, gear, terrain and graphics very good. Voice actors, 9/10.
All the little bits. IE: finding caches and shrines. Having a goat or a dog or a puppy (careful with that btw) or a robot or a terror hang with ya and love you....priceless.
Finally, if you want and old style isometric game that is very challenging to learn, then provides a great story and combat tactics......this is for you.
WELL done InExile, well done. 9/10

reviewText:
If you're looking for a turn-based RPG, it doesn't get a whole lot better than this.  The game has many minor flaws - most of which are UI-related - but the world and writing oozes character and sucks you in.  There could also be some mild balance issues, but I'm not entirely convinced they're all in my head and I'm just rebelling against the CLASSIC system in Wasteland 2, compared to the SPECIAL system I'm used to from Fallout and Fallout 2.

If I had any one desire, it'd be deeper, more interesting combat - especially given how common combat is! - but while it's not going to match XCOM: Enemy Unknown in that area, it's not *bad*, either.

Wasteland 2 may not appeal to everyone, but if you're interested an old-school, turn-based CRPG, this'll scratch that itch for you.

reviewText:
In recent years there has been a lot of games that have tried to fill the gap that is the survival genre,  but there is few very games that quench that thirst quite like Wasteland 2. The difference is how involved you feel when making decisions. Generally in games, you're divided between good and bad, and depending on how you want to play, you'll either help or kill those you meet. Of course this is possible in Wasteland, but your actions bare much larger consequences than you might have first anticipated. Then again, you probably won't live long enough to see these play out...

The short:

Wasteland 2 is a top-down, strategy-survival, RPG that is difficult, challenging and extensive in both content, and quality. For those that love narrative, there's plenty of it, and it's good material, well written and some is voice acted, which is exceptionally high-quality. Combat is much alike that you'll find within XCOM: Enemy Unknown. You'll find yourself using cover to reduce hit chances, you'll command your units individuially around the battlefield and when a unit is down, he's down for good. There's a unique sense that your actions matter. Each trap you disarm, each surviver you encounter, you feel a part of a world that's much larger than what you see. Characters have personalities and behave in believeable motion. It's an experience that, unless you're an old-school RPG fan, you'll unlikely have experienced before, and that's a refreshing sensation that's rare to find.

Pros:

-Great narrative & voice acting.
-Dynamic, tactical combat.
-Well optimized.
-Choices with consequences.
-Rich character creation and custimization options.
-Great emphasis on survival & difficulty.

Cons:

-Objectives can sometimes be unclear, or poorly presented.
-Slow to start and pick up the pace.
-Graphics feel outdated in comparison to newer titles.

The Long:

In recent years, the survival genre has become saturated with a wide range of games, all looking to fill the gap. This could be traced back to the release, and huge success of Minecraft, which arguably changed the genre to what it is today. These games are great, but having played Wasteland 2 for a few hours now, the differences are remarkable.

The main difference I find is the connection you have with the world. You create a squad of four characters, either using pre-made selections, or by creating your own, from scratch. This is where this sensation begins. If you decided to create your squad, you decide exactly who your character is, what they look like and what their story is by creating a character page, which includes a bio, name, age and religion, Despite not being familiar with the Wasteland series, or games like it, I felt compelled to sit down and dream up stories that define my characters. Very few games can achieve this sense of importance and connection that ties you and your characters so closely together. Wasteland 2 follows a similiar perma-death system to that found in XCOM: Enemy Unknown. You'll play with your four characters, but once they die, they're gone, for good. You can reload saves and retry, but in a game that focuses so much on consequences and connections, it almost feels like you're cheating yourself out of the real satisfaction that makes this game unique. Sure, seeing a character you've survived with for ten hours or so is sad, but that sensation of waving them goodbye, and moving forward enhances the overall aspect of what survival is really about, and Wasteland does this brilliantly.

Amongst the character creation is a range of skills and perks that you'll use to develop your characters personality. As you level your characters, you'll obtain opportunities to further enhance their abilities, or simply learn new ones. It's important to have a good balance of skills within your squad, otherwise you might find that you'll quickly become nothing more than a pile of bones amongst the wasteland. A few of these skills include:

-Abilities to use weapons, such as: Heavy weapons, Assault weapons, Shotguns, Snipers, Blunt Weapons, Brawl weapons, Blades and so on.

-Technical abilities, such as: Picklocking, Safecracking, Alarm disarming, surgeon, Field medic and so forth.

-General abilities, such as: Leadership, Smart, Kick and Kiss-♥♥♥ conversational abilities, weaponsmithing and more.

There's a range of about twenty different abilities, which can be shared amongst your squad, however your see fit. In addition to this, your characters can be equipped with armours, radiation protection, cosmetic clothing, and untrained weaponary to suit your play-style. There's very few limitations within Wasteland, a point which is clear right from the beginning. You're immediatelly introduced how to interact with the environment, which brings me to versitility. Wasteland 2 is tinsled with the concept of free-choice, you're never forced into approaching an area or battle with a particular play-style, it's up to you whether you want to run in, guns blazing, or whether you want to seek out the high ground, and be more patient. The same can be said about the environment too. In the situation that you're presented with a door that's obstructing your path, you have several options. You can either hack it, picklock it, use brute force, set explosives, manipulate an NPC to open it, find the passcode or simply give up and go get lunch. The emphasis on choice is very much alive and kicking.

Combat is fluid, tactical and intense. Each unit has a set of action points, everything you do will consume an amount, once you've used them up, it's onto the next unit for their turn. Alternatively, you can end your turn sooner to save the points which will be added to that units next turn. This makes for strategic decisions and a good mindset in plannig ahead. The combat system uses an inititive system. Each unit has an inititive stat, decided by their stats and their gear, depending on how high or low that number might be depends on which position in the queue roaster they'll be able to take their turn. Units with a higher inititive might find themselves acting not only quicker, but more frequently than those with lower stats. You control your units independantly, moving them across the battlefield, using cover and action points each turn. If a unit dies, you have a set amount of turns to revive them, otherwise they're gone for good and you best hope there's an NPC in a nearby town willing to fill the hole. Combat in Wasteland can be compared to that within XCOM, however because this is also a survival game, there's much more to it that simply shooting at targets, it's knowing when to shoot, and when to run that matters. Ammo is limited, very limited. At the beginning of the game you'll start with no more than a single round of ammo, for each of your weapons. It's up to you to hunt and purchase more. This doesn't seem like such a problem, but it makes combat encounters that little more intense, just knowing each bullet you use could well be the reason you die ten minutes later to a group of bandits. There's a tactical element to the combat that very other games can match. There are plenty of times when an opportunity to kill an enemy emerges, but it's in those moments when you have to pause, and consider the consequences of using those rounds, those supplies. It sounds very simply. Shoot, and resupply later, but in Wasteland, later is a struggle to reach when you're well equipped, let alone when you've got one arm shot off and you're crawling amongst the dirt like a sloth.

There's much more to say about Wasteland, but it's an experience you'll have to have yourself to know the true values that make this title unqiue. It's engaging, connected and impactful right from the moment you hit play. Pick this up, take your time, question your decisions and enjoy perhaps one of the best RPGs in recent years.

9.5/10 ~ Simply brilliant.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is very much defined by your expectations of it - on its own, or as a sequel to the original Wasteland, it stands proud and incredibly successful, with a rich storyline (mostly) and fun gameplay, leaning more towards combat than dialog and choices, but still having plenty of the latter two just the same.

But if you expect Fallout 1/2 depth, or its balance of combat and choices, you shall be somewhat disappointed.

My advice? Take the game for what it is, and enjoy the ride. 'cause it's a great game, with a fantastic game world designed and written into it.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since the first minute I could download it when the beta went live ... it has gone from a game that my very decent computer was barely able to run ... to the smooth shiny beast that we have today ... this game is hard ... especially on the hardest difficulty ... and it does give you a huge number of ways to tackle all the problems ... I have done multiple series on YouTube of the different versions of the beta ... I have found bug after bug and struggled to find my way around ... and I have loved every single minute of it ...

http://youtu.be/BaPTV68PRMk

If you are interested I am doing a complete playthrough - all secrets - all dialogue - all the game on the hardest difficulty ... see above ...

But what do I really think of the game ...

If I take my fan-boy hat off ... actually I am going to leave it firmly on ... the first Wasteland is the game that defined my childhood and the open world ... freedom to do what ever you want ... freedom of choice kind of game I have been looking for ever since ...

I have waited 25 years for this game ...

Does it live up to my expectations ... yes it does ... it has the same heart the old game did ... your choices mean something ... they have an effect on the story around you ... there are consequences that ripple out from things that you do ... the world is just what I remember ... although I miss Needles and Quartz so very much ...

The game is not perfect ... but it is everything that I wanted ... the combat is fantastic ... the art direction is great ... I would have liked better character modesl for my rangers but that is ok ...

I can't wait to finish this and then start again at the beginning and do it differently ...

Brian Fargo ... you have made my childhood dream come true ... and bugs and issues taken into account ... this is one of the best games I have played in years ...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Remember Wasteland?

1988, a pivotal year towards the close of the last century.
Arnold Schwarzenegger discovered that Danny Devito was his long lost twin.
Tom Cruise encouraged Dustin Hoffman to play a little blackjack and George Bush senior had just been voted into office.
A fact which I'm sure had no bearing on the emergence of a brand new gaming genre, the post apocalyptic RPG.

Let's not Fall Out over it!

The original Wasteland was a ground-breaking title back in the day with recruitable NPC's populating a persistent world. This is something we take for granted in RPG's today, but back in the pink and blue neon haze of the 80's this was unheard-of.

Even if you haven't heard of the original Wasteland, I'm certain you'll be familiar with the Fall Out franchise. A franchise which would probably not exist had wasteland not come before.

In the meantime"

It was nearly 10 years after Wastelands release before we got our hands on its spiritual successor Fallout.
Sequels were planned for Wasteland but they never quite came to fruition
date:
but now thanks to a little thing called kick starter and loyal fans with long memories ...

Apocalypse Now

... We have the imminent and long overdue release of Wasteland 2.
After 26 years lost in the wilderness
hoursPlayed: but are we in danger of placing Wasteland 2 on a pedestal
voteText:
expecting too much and inevitably about to face disappointment when September 19th rolls around?

Four Rangers and a Funeral

After hitting the play button for the first time you'll find yourself at the character creation screen.
Here you'll find more stats and options than you could shake an iguana on a stick at

with skills ranging from animal whisperer to toaster repair.

Prepare to spend an unhealthy amount of time agonising over the attributes and skills sets for your posse of wannabe rangers.
Not that this isn't fun

Once you've settled on what you hope is a complimentary skill set for your four rangers you'll be treated to a highly atmospheric cinematic which cleverly fills in a little of the back story for the desert rangers and leaves your group standing around the fresh grave of a fallen comrade.

Ace in the Hole

The writing on the makeshift coffin reads "Born a man
votesFunny:
died a desert ranger"
It's here that the game starts as "Ace" is laid to rest and you're team picks up his failed assignment.
It's this assignment that will be your first thread of the main quest that you will follow through Wasteland 2.

Triffid or not Triffid
commentsCount:
That is the Question

After some interesting conversations with the NPCS at the graveside you'll head off on your first mission and it's here that the first moral choice hits hard and fast.
There's a distress signal from Highpool

reviewText:
When I first heard about Wasteland 2 I was excited the game was getting excellent reviews and I bought into the hype. After playing for a few hours saving Highpool I felt really burnt out which isn’t something you want your game to do. There is just too many meaningless fights and the quests are the most boring nonsense I have ever encountered most were broken at the time which greatly ruined the game for me.

The main problem with the game is its gameplay I love turn-based combat but not when it takes 20-30mins per fight it just isn't fun. It still doesn’t have that element that makes combat satisfying that will have players coming back and investing hours into your game. The story is uninteresting, companions have zero personalities along with its countless bugs, forced story choices, stupid AI, no strategy required, useless game mechanics or terrible controls.

Overall I would not recommend this game I had to force myself to finish it and don't understand how it is getting a Game of the Year Edition. Wasteland 2 is just mediocre at best Fallout 1 & 2 or Jagged Alliance are by far superior and I wish I could refund this game.

reviewText:
Summary at bottom for those of you in a hurry.

I approached this game as a newcomer to the series. I had never played the original. So, I have no fan boy bias at all. I will probably end up comparing it to Fallout at times, but I WAS NOT expecting it to be a clone of Fallout. I will repeat that to make sure everyone understands that. I WAS NOT expecting this game to be exactly like Fallout. That being said, nobody can deny the two are similar. They’re both apocalypse’ish games that are centered on RPG mechanics.

The Good: I actually liked the looks of the game. They’re aren’t the most high definition graphics, but they do look right. The game mechanics work well when it comes to combat. I liked that you got to customize up to four characters to play as. That’s something you don’t get to see very often. The last time I remember getting to customize more than one character in a game like this is Jagged Alliance 2. The combat was pretty solid. It has some issues, but nothing that can’t be fixed with some tweaking. The sound effects were good and so was the music. Sadly that’s about where my praise for the game ends.

The Bad: The characters. I didn’t really find any to get attached to. The only character I liked was one of the random NPC characters you can pick up. Any game like this has to have characters with personality. You have to either love or hate at least some of the characters for anything to matter. Fallout 2, which is the closest game to compare this to, had great NPC characters. I just would have liked more connection with the characters. I remember going around with Cassidy (and his daughter in New Vegas) and enjoying their company. Next, there are the bugs. This game has acres of them, but I’m willing to give that a pass right now since it’s new and this is an indie developer. They seem determined to fix them, so good on them.

The Ugly: The story. I found it boring. There was no hook to it. The story starts off with you attending Ace’s funeral. Ace was a ranger and so is your party. You are tasked with the mission he was trying to complete of attaching devices to some nearby towers to track a transmission. This transmission has been transmitting some very worrisome messages. The problem with this whole plot is there’s no attachment to it. I didn’t know Ace before he was dead, so there’s no attachment to him. I don’t know the Rangers, so I can’t feel attached to them. This comes especially so when the General doesn’t let you in the main fort to get supplies. He even lampshades this saying something about it being a real dangerous mission when you ask to go inside to get supplies. You can very minimal supplies outside at a trader, but still. You don’t feel like you’re being treated like one of the group, so why should you care about them? Without spoiling anything, you get to a point in the story where some bandits are harassing the area, so you have to deal with them. Now, their camp is guarded by these huge invincible turrets. I was gratuitously over leveled at this point because I had explored every square inch of the game so far, but they slaughtered me. I was frustrated with this, but accepted it at the moment. But, on a whim, I decided to see if I could take on Ranger Citadel (the Ranger HQ). I wanted to do it just for fun, not to actually keep as part of my save. I slaughtered everyone with ease in there and the only one who posed a threat was the General. The four turrets in Ranger Citadel went down it 2-3 hits each. It made no sense that the highly militarized and organized group had worse equipment than some bandits. To be fair though, I did like the second half of the story a lot more. The second half of the game could have been the start and I would have liked it a lot more. There was more personalization with the characters and therefore the events happening in the story mattered.

Long story short: I do not recommend this game. The story was lackluster. It lacked any sort of immediate trouble in the game. There weren’t any memorable characters for me. I had the same problem with Skyrim (I know they’re very different games). They both had good gameplay, but lacked anything that could remotely be called a good story or characters. Good story and characters is pretty much 75% of an RPG.

reviewText:
Just finished this game, I will say I had to start a second playthrough, skills are important and characters with dumped intel really suffer for skills and things to do.  So after reading a few guides I decided to start a second playthrough.  With a better rounded party and more skills to get involved with challenges it made for far more interesting gameplay.

Dialogue - only certain characters are voiced and then rarely, but this is more than made up for by the excellently written character dialogue and conversation pieces.  Some very excellent post-apocalyptic sarcasm to be had :D

Game play - loved it, obvious comparison to other genre staples aside, the game has a really smooth challenge curve, very rarely did any fights feel easy.  Keeps you thinking and planning.

Storyline - Excellent, particularly enjoyed the way the post ending wrap up is handled.

Thank you to Ehrgeix for recommending this game to me!

reviewText: An RPG in the classic styling.  One of the more fun turn based RPG's i have ever played. The combat is decent but to me the game shines for it's story, and the way skills work are well done.  I'd put this game up there with any of the top RPG's i have ever played, especially if you are the sort of person that likes topdown, party based games.  Learning how to build a team is key, but there are guides around for that. Over all i'd give it a solid 8/10. My reasoning is there is always a bit of room for imporvemnt, like greater customization. It also could use a few more deeper choices or branching story lines, but it does have many already so it is more nit picking thatn a flaw. Id really love to see a wasteland 3 down the road, or another style game using a similar system.\n\nAs far as polish goes, i have yet to have a single crash, or encounter a bug that stopped a quest in over 100 hours of play. It would seam like they have ironed out the early bugs quite nicely.

reviewText:
Are you an intelligent gamer interested in actually reading the colour text and searching between the lines in conversations for clues, looking for a deep, superbly-written role playing experience with a dash of turn-based tactical interest thrown in?  Yes? Then you absolutely MUST get Wasteland 2.

I could rave for hours about the old-school feel with the up-to-date features. I could go on and on about the stellar writing that was a core premise of what got me into gaming so many years ago. I could even enthuse about the art style, the tone, the humour, the grittiness and the lack of punches pulled in the overall theme.  I won't, I don't need to. If you have any sense or any taste whatsoever, you will play this game, you will give it your attention and your love and in return it will make a little home in your heart such that it will stay with you forever.

Simply superb.

I was a kickstarter backer and waited for this a long time. I really like deep rpg's and thought this would be my game.

How you need to google what skill disarms trap because the skill with disarm in the name is actually alarm disarm" and you need to use demolitions skill. reviewText: I pre-ordered this and I really really wanted to like it. Unfortunately there is not a lot to love. I know with the onset of roguelike RPG's there seems to be a consumer market for old-school difficult games but there is a fundamental difference between difficult and inconvenient. Wasteland 2 isn't that difficult it is just extremely inconvenient. Spammy and monotonous battles on the main map, no useful fast travel for getting from one area to another, and writing that, while definitely serviceable (sometimes funny), just doesnt stack up against other major RPGs. The combat is boring as hell, the upgrades system is weak and unineteresting, and their is little depth (though they can be interesting) to the few characters you can pick up that do have characterization (the main group you use is a blank slate with zero characterization). When you compare this to Kickstarter RPG's such as Pillars of Eternity there is just no comparison. Pillars of Eternity (which I am using as a comparison because it is also a kickstarter) is just a fundamentally better game.  Sure the graphics are crap (what do you expect from a kickstarter game?) but the plot, characters, upgrade system and combat is infinitely (haha  pun) better. This is not a horrible way to kill time but there are just a lot better ways to kill it.

reviewText:
EDIT for Enhanced Edition:
Still buggy and unoptimized. Buy it if you are a patient person and the price drops to 10 EUR.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
According to devs, it is finished and they are just fixing bugs (the final patch will not invalidate saves, but it may damage them - release date is 19.9.2014). So, the time has come to make a judgment (preliminary since I did not finish the game, yet).

Well, it is a difficult to decide, if I should recommend this or not.

I will judge based on playing a lot of computer games, especially role-playing ones, but tactical, TBS, RTS and plenty more, too. First of all, I consider Fallout 2 with Restoration Project from Killap (I bow before this guy) as a kind of standard. I did play the original Wasteland, all Fallouts (F1, F2, Tactics, F3, Vegas).
Right at this moment, this game is a disappointment for me (because I had very high expectations). The combat is comparable to Tactics (FT being better for me, but it is a matter of taste) and the role-playing part is worse than F2. It's a mixture, but it seems to me that the focus is on tactical combat with some RP decision making.
It is not a bad game compared to what is produced these days. I just hoped that it would be so much better. There are some things – even in combat – that take away the immersion for me. So, if you liked Tactics, go for it – but not for the current ridiculous price. If you like more role-playing I would wait till the game is modded (fingers crossed) and there is a sale.

Graphics is OK, nothing groundbreaking, but it does the job.
Audio is OK, there no catchy tune in my mind, yet – but it corresponds to the setting.
I would like to note that there may be something along the story that will change my mind. I will update after I finish the game (I will also go into more details about those little pesky things like the enemies with infinite ammo; they don’t drop stuff they were using in combat, etc.).

reviewText:
After finishing the game (70 Hours) here is my verdict.


Gameplay/

Gameplay is one of the most aspects that drive my judjment towrd any game, the more solid the gameplay and polished the more i invest my self with it.

The battle system doesn't offer much of creativity or presenting a new ideas, compering it to XCOM Enemy Unknown which has a simillar battle system, though the latter is better in that aspect.

The AI in this game is highly underdeveloped, enemies with ranged weapons would charge towrd you despite that it will hinder thier accuracy and hit chances and they don't seem to use the environment In their favor that much, like cover for instance.

The difficulty spikes seems to be absent most of the time regarding that you know what you're doing. I have't encounter any impossible situation that hinderd my progress. All of the hard encouters is doable with a will excuted strategy ofcurse.

Nice and will implemented skills system that add a decent and rich experiance.
_____


Graphics and Sounds/

I don't usually mind graphics in games too much, but I do agree it gives a nice boost to the game experiance.

Graphicly the game is not emprassive at all, varrying between a poor characters design and a moderate enviroment design.

yet there is some nice areas that have some depth on them.

The sounds generally is fairly good, but the game lack variety in the soundtrack department.
_____

Story and Writting/

Likable strory with some nice twists and a bold and brilliant writting.The strongest features in this game is the writting and it's quist line.

The game Intelligently combine decision making with your team's skills to progress through the game, making every playthrough a different experince.

It sometimes present a deep and philosophical ideas but somehow faild to present it properly.


_____

The technical side

Unfortunately the game doesn't excel technically, starting with massive frame drop and graphical glitches.

In the first half of the game the frame rate average at ~90 FPS then drop dramatically in the second half at average of ~35 FPS (680 GTX OC).

A lot of the time the game won't responds to mouse ckicks when initiating skills command.
____

reviewText:
I paid $10 for it and I feel ripped off.  Your 95% to hit is really about 40%, and the levelling system is ponderous at best. As others have said, the voice acting is atrocious.  The game plays better without it, but that doesn't help all that much because the text is boring to read.  The movement is slow and lanky.  It really ruins immersion when I'm bored and watching my guys move ponderously slow.  This game has too many serious flaws to be worth playing.

The levelling system is seriously just painfully bad. You get 23 attribute points, and you get 2-5 skill points depending on how many of your attribute points you put into Intelligence.  You can't raise your attributes later on.  So if you put half your attributes into intelligence, then you cripple your combat skills so you can get enough survival skills end-game.

First skill level takes 1 point, 2nd takes 2, 3rd takes 3, etc. You have 4 characters and you can get an npc.  You will need to level 10 non-combat skills to open doors, see traps, upgrade weapons, etc.  Another few skills if you want to get good use out of your medical supplies.

If you're a big fan of games like these, check out the Avernum line of games or X-COM: Enemy Unknown.     You can get Avernum on sale for $1-3  and it is far superior.

reviewText:
Is Wasteland 2 up to spec?  No, sadly, it is not.

As a squad-based RPG, it feels more like FO:Tactics than Wasteland.  There is a storyline, but the actual roleplay suffers from the lack of a central character.  You end up with less of a Fallout-style Jack of All Trades and more of a set of specialists that feels stale.

The game also seems unfinished, with many bugs still present and most problems have one real solution and a bunch of approaches to it.  The conversation choices are just garnish and a lot of interactions will result in being attacked without a chance to explain or talk it out.  Prepare to be frustrated by a game that looks more modern, but lacks depth (plenty of breadth, though).

It's been covered in other reviews, but here are the basic issues with this over-specialization:

-You have to constantly switch between party members for each task (lockpicking, safecracking, defusing, disabling) and wait for each to have a small loading icon to complete the task.  The delay between selection, the poor controls, and having to swap between them makes it tedious.  All for an old teddy bear, a used polaroid, and some scrap metal (not a joke, this is the kind of loot you will be seeing a lot of).
-Success at these skills yields XP, but only to the party-member who does it.  This means that your demo guy will be getting a lot more, as almost everyone in the wastes seems to have the knowledge, supplies, and desire to trap everything.
-Some weapons types are so situationally specific as to be obnoxious (looking at you shotgun and heavy weapons).  Others have handicaps that don't make sense (an assault rifle suffers a penalty to hit when a target is adjacent, which the AI exploits by rushing a group of heavily armed people with an axe).
-You have to micro-manage prior to combat to ensure that your weapons are optimally employed, but it is often a matter of getting interrupted by the enemy spotting you (no, there is no sneak" option either) and having combat kick off prematurely while you awkwardly select and move your personnel.
-NPCs (to include hire-ons) have a tendency to go rogue
date: ruining your carefully-crafted team composition and plan.  This usually means rushing out of cover and often shooting past teammates
recommended: hitting them in the process.  Tag-alongs (like animal friends or story characters) are always in this AI pattern
hoursPlayed:
making you leave your positions to take the heat off of them.

Now let's talk about design.
-Levels are often open areas with little or nothing to do in them.  A few stashes (with locks

reviewText:
Let me get one thing out of the way first: I do recommend this game, I think it's great and it makes me feel like I'm playing the original Fallouts again... BUT. I had very high hopes for it initially, I wanted it to be a worthy successor to Fallout 2 and it just falls short in comparison for several reasons.

The first thing I noticed is that the locations are graphically very busy but their size encourages to view them with the camera zoomed out all the way. This sometimes makes it hard to make out items of interest like NPC, chests and doors, I often find myself scanning the screen with my mouse, hoovering over everything trying to find something I could have missed. It's often also hard to see how high a given structure is or where are the characters allowed to walk, this is also due to the camera rotating freely and the levels not being designed to be viewed from a certain fixed perspective.

My second gripe is the dialogue system, there are no dialogue trees and instead you always have a list of topics a given NPC can tell you more about, this makes talking feel much less impactful. I do love however that there is not one but three talking skills that might come handy at different times, hard-♥♥♥, smart-♥♥♥ and kiss-♥♥♥, each of which unlocks different replies that might change the outcome of a conversation.

Another thing is the level design which often feels streamlined with one path leading you from start to end of a level. This is not always the case and there are some great non-linear locations, but I feel the Fallouts did a better job at this.

Lastly, I don't really feel there are that many impactful choices in the game, NPC interactions often just lead you to the one expected outcome and 12 hours in I think there was only one meaningful choice I had to make.

Still it's a very solid game. The combat is pretty deep, with positioning playing an important role. The skill selection is awesome, every one feels very important and comes in handy more often than not. There is an element of crafting, you can apply upgrades to weapons or strip them for parts. Trying to optimise your team build to cover the whole spectrum of skills and to be effective in combat is fun in itself, and you can always ignore some skills and concentrate on others (for example you don't need lockpicking and safecracking much if you know how to use explosives or brute force). I also like how non-initial party members always have a chance of going 'out of control' during combat and shooting an enemy of their choice instead of letting you issue orders, this effect can be mitigated with the leadership skill.

All in all I don't regret backing it on Kickstarter and I haven't played such a good RPG in a very long time, but still it could have been much more.

EDIT: After finishing the game I have to admit that there is indeed quite a lot of interesting choices in it, the longer you play, the more of them you see. I highly recommend this game if you enjoyed Fallout 1/2 and Torment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK, this shows promise and as a fan of the first Wasteland I really like the walk down memory lane.
The first few hours of game play were,however, a bit frustrating to say the least.

***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS***

So you get this mission to check out a radio tower. The problem is if you don't go there straight away and roam a little you trigger this new quest line of either going to Highwater or some agricultural station. Your 'boss' tells you that these calls have priority over you initial mission, so off you go!
Problem is, you automatically fail one of them. While you're exploring some hydro-plant which is about to fail you get this desperate radio calls from the other mission, how they're overrun but you can do nothing about it as the hydro-plant is about to explode. Moreover, prior to the power plant mission you get some side quests which ALL fail if you don't do them first. Basically, I saved the town's power plant from destruction but the grateful people of Highwater kicked me out of town because I did not kill the bandits first, found a dog and put out a fire for them. Consequently, the wrong person gets the votes to be the new mayor. He's all in with the bandits and tells me to get the hell out of town.
Basically, after six hours of game play I'm a total failure. Is this a feature? I don't know. Maybe this game is about priorities but the jumps in the quest system seem contrived and lack immersion this way. Non-linear is OK but if you simply say 'If you don't do missions A,B and C before D then they must have failed!' is a bit sloppy in terms of story-telling to me.

***END SPOILERS***

Apart from that you pretty much get a product as advertised: An isometric sequel to Wasteland 1. It is all there! The setting, the desolate arid lands, the radiation zones, the bandits and mutants and all those old-school turn-based combat fights. The skill system is almost pen&paper-like but does the trick. The item system is working as intended. I really like how easy you could set up hot buttons and point and click your way to skill checks and interactions.
I did have a hard time getting used to camera controls and setting up teams of party members but that might be my inexperience at work here.

Bottom line: As a fan of the original Wasteland, you will not want to miss this, but the game does confront you with certain constraints you might not consider acceptable in a modern open world setting.
But what do you get if you deduct the fandom? Not sure about that at this stage of development. I will restart the story with my utter and complete failure in mind and update my verdict.
As for now I think you get a better chunk of post-apocalyptic America for your bucks from Fallout 3/New Vegas games.

We'll see.......

Disclosure: I backed this with $50 during the KS campaign.

As a huge fan of Fallout 1 and 2, Wasteland 2 has been a great enjoyment. Whilst I think the game could certainly use a little more polish (there are some minors bugs and balance annoyances to address), the quality of the writing and content is extremely high.

I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys story driven RPGs with a strong focus on both choice and consequence, and grey morality. I hope both Wasteland 2 and Divinity Original Sin are just the start of the return of the classic CRPG.

reviewText:
I like this game.  Please read further as I try to form paragraphs and make relevant points.

Probably the biggest compliment I can give this game, this is as close to Fallout 1/2 as we are going to get anytime soon.  There are lots of weapons/skills/stats and character development.  The post apocalyptic atmosphere is well done.  The game has dozens of hours of content.  The game was compelling enough for me to play it to completion.

While the game is a positive experience overall, I have a few nitpicks -- The UI is a little clunky and limited. The balance between weapons\skills\stats could be better e.g., Assualt rifles are generally better than other weapons in most circumstances.   Finally, the skill checks encourage save scumming like no other game I have played in recent memory.

Best Regards, (the)King of Save Scumming
