reviewText:
Early Access Review

The good:
++++ Incredible artwork (portraits, areas, ... )
+++ Good writing: dialogue, storyline
++ Impressive game Atmosphere: created by the music, the in game artwork/colours & mature environment.
++ Game for adults: doesn't shy away from credible violence like seen in Mad max movies or a little bit of controversial violence and adult themes
++ A lot of nice variation in environment locations (official ones)
+++++ Originality (Tons of good original ideas: like the mad monks f.e.)
++++++ The only old school RPG released at this date. It s not hard to be the best when you re the only one competing for the title, but despite the lack of competition for being the best Old school RPG the game is pretty damn good at becoming something as memorable as the Fallout 1 & 2 games where for me. (Not talking about Bethesda s version of Fallout as that is clearly a different game: more an adventure game like Oblivion). Fallout 1 & 2 fans will feel right at home, not having played wasteland 1 I can not speak for Wasteland 1 fans.

The bad:
---- Combat turn based isn't as good as in the latest Xcom game, could use a lot of improvement. But this isn't the focus of the game, so that s ok.
----- Random encounters not always as good. But I guess these can be improved later with patches to improve them.

------ Learning Curve: Hard to figure out for new players how to build your characters: f.e. in the build screen it isn't obvious that low intellingence will cap the progress of your surgeon skill/ other skills or that strength lvl 4 is needed to wear certain types of armour. You will need several tries before you will figure out what is a good party and what isn't and which attributes go well together with each other and with which other skills. Maybe that s why this game has a manual: but to be honest, I never read the manual for playing a game (I try to figure it out on the go)

It would be nice to see in a blink of an eye which attributes affect which skills and how. Or how f.e. group charisma has an effect to inviting new companions.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I backed the Kickstarter and I've played during the beta.

Wasteland 2 may look a bit iffy on the graphics end and there are some bugs that haven't been fixed yet (although I haven't seen anything gamebreaking yet) but quality can be found in just about everything else.

This game is basically made for anyone who was a big fan of the old Fallout games (1 and 2) and possibly the first Wasteland game that came out in 1988. You take the role of four desert rangers who have been tasked with traveling to different areas in Arizona to help people in need in a world where nuclear war has taken place and is now... well, a Wasteland. The world is ridden with radioactivity, punks, fanatics, cyborgs, the list goes on.

Wasteland 2 is a roleplaying turn-based strategy game. You have the ability to move about as either a group or split your team members up for tactical advantages. For example, mabye one of your team members is a sniper and you want that person to stay behind and pick off the enemies while your mid to close range characters take the front line. Be careful though since this game has friendly fire.

As you start you get to create your four characters in a typical roleplaying game fashion. Place stats, choose skills, names, looks, etc. It can be very tricky to pick the right skills for each character because there are many skills to choose from and you won't be able to pick them all and still be able to use them all effectively since there won't be enough points for you to distribute for such a run. You will quickly notice that there are occasional obstacles that will require a quite high level in whatever skill is needed.

One of my favourite aspects of Wasteland 2 is the text that is constantly being displayed in the lower right corner of the screen. Just like in the Fallout games, it details your surroundings, people you meet, objects, etc, just as if it was being told by a very witty game master in a pen-and-paper roleplaying game. Wasteland 2 has lots of black comedy, and I'm a sucker for comedy in games. I generally don't read most flavour text in video games, but in Wasteland 2 I'm willing to make an exception.

All in all, I'm glad to see that Wasteland 2 turned out the way it did because it proves that Kickstarter can work as long as you crowdfund the right projects. Anyone who played the older Fallout games or Wasteland 1 will most likely be very happy to play this. I would go as far as to call this the real Fallout 3.

GOTY 2014.

reviewText:
Introduction

What do Duran Duran, toaster repairing and a post nuclear wasteland all have in common?

Around 1988 I played Wasteland 1 on a C64. It was a cross between Bards Tale 1 type combat with Ultima IV type world movement. It was one of the first games to include a persistent world. The manual asked you to create a copy of the game disks so that choices and consequences you experienced during the game were saved. If you suspected your entire party was going to be wiped out or a gaming catastrophe was imminent and tried pulling out the floppy – it failed.

You were prompted to read chapters of text from a booklet at key points in the game to further the storyline. Wasteland 1 was released in a world without many hard drives so computer memory was restricted. The story booklet also provided a form of copy protection. The developers included fake text to give cheaters a hard time and prevent players from reading ahead and discovering the plot.

Time passes and its now 2015. It fascinates me that I have read reviews about Wasteland 2 from RPG “experts” who were not even alive in 1988. It’s been a long time. Reading these thoughts from youngsters about a sequel to a game they have never played was slightly interesting and mostly offensive. Saying that, I know nostalgia can be a powerful thing. I am glad that the passage of time has faded my memory. Some days I believe any old game released in the 1985-1995 period was a great game as there wasn’t many around. Or more accurately I could not afford that many – heck I was in school. Just look at me now with Steam or GOG – I don’t even have to leave my mother’s basement :)

WL2 is set in Arizona after a nuclear event destroyed much of civilisation. It is a RPG where you can control a party of four rookie desert rangers that have been asked to investigate the murder of a veteran named Ace. As your progress through the game you can recruit NPCs that join your party who bring along their own skillsets. Lacking a medic in your party? Recruit a Doctor. 15 long years have passed since WL1.

Character design

When you begin a new game you can create a party from scratch or import and amend existing rangers. In an attempt to show traditional RPG credentials – the developers have given each character seven attributes using the CLASSIC method (never heard of it either – hardly classic). These include Strength, Intelligence and Awareness.

Interestingly Luck and Charisma also appear. These two seem to be a throwback to D&D and live gaming with a Dungeon Master. Developers seem to struggle finding a real use for them and most players will therefore roll a low score in these to obtain higher scores in Strength, Endurance etc. I would have preferred a more balanced approach regards the attributes so that they were all equally important depending on the build or concept for that character.

It’s almost become fact now that Intelligence is the most important attribute in WL2 as that determines the ability to learn skills. Pretty soon it becomes apparent that unlike many RPGs your attributes do not always link with or enhance your skills. For example a character with 1 ST can be highly skilled and effective in a skill called Brute Force. This disparity is not quite fatal but a poor show nevertheless.

The skillset of your characters are the key factor in determining on whether you will be successful – at anything. The skills are divided into three groups, general, weapon and knowledge and each has ten levels of expertise. There are far too many for any one character or party of four to excel at everything. You need a plan.

If you want to recruit other party members beyond your base four – learn the Leadership skill as that improves their combat abilities and keeps them in check.

If you prefer to shoot first and chat later – you may want to ditch the three conversation skills.

Over my 100 hours of game time – I found that levelling is quite generous and any reasonable INT team member would gain sufficient skill points over the game. I also found that combat skills and ‘how to open stuff’ skills were used 95% of the time.

Skills such as Animal Whisperer, Alarm Disarming and Surgeon were hardly required. The Toaster Repair skill just seemed to be included without much thought and relied heavily on pre-game knowledge. For example, if you fixed a toaster in day 5 of gaming and subsequently acquired an item, that same item would only be of value if you happen to have it in your inventory on day 55. Items from toasters are not marked as quest items. Poor show.

Game Engine

The game engine has a two-fold approach. Movement across the world map is a 2D affair – think Indiana Jones in his airplane. 95% of the game is top down, 2.5D isometric movement with a camera that can zoom out and turn left or right. Graphics were sufficient and I cannot remember any bugs or glitches. Sometimes the game would slow down a trifle in heavy combat or densely populated areas.

The local map representation of towns and places you visit is just diabolical. I struggled to find any use for it apart from seeing where your party is in relation to your entry point. For some reason the developers camouflaged the entries/exits to buildings and other locations on the local map so it takes the gamer about 50 hours to even realise they are there. Not fantastic. I thought we were going back to Wasteland of 1987 – not some crappy game from 1957. Ask the developers when Ultima Underworld was released – for goodness sake!

Summary

There are a lot of things wrong with this game. I would really like to know if players spent more time on opening things or in the dialogue system. I would like to know why in the Rail Nomad area I had to criss-cross the various maps about 100 times.

I want to know why the local map is crap.

Looking back to all the press about it, I wonder about the ‘choice’ you are given at the beginning of the game and why so many journalists sang its praises from high.

I couldn’t remember which items emerged from toasters.

Then I met Simon Le Bon in a random encounter that was Hungry Like a Wolf and then Frankie told me to Relax. Then my heart just melted away and this somewhat not that bad game became something special.

I really enjoyed storytelling for once even though some of it was boring and mundane.

I really enjoyed building up my team of four and wanted them to do well. I watched over them, groomed them and bent them to my will. I was proud each time the radio sent me a message back promoting them in the field of operations.

I spent 100 hours on this game to completion and the only reason I didn’t do another playthrough was because I have some urgent business working through a list of 71 other decent games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me put it this way: it took 62 hours of playing before I decided to take a break from it, and I haven't had it but a couple of months. If you like old school turn based rpg stategy, such as Falloout 1 & 2, old X-Com, Jagged Alliance series, Balders Gate, Planescape: Torment (and somebody needs to gtf on with rebooting Torment, that game was !@#$ing GREAT!), you're going to want this in your collection. The story thus far is pretty damn good, in my opinion, voice acting is well done too. I think it looks great graphically, and I run a mid range gaming comp. Buy it now and help them make it great, or buy it on release, but get it. Seriously. Just understand it's a beta build and treat it as such and you will enjoy it if you like this kind of game, the bugs are not that bad, except for a couple I'll note below. .

The random encounter battles as you travel on the world map are a little small in area, which makes combat down and dirty and  fast, if you're playing anything but Rookie difficulty. That can be a pro or con, depending on what you like and your play style. Feels cramped to me on the majority random encounter maps. It takes away from the strategy aspect when you're pretty much at point blank range in most of your battles, which are pretty lethal to begin with. BUT, they are still fun and it's extremely satisfying when you win by the skin of your teeth. The big battles are hella fun!
Not so much a con and probably a bug, but DO NOT dismiss characters on the world map. At least not Angela, if you have her. I did and unless she's supposed to be gone, she's still out in the Wasteland where I left her. Hope I left her some water, I tkink it was close to a water source, or her and Ace are gonna be meeting again real soon....she's not in the Ranger Citadel either. If you take that kid you save from drowning into your party, and go back to the Citadel, leave him at the entrance or don't let him be with you when you go in, a conversation fires off between him and another member of your party when you go near the museum and you'll be stuck there, in the conversation, with no choice for a response and no other choice but to reload, and that's the only game breaking bug I've found so far. The UI could use some tweeking, status effects are hard to determine visually on quick glance; I had already played many many hours before I noticed the tiny consussion icon above the character portrait for the first time.
Other than those issues and some very minor stability issues that are probably more related to my rig than the game itself, any other bug I've come across, hasn't been anything major. I emphatically recommend this game, it has the potential to be one of the best titles of it's kind in a very, very long time.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 - a game that completly flew under my radar til it was discounted on the last Steamsale. Having played all FallOuts up til New Vegas with the Exception of Tactics I was genuinly interested how this game would work out. That and I'm a huge nerd over CRPGs, still considering Baldur's Gate II the best RPG ever developed.

Gameplay
The game is played from an Isometric perspective, with a typewriter on the right side describing the locations and subtitles. This game has ALOT of reading, so when you are no fan of that you should take that into consideration. Only a few important characters are voiced and your PCs are  mute all the time (Sadly we can not make our own basic voicelines like in Baldur's Gate, but hey atleast we can use our own portraits). You traverse the locations in realtime while the Worldmap has a water limitation and combat is turnbased. It is pretty much reminscent of FallOut 1&2 before the series became what is today. You travel through Arizona visiting the different locations and working towards your way to uncover a sinister plot.

Story
Warning: Heavy Spoilers ahead, read at your own risk

You create your own Rangersquad, consisting from up to 4 Rangerrookies, with different talents which you will more or less all need in the Wastes. Rangergeneral Vargas then sends you to investigate the murder of one of your fellow Rangers paired with the quest to investiagte strange radiotransmissions coming from behind the great radioation wall to the east. While the games plot starts superstrong, it will degrade over time and if you hit Los Angeles later it will drag on longer than it should (Felt for me like it). As soon as you know who Mathias is and what is behind his war" with Dugal the plot becomes more or less predictable and the end feels a bit unsatisfying. The proverb "The journey is the reward" pretty much sums it all up. Also for a game that starts strong in meaningful choices and their consequences it als degrades in that regard. There is no evil playthrough possibility and if you try to side with Mathias he will blow you up with a nuke. (I refer to FallOut here where the Master was more than happy to add you to his army) So you are pretty much forced into a Good-Guy-Role.
It was not a bad plot
date: but it started way stronger than it finished\n\nGrafics
recommended: Sound& Music\nThe game was made in the Unity-Engine and is certainly not the prettiest one
hoursPlayed: but it does the job and all locations are unique and memorable. The sounddesign is well done and paired with the games music it can feel downright creepy at times
voteText: the perfect feeling for a post-apocalyptic game.\n\nAll in All if you liked the old Fallout-titles or you are intrested in CRPGs Wasteland 2 is definatly worth a look
helpfulPercent: even if it can feel downright clunky sometimes yet it was modernized in the right way and I will definatly see forward to a 3rd installment"

reviewText:
I would recommend playing fallout 1 or 2 instead of this game, it starts with your character talking to a ranger, no explanation about who you are or why you're here, he just tells you about the death of another ranger and assumes you're in on the loop, you're dropped straight into the story with no idea who your character is or how they got there.

So you and your team of 3 (which you just met without introduction) leave the ranger camp to investigate a ranger's death for you're boss you just met, and for a moment I expected to embark on a grand adventure but dissapointingly the ranger died just a short walk away (along the way you'll have to fight the same 3 or 4 raiders over and over again) The team you lead doesn't say anything to eachother, apparently no one cares who they are or why they're here they never react verbally or non verbally to anything they're seeing or doing.

In fact every NPC feels as lifeless as their voice acting, which frankly is dull and boring, understandable had they been reading perhaps the 400th line of dialog at 5pm on a Friday, but it seems they carry the same enthusiasm or lack there of throughout the entire game or at least the first few hours that I've played.

After a few hours I began to grow impatient and decided I was going to do my own thing because I honestly don't care about the rangers, or their quests. I thought maybe I can start a fresh in another part of the wasteland, but you can't go walking too far into the desert, oh no, don't go exploring and trying to have fun because then you'll die of dehydration, you need to stay around the oasis' which are conveniently located along the routes to places you need to go, mother nature you sly dog.

It's disapointing that there's nothing to do around these oasis' except fight the same raiders over and over which for some may be fun for a minute or two, but you'll soon run out of ammunition and you're party is very fragile often bleeding from a single gunshot until death. Not a problem if you have plently of supplies dropped by the raiders you've killed for no reason, but wait a minute, I can't use it because I didn't go through med school, I needed to spec my character in a particular way otherwise I'm not able to heal.

That's alright I'll just go back to the ranger base and get them to heal me up, seeing as I am helping them out by investigating the death of their friend. Nope, they'll let me buy more of the supplies I've already got with the very little money I already have. But it seems they aren't prepared to give me treatment or anything else accept for the odd 'hurry up and do your job' radio message, If only I could somehow communicate to him that our group is very close to dead and would likely not survive another raider ambush.

It's puzzling how these characters survived for the 20 odd years prior to the beginning of this game without any decent weapons or currency? Don't think about that you gotta keep focused on the story, about a ranger that was killed by a giant frog when he went for a walk? The only appeal a game like this has for me personally is story and I am trying really hard to find some story here, it's just not happening.

reviewText: Definitely worth it.  It's definitely a spiritual successor of Fallout 1 and 2 in many ways (kind of funny, seeing as how Fallout was a successor of Wasteland) - even the art style reminded me of the pre-rendered cutscenes in F1, 2, and Tactics.  The gameplay can get a bit frustrating with the absurd number of jams and critical failures that seem to occur, but once you get into it, it's really fun, especially since it forces you to rely on a balanced squad rather than maxing out every useful skill for one guy.  There's enough choices for three or four thorough playthroughs, too.\n\nDefinitely recommended.  I do'nt think I've managed to sink this much time into a non-open world RPG for a LONG time.

reviewText:
Ignore the people who are angry that inXile defended their trademark. They don't understand how the trademark system works. inXile could potentially lose their trademark if they don't defend it.

The game is definitely enjoyable and provides a challenge even on the lowest difficulty. It's quite refreshing to find a game that doesn't hold your hand as though it's life depends on it. Even moreso with a game that actively rewards interacting with characters and exploring like Wasteland 2 does. The amount of lore behind every setting and character is fleshed out and gives a lore-nerd like me something to read, inbetween blowing people's brain's out.
A love-it or hate-it thing about the game is that it doesn't do much in the way of quest markers. Typically the quest log will tell you where you should start looking and nothing more. While this does result in much more organic gameplay and storytelling, it can be frustrating when you've been searching for that one guy that you need to talk to for the past fifteen minutes.

The game's addition of it's humor in it's post-apocalypic setting is implemented very well. The humor is enough of a sideshow to be entertaining, without ruining the theming of the game - it reminds me of Fallout 3 with the 'Wild Wasteland' perk in some ways, just the little things. Seriously, Toaster Repair is a surprisingly valuable skill in a world without toast.

reviewText:
I have mixed feelings on this game:

First, I really wanted to like it. A lot. I loved the original, warts and all, and given that this was an indy effort, I was willing to put up with some rough edges. Because unlike a lot of games today, this one is a challenge! Ammo is scarce, combat is hard, decisions haunt you. I liked that part. I loved that part.

BUT THE GAME F***ING CRASHES SO OFTEN.

I literally cannot get through 30-60 minutes, sometimes even more like 10-15, before the game crashes out. It's not like this is a new product, it's been out for a while, and this is really kinda unacceptable. After 12 hours, and 15 crashes, I just cant deal with it anymore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok so I really want this to be a winner in the long run. It is so damn buggy it's stopped me playing. I only hope my $60 will go towards cleaning up the end product and make it all worth while. I mean the story is great as I'd expect. The concept solid as ♥♥♥♥ but the combat is just ok. Skills are questionable. This is after just a few hours playing the game. I think the first 1 or 2 were spent wandering aimlessly in the waste as I had no concept of how to change camera angle let alone WTF the water gague was and how to refill it.

So I finally find an oasis... I AM, FROM 1988, A FAN OF WASTELAND! ON THE APPLE II NO LESS AND I AM NOT HAPPY. Get it together guys, I know it's beta but $60? I can't even get it to full screen on windows 7. I love the story, the puzzels are great, the combat is ok but the skills and stats etc?? Did the first 3 missions which were kind of fun. The patchy loading is really annoying as is the lack of a full screen view. By highpool mission I'm a more than annoyed. I really hope the completed game is less patchy, has better graphics, more dynamic feeling turn based combat and is more imersive then just getting a portrate box with text and voice over. Maybe just some facial movement ie their lips move when they speak, expressions??

So yes I do recommend this game, if anything to give the developers more cash to polish the end product. If this is pretty close to the finished article there are going to be many dissapointed fans of the original. At least I can play the original if I have the time to indulge in nostaligia... for the price not really worth it. In the long haul if the game get's a serious overhaul and some much needed improvements then I will be a happy camper. If not, well that is $60 I wasted. If your a fan of the original, can overcome some serious glitches and bugs and annoying status effects that appear to have no cure (the plant infection WTF, even if it only last until the relevant section of the game is completed I think) confusion (expected from any beta) and a hefty price tag well this is for you. I look at it as a donation towards a fantastic end product. DO NOT DISAPPOINT ME PLEASE!!!

reviewText:
This game is not good. It's one of the worst modern RPGs I've played.  The graphics are bad and the art design is uninspired. Many of the environments are hideously repititious. The camera controls poorly. The RPG aspects consist of ensuring skill points are dumped into a couple of specialties in order to pass checks in conversation dialogue and opening locked boxes.

In combat your options range from: Shooting, Crouching to Shoot, and Reloading. You can also hide behind arbitarily designated cover positions. If you've played XCom or Divinity: Original Sin you know this style of Turn-Based combat, and what you'll find here pales in comparison.

The AI of the enemies is basically nonexistent. They will run at you and shoot you or they will run at you and stab/bludgeon you. Upping the difficulty seems to only increase the Bullet Sponginess of your foes.  Since you have extremely limited tactical options there's basically no point in playing on anything beyond normal unless you enjoy reloading quicksaves.

Combat initiation is wonky. You can attempt to arrange your characters behind cover beforehand, but this process is extremely janky and you'll probably inadvertently trigger combat before you intended to.

There are no real characters. There's a Native American companion who has a bow and is really good at sharpshooting. She talks a lot in ham-fisted stereotypical fashion. Oh and she also has a skill that allows her to Tame Wild Animals.  There's a gruff commander. He is gruff and old. There is a ranger who is sad that another ranger died.

The entire thing feels completely perfunctory.  I got about four hours into the game and had yet to decipher what the game was supposed to be about beyond meandering from fetch quest to fetch quest.

One storyline involves doing a bunch of quests for some townsfolk. One guy's house is on fire. One guy's dog is missing. The waterpumps aren't working.  If you help the people in these quests, the townsfolk will elect a good mayor. You know she's good because she's nice to you. If you don't do the quests the townsfolk elect a bad mayor. You know he's bad because he's mean to you. There are virtually no consequences in either result. If you enjoy this kind of compelling, interactive storytelling this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(English / Japanese review, 日本語レビューは下のほう)

Brian Fargo did it. I'm happy that I paid $115 on it(for physical CE).

Team based RPG with up to 4 rangers in the team(don't know if you can separate the team that you could in WL1).
Combat is AP based, but Initiative decides the action order(not Player team > Enemy team system like FO:T or Jagged Alliance).

Graphic is rough(Especially character models) but I believe that's what Unity isn't really good at, and it's not very important thing for *DEEP* RPG like WL2.
Bugs? Small UI? Imbalance? It's still beta, get on with them and you can help it making better!

Forget Fallout 4 and get it, NOW.

あのRPG界の巨匠Brian Fargoの新作。Kickstarterで$115(パッケージ限定版+送料)払った甲斐があった。

4人パーティを構成してプレイするRPGだけど、前作みたいに別行動させられるかは不明。
戦闘はAP(アクションポイント)制ではあるがFallout TacticsやJagged Allianceとは違い、行動順はイニシアチブで決めれる形で敵味方が入り乱れて動く。

今の問題といえばグラフィック(特にキャラモデル)の出来はそこまでよくないが、Unityを使っていること(超グラフィックよりマルチプラットフォーム化と動作速度を優先してるのだろう)や、超ディープなRPGにグラフィックは重要ではないのであまり気にならないか。
バグ、小さすぎるUI、ゲームバランスの問題は、まだβだから仕方ない。というか今すぐ遊んでその辺が改善されるよう手助けしよう。

RPGゲーマーを自負するならFallout 4なんて忘れて、今すぐこっちを遊ぶべき。

reviewText:
Damn it.

This is such a strange game for me because I want to love it....but...  it just feels ...old and dated...but intentionally.

Instead of making a modern game that followed the core design principles of the of late 90s RPGs... they made a game that looks and feels 15 years old....with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ interface and terrible graphics. With that said it's not a bad game, there is a lot here to like, especially if you long for more complex mechanics.... But it does feel like a real missed opportunity.

I'm glad Wasteland 2 exists, but go play Divinity if you can only pick one. :(

reviewText:
This was the year of the RPG and this was one I was really looking forward to. A strong pitch which felt like it laid out realistic goals, along with a spokesman who was hitting all the right notes. Yet what they delivered was so very bland. A combat heavy game with an incredibly shallow TBS component, one where it felt you did little more than maximise your damage each turn and terrain had little to no impact. Compared to Shadowrun Returns/Dragonfall, which had built their entire editor around creating good combat layouts, this was weaksauce.

More than that though, the characters and story were dull. You have a team of nobodies, which would be fine if you had a strong combat system to back it up. The personalities you do collect are at a Baldur's Gate 1 level, and less memorable than those. Not one of the NPCs, party or otherwise, stands out.

It just all came together to form a rather dull experience, and after a while I found I just sort of stopped playing. I couldn't find anything to motivate me to push on. That the primary mystery is spoiled during a joke death scene was just the icing on the cake.

It leaves me worried for Torment.

reviewText:
“Bottle caps?! We only accept scrap.”

Greetings to you, traveller! We welcome you into our wasteland with water in our cans and radiation in our lungs!

You may not understand our wasteland, you may even fear it. Do not worry, we have all struggled in such ignorance or died of thirst in the desert. To understand what the wasteland is, is to understand the Great Glow. Everything is part of it, but it is the mushroom cloud that expresses it most directly.

But, do you not need to seek the next mushroom cloud to find the Great Glow? The answer is no! Look into the eyes of a mutated animal that is about to attack you. See that energy, that life there? That is the Great Glow.

Of course the blessing of the Great Glow is not for free, for nothing in life is free. Study the various wasteland guides to truly understand the Great Glow, the nature of the mushroom cloud, and understand why salvation lies only through their wisdom.

And always keep these rules in mind:

1. Tread lightly and carry a big gun and/or stick.
2. Every animal with the prefix ‘mutated’ considers you to be its lunch.
3. If your Geiger counter starts going off the scale, you should turn around.
4. The only thing worse than a robot the size of a truck with a circular saw and a laser beam, is a robot the size of a house with a minigun, a flamethrower and half a dozen minions that are coming right for you.
5. Toaster repair is essential for a good breakfast.

Fun fact: The credit song “Cries of a Dead World” by Miracle of Sound perfectly captures the atmosphere of Wasteland 2.
--

My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:

-	Atmosphere
-	Combat & Controls
-	Details
-	Tactical gameplay
-	Characters
-	Story

Based on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading:

-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

If the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).
--

Atmosphere: S-Rank

(This oddly dressed merchant sports a slight tan, huge arms and legs, a bear belly, and big beard with two white stripes in it. Under normal circumstances the pink tutu around his belly would look odd, but somehow Ratboy makes it work.)

Combat & Controls: S-Rank

(If yer sober, that’s the best yer gonna feel all day.)

Details: S-Rank

(Shoving your hand into a roiling vat of glowing radioactive gloop is probably one of the worst ideas you’ve ever had.)

Tactical gameplay: S-Rank

(A little more persistence, a little more effort, and what seemed hopeless failure may turn out to glorious success.)

Characters: A-Rank

Story: A-Rank
--

There are no multiplayer achievements.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like tactical games, post-apocalyptic worlds, guns, critical thinking, even if you enjoy dungeons and dragons; then I suggest you try Wasteland 2.

If you like the world of Fallout, you'll love the world of Wasteland. Not to go into too much, but its from the same developers of the original Fallout games, joined by some of the creators of the newer versions of Fallout.

As of now, the game is still in beta but is scheduled for release soon, and yes, I'll admit, the price is a bit steep for now, but I'd suggest it once it releases, and the price drops. You get a few added things if you buy the DDE, but that's for you to decide if its worth it.

The game itself is interesting. There's a lot of reading, remembering key words, critical thinking (should I send my team in fighting? Or should I try a more diplomatic approach?) and storytelling. Quests and advancement is a little lackluster, but not bad, and every choice has a consequence. Graphics are decent, sound and music are stellar, and some of the game (easter eggs, dialogue, and random loot) are a little corny, but not bad.

I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys any kind of Role-Playing game.

reviewText:
A very compelling, classic, post-nuclear RPG with highly satisfying turn based combat in between. Wasteland 2 got a pretty cool flair to it, rough and sometimes weird characters. Lots of text, which you actually have to pay attention to - really nice to have something like that amidst the dozens of games requiring nothing of you but to look at the minimap and the HUD telling you to what to kill and how many of them.

Pretty good integrated tutorial function, which holds your hand if you want to but you can also just go ahead and figure out most of the mechanics by yourself. Either way works. Skill system is deep enough but not overly complex and the story kept me hooked most of the time.

The only thing that is not quite favorable are the graphics - and that is coming from someone who usually doesn't give a rat's ♥♥♥ about the looks of a game. And I'm not talking about polygons or explosion effects. It just seems a little bit too blurry in some scenes, the colouring is very desaturated and without a lot of contrast, sometimes making it hard to spot certain things like crates or objects related to quests.

Other than that, if you like the style of games like XCOM, the Fallout series, maybe even S.T.A.L.K.E.R. (even though that's an FPS) you might just dig Wasteland 2.

reviewText: Freaking RIDICULOUSLY good...so far.  My biggest gauge of a game is how obvious it is that the devs gave it the love it needed.  W2 got enough love.  It's immersive, comprehensive, engaging, its world is deeply responsive, and it's as funny and cheezy as needed.  The expected micromanagement side of things took some getting used to, but it's not too much and it's solidly designed so you can get some good speed going with the interface once you get used to it.\n\nAs far as criticism, the only things I've noticed so far after 100 hrs are minor.  For ex. when your level for a skill is below the minimum for a task, it'd be nice if it told you how many points you're under the minimum instead of just this is impossible" (which makes me think it's actually impossible regardless of level).  I've only got a handful of other minor beefs (like dialog sometimes being stale vs a situation).  The biggest beef I've seen so far is that in some situations it's not obvious from what you're given what to do next.  In every case of that
date: peeking at hints online make me go "ohhh you dumbass".  It's still minor.  For a game this mechanically complex
recommended: that's a freaking huge success.\n\nGreat work inXile
hoursPlayed: keep em' comin'."

reviewText:
Isometric RPG's are back and as good as ever! If you ever played and enjoyed the original Fallout games, or even the Baldurs Gate series, you absolutely owe it to yourself to try Wasteland 2. Successor to the original Wasteland, and spiritual Successor to Fallout 1&2, Wasteland 2 delivers a fantastic story, great voice acting, a compelling setting and the brilliant isometric RPG gameplay you'd expect from the old classics.

My only real criticism is the poor graphics. They're not terrible, and I can understand that they didn't exactly have the AAA title budget, but they're just not up to the stellar standards set by the rest of the game.

Overall I would highly recommend this game to any fan of the old school RPGs, as well as gamers looking to find out what all the fuss was about. Welcome back, Brian Fargo, Chris Avellone and everyone else involved in making this amazing game. You've been misssed!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe fact that this game was made at all fills a corner of my heart with great joy -- Games like these (turn based rpgs) of good quality are often far-between, and I have no regrets playing this one. Very true to the wasteland of old, part of what I love is how you don't need to have played the ancient classic, but if you have it breathes life into many facets of the story. the gritty feel is spot on, and the skill system and character building is intriguing -- though perhaps not as fun as fallout series. It is interesting to note that Wasteland is THE game that inspired so much that came after it in the post-apoc rpg genre... so it is interesting that when it's sequel finally arrives, some of it's successors have already pushed the horizon beyond what it appears (thus far -- haven't finished yet) wasteland 2 will be able to take us. The robots rising from the ashes of the past to take back the earth" premise has been done so many times since wasteland 1 -- at least twice in the fallout series alone
date: I'm kind of sad that wasteland 2's synthetics seem to be shaping up to be more of the usual as well... still
recommended: I can't write out the idea that this is a red herring as of the time of this review
hoursPlayed: but lets just say I'd be slightly sad if it's not. Wasteland 1 was revolutionary in almost every respect -- for Wasteland 2 to rise from the ashes

reviewText:
Not a Fallout. Not even really an rpg unless you consider a billion of supersimple fetch quests to be hardcore roleplaying. (you can complete most of them without actually going and actively fetching ♥♥♥♥)
This doesn't stop game from having stellar wirting and great atmosphere though, they really put a lot of work into descriptions, world building and dialogs (as simple as they mechanically are). This is probably the most text heavy game I played in a while.
Gameplaywise this game is more in tune with Xcom:Eu (combat system is nearly completely lifted from there) or Silent Storm Sentinels or hell, even Jaggged alliance 2 - combat and squad based tactics are the real meat of the game It's definitely not the deepest game in the genre, but it manages to be entertaining for the most part of it. (I do wish weapon balance and variation were much better though)
Overall I'd say the game is a really rough gem with a lot of flaws but it had just enough redeeming features to keep me interested.

P.S. Don't invest in charisma or luck. They do nothing.

reviewText:
I highly recommended this game to those that love tactical turn based RPGs in the same vein as the first two Fallout games (considering that those games are based on Wasteland 1). Wasteland 2 is a more contemporary universe, a less foreign world ravaged by nuclear war rather than the more comedic, 50's stylized alternate reality of Fallout. In my opinion it is also far more serious in its tone by forcing hard choices and painting a sad state of affairs for humanity. The humor present is often dark and subtle.

This game easily beats out any triple A RPG title I've played in the past decade.

reviewText:
Took 90 hours to beat but this is a case for an RPG to have been better off having less content than offered. Besides that this is a great return to old-school fallout 1/2 type games with great writing in some parts and memorable characters. Combat is meh but it can be imporved upon as well as character customization. The ending kinda just happens even when you clearly see the end in sight because the last few hours is a linear gauntlet so hard to the point where I had to finish the final battle on rookie difficulty. Overall Wasteland 2 is by far an enjoyable experience with dozens of stories to tell each time you replay the game and I gladly await the game of the year edition update and wasteland 3 (although Fallout 4 hype is still ♥♥♥♥ing strong here).

reviewText: Welcome to the glorious wastes of Arizona with nothing but old school RPG turn based combat and a plethora of cross roads to travel. This was a game I had been watching from the early beta days but decided against diving straight in and waiting for the final" version of the game to come out. On that note before continuing
date: I use the term "final" very loosely.\n\nThe first half of the game is fantastic. Hands down one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a while. Refreshing real choices with actual consequences. Multiple choices and decisions to be made at every corner ranging from simple attire
recommended: to devastating lesser of two evil choices that affect the rest of the game and years to come following. Great character creation allowing role-players to enjoy a world the can fully immerse themselves in. This and so much more awaits you.\n\nOn the opposite side of the review this game is not without short comings and issues. The second half of the game is anything but complete. More than ever this is a game that you save often for and making 100+ individual save files. Major quest lines are riddled with bugs and plot holes the size of the grand canyon can be found more frequently than not. While I still enjoyed the vague idea of the second half of the game
hoursPlayed: it was a disappointment after how amazing the first half was. Another big issue was balancing. Take this bit of advice. Sniper rifles/ assault rifles/ shotguns and energy weapons are the only good guns in the game. The rest are terrible.\n\nIf you enjoy turn based RPGs and an apocalyptic theme this game is for you
voteText: while I may have listed some off putting downsides especially for the second half it is still worth playing. The first half of the game does such a great job and the curiosity you will have to see how things turn out will help you through the issues of the second half. I finished this game 100% including a run on the higher difficulty in 158 hours. Well worth the money. 8.5/10\n"

reviewText:
Pros -

It's a game straight out of a better timeline where games such as Fallout, X-COM, JA2 etc's publishers held onto the rights and kept making them in the same style into the mid 2000s.  I mean, at this point if you're the type of person who likes this sort of thing, anything further is totally redundant, just go and buy it now.

Cons -

Pretty much exactly the above!  Some of this is down to it being deliberately guided into a retro style of game through the beta, some of which is down to not having an immense production budget.  It's more like someone found a portal to a better universe's ~2007 and brought this game to ours through it, rather than a 2014 remake.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Best of the turn-based RPGs I've played this year.

This tickled my turn-tactical bone in the same way X-Com Enemy Unknown did. Now that I've played it through I enjoyed the general story arc, it felt like you were bringing law and order to a land full of people clammoring for it. Gotta love the Star Trek-esque takes on alternative societies as humanity claws its way back from the grave.

It isn't perfectly open ended, but you have a lot of freedom to accomplish goals. I ended up doing a lot of quest lines backwards by outright murdering individuals .. which inadvertently solved quests later. A lot of times you're forced to take 'sides' in conflicts between factions, but you can just obliterate both of them if you so choose. In certain cases that may even be desirable, we're talking about some odious people here.

The gameplay is pretty solid. Investing in social skills heavily can pay off in several questlines later. There's plenty of skill objectives in every map, making it feel rewarding if you invested in something as seemingly irrelevant as Toaster repair. The various weapon types all feel useful in different ways, forcing you to seriously consider if items are up upgrades to your playstyle or not.

Terrific RPG.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWasteland 2 is to Wasteland what X-Com: Enemy Unknown is to X-Com: UFO Defense, and so much more. It is more than just a refurbished classic with updated graphics and interface; it truly is what happens next. I recognize people and places I knew when I first explored the Wasteland; old teammates are now grizzled veterans in positions of authority, landmarks are still there, just as I pictured them… and sometimes even better. I can see where my trials and tribulations helped the people of the Wasteland… and where my hard fought battles did not matter after all. It's nostalgic, new and exciting all at the same time. I highly recommend purchasing this game and enveloping yourself in post-apocalyptic Arizona again, or first time. You won't regret it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well as a fan of RPGs i couldn't walk away from this one. I mean this is a real hardcore, oldschool RPG at it's best! Early access brought on us many bugs, glitches and many times after another patch game would not run... but, now it's made a whole, there are some minor fixes left so what will Wasteland 2 can give you?

Graphics: Decent. It's not masterpiece in graphical state, but it's not the polygons that make game looks, it's artstyle. And it's there! You think Wasteland 's a big sandbox? With some rubble piles here and there? Destroyed houses and cities? yes all that, but also plenty more! Gen labs, terrariums, farms, villages; there are enough places and variety to feel like home (if you're a fan of postapocalyptic).

Gameplay: True oldschool. Do not touch this game if you're JRPG\console raised or school lad\lass. You probably feel lost, because game require brains to play. From Charecter creation to Wasteland jorney. You allowed to create up to 4 charecters, and will meet some more on ye joprneys, team can be 7 people max. And it is important what stats and skills charecter posses. Many times to find alternate root or to unlock secret, or simply to snoop around you will need some particular skill; One charecter will not be able to be master of everything, so think, do math... still you will probably will have to start game all over after first 3 hours. Stats btw are connected, so if you want fast or strong charcter you will have to sacrifice something in order to build that charecter. So it's important to understand what do you want, not blindly jumping into a game (stats btw can not be increased with level up, only skills can. Though you will find little trinkets here and there that will amplify particular stat). And the most awesome of all -- you can write your own biography for charecter! And use random avatars! As the game starts, well it's you standart RPG; World map, quests, exploration, fights... but with a certan twists here and there. For example, while wondering through the desert your charecters will need water and rad protection (or they will die) water can be refiled in Oasis or on base still you need to plan ahead. Combat can be very hard, or simple (depends on your charecter combatant skills and difficulty level), there are a variety of enemies and some of them can be really chalenging, or will require a certan tactic to defeat. Finaly a lot of secrets, alternate roots, quests that go against each other: Right from the begining you will have a choise to save X or Y and this WILL, I repeat WILL affect game, not like in JRPG or modern adventures. No, you WILL suffer the consiquences of ye choise... High replayability value.

Music and Sound: Musik is... well it support atmosphere still you will probably won't even notice that it exist. Sound on the other hand is great.

Final verdict? If you love Fallout 1 and 2, if you love oldschool RPG that require brain for play, if you hungry for challenge and want game that will give you freedom while restricting you gently. This is Wasteland 2 lady and gentleman: a game that every hardcore player and every oldschool gamer must own.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText: In short, this game is excellent. However this is coming from a gamer who still replays Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of steel and owns both Xcom: Enemy Unknown and its expansion. I love my squad based RPGs, turns or no. And I love the post-apocalyptic setting even more, it has always been one of my favourite areas to tread, and with Wasteland 2 I have tread far and wide, nearing the end of this game I am already looking forwards to re-rolling on Ranger difficulty for many more hours of frustratingly amazing gameplay.\n\nMany people complain that this game is too hard, and that they have to restart multiple times, but I have not restarted a single time, nor have I encountered many bugs aside from the occassional camera glitch (Exactly 3 times in 50 hours of game play). I am still playing through on my first squad roll and loving every bit of it! The love you put into your squad before you start playing is the basis for everything that comes after - Remember that.

reviewText:
Let me begin by saying that Wasteland 2 is not like Fallout outside of the post-apocalyptic theme, and a few design choices. Wasteland 2 is a great game, but it is not as good as Fallout 2.

The game is a good squad-based RPG that reminds me heavily of those old Fallout games, though. And indeed, I love this game much the same. There is a variety of ways you can solve most of your problems, and because of that, this game has consumed what has to have been over 10 hours of my life already.

There are some problems I have with the game. And if this game were made by any other unknown indie developer, I would have rolled my eyes and moved on. But this game was made by Brian Fargo, with help from several other veterans of good old RPGs that we knew and love, so this makes me disappointed at a few design choices.

1. A few skills are a bit too divided. Unnecessarily so. Why is Safecracking and Lockpicking two different skills? Why not just make Safes harder to lockpick? Why are Blunt Weapons and Bladed weapons separate? What was so wrong with a general melee" skill? Why is there a skill just for modding weapons? Who in their right mind would put skill points into Toaster Repair? While some skill divisions made logical sense -- obviously
recommended: a generic "guns" skill would be broken

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I played the beta of this game in 2013, I was not impressed. I was frustrated with the UI, the art direction, the scripting, and the way combat was weighed. I played the original in the late 1980s, and loved the surreal and unforgiving world it created.

I came back, this month, hoping that the issues I'd complained about had been fixed. I genuinely love this series and was pessimistic about its survival. I owe the devs an apology--the beta I've played this month has been everything I could have wanted (though I could always use more toasters and mutants, if anyone is listening).

I can recommend this game to fans of the first game, as well as fans of dystopian and apocalyptic games. However, it is distinct from other entries in this genre, including the often-cited Fallout series.

Closer to the roots of such games than the more recent entries in the apolcalyptic genre, Wasteland 2 is tactical and played from above your party's head. You can pause between turns, and sometimes you'd better think about it first.

It also has the charm of being more appropriately unforgiving--it's the !@#(*% apocalypse, the stakes are high, and I APPROVE of punishing button mashing and careless playing.

Know your save file, love your save file. The game saves less often than you might want it to, so you'll want to stay on that yourself.

Your characters will have to specialize, and no single character will be able to be everything. You will want to think hard about how you want to allocate specialties.

It is very possible to make in-game mistakes that kill you and your party instantly, though you'd have to be pretty oblivious to make them. If the button says do not push me
date:
do no--actually, if you push it, you deserve what you get.

The wrong comment to the wrong person can touch off wars between groups, closing whole story sections to you. The appropriate choice in dialog is not always obvious, and the best choice is not always available to you, without specializing.

Depending on your level of difficulty, making use of the ability to create ambushes and lead people into them will become very useful, as is developing a character able to scout ahead.

The game is still being developed, and has some on-going and minor technical issues, including an optimization problem I ran into on my rig that required me to turn down the refresh rate and render quality considerably. From reading the forums, this problem is not exactly common, but happens often enough to merit mention.

The half of the game available for play right now also seems a bit short--I'm hoping that the final product will be much longer (gimmie!)

It's hard to evaluate a story when you're missing the denouemont, but to this point, it has a familiar and interesting arc. Given the development, I'm fairly confident the finished product, based on the skill I've seen, will have been worth backing the project.

A word of advice: do not buy this game expecting Fallout: New Vegas, or expecting a completely open, huge world filled with 1950s kitsch, naivete, and classic sci-fi allusions.

Expect, instead, a world hemmed in on all sides by radiation and death, with the disaffection, paramiliatry themes, and violence of the 1980s. The devs have done a particularly good job of recalling the first game without simply recreating it.

And devs, at the risk of spoiling something, the Brothers patrolling the mountain pass are just about perfect. If there's any fear close to our current, collective hearts, it's contamination.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The fundemental flaw in the YES OR NO recomendations in steam reviewing platform really starts to ♥♥♥♥ me off when you review Early Access or alpha build games.  The problem is like many alpha and early games the changes that can and will come can drastically alter your entire experience.  In some cases an entirely new build may completely destroy what you got use to over the last 5-6 months of playing.

Wasteland 2 I waited until it was on sale for, 60$ price tag was justified by not spitting in the faces of their kick starter backers, and I do respect that.  Was the $40 (on sale) I paid to play this game a few months before release worth it?  I would say yes.  While not an MMO and i won't get points for getting to x, y, z before anyone else, it still is a really solid return to classics.

It shows that classic systems implemented correctly into newer engines can play really nice together.  Now I must admit i don't remember much if ANYTHING from the original wasteland, but I do remember Fallout and playing that.  This game feels more at home with an isometric Fallout (to me at least).  It plays really well, but for some it can be described as too slow".

Wasteland 2 doesn't hold back on a classic experience by giving you a bunch of tools at your disposal
date: and giving you the freedom to resolve conflicts your way.  Save a few game breaking bugs (again early build beta)

Now while playing I felt like I have in most RPGs eventually your character becomes a hoarder and you are able to basically buy anything without it having it hinder you in any real significant way.\n\nFor being survivors of a wasteland these guys sure as ♥♥♥♥ stockpiled the ammunition up.  It became overly easy to have an abundance of ammunition

reviewText: I have no experience with the classics of the cRPG genre, as I am a bit too young to have been good enough at video games to enjoy them during the glory days (25 now), but let me tell you something: This is the best genre of video games ever. No questions asked. I don't care if you have never played this style before, please pick up this game along with Pillars of Eternity. Honestly, these two games, which apparently aren't even as good as the true classics, destroy every modern game when it comes to storytelling, character development and lore. You really feel like you are a part of the world and that your actions are changing things. If you don't like to read, well ah, I guess Call of Duty is on here somewhere, but if you're even moderately intelligent, enjoy great storytelling and atmosphere, this game is for you. Don't be intimidated if you haven't played the classics. This is a fantastic game for rookies or vets.

reviewText:
I looked forward to this game for a long time, and will admit that once I got it did not fall in love with it and so have put very limited time into it, so take my game experience with that grain of salt.  Many people have clearly loved it, and so maybe you will too, but I feel let down and consider this a title that for me has lived up neither to its hype or even to its promises.

Clearly a lot of care and attention to detail went into crafting this game, as well as a long process of interacting with the community during development, and I am impressed with the features.  That they did not add up to a fun and immersive experience for me may have been primarily due to a dislike for the camera handling.  I found early on that I preferred a wide view most of the time, but the camera handles poorly for that.

I also believe that the bar was set reasonably high for visual quality, but again I feel like the look achieved was not equal to the sum of the components, and possibly that has to do with the Unity engine.

I have generally good feelings that Fargo's team was revived by this project and has leveraged the enthusiasm for this revival to  continue on with new projects as well as encouraging other developers doing interesting projects, but otherwise am not too excited to have been a day 1 kickstart supporter.

Some 32 months after the project was officially funded we have not seen the mod tools kit that was promised.  I realize that Fargo was honest in projecting that mod tools would require further time and it will probably come someday, but at this stage of the game's shelf life I'm about ready to declare that a broken promise.  This may seem like a moot point since I haven't cared much for the game, but it is disappointing nonetheless.

reviewText:
Welcome to the Wasteland

PROS+ NO BUGS/CRASHES almost after 5 patches changing the game itself for the better...
+ VARIETY on quests (could be more but don't forget it was a kickstarter game not big a company)...
+ REPLAYBLE starting over and over with different team and diferent choices which for me is the essence on this kind of game...
+ DESTRUCTIVE enviroment & TACTICAL thinking on before positioning squad members, otherwise u are dead

CONS- somewhat clunky UI but not that big deal
- weak storyline and some bad writing on some quests
- lacking in music & sound cover

8.0/10
Let me start by saying this game through the visuals & vivid setting reminds Mad Max universe,
post apocalyptic, desert (for the most part), raiders etc etc my kind of favourite

After 100+ hours i concluded that you die a lot in the wasteland, which that can happen by a number of reasons poor character creations, bad judgement on the skill sets, choices that didn't come out and so on, thus making starting over trying to find the best squad to survive.
This by all accounts is an excellent game...

in overall i would strongly recommend it especially if you are a sucker of those old classic RPGs and with winter sales coming and going you can easily enjoy it more by getting it on discount.

*MICHAEL BAY directed the last part of the game

reviewText:
This game hates you.

Loot aquisition is just horrible.  Make the best damn thief around, max out your skills and you'll still fail opening locks, safes, etc.  If you're so inclined you can save before and reload if you fail and try try and try a-frickin-gain.  I don't feel like cheating so I don't.

At one point you get ambushed by a cyborg death squad that shoots you with energy weapons. It's crazy difficult.  The recommendations from the message boards: Before going into this situation strip off your armor.  Well grand.

The game should have stopped in Arizona.  California is alright, storywise, but the game mechanics shatter.  Maybe it's a balance issue, who knows.  It feels like they wiped out your skills and reset them to zero due to the difficulty being so over the top. EVERYTHING in California is a Herculean skill difficulty.

A lot of games really build up and reward you for the time spent, but no, not this game. THIS GAME HATES YOU.

reviewText: I know this game is in no way linked to the fallout series, but obviously there are direct comparisons to the first two fallout games, and possibly tactics as well.  A lot of players have commented that it brings back the feeling of the old fallout games, but I can't agree with them.  The greeat thing about fallout 1 and 2 were the intellegence and humour of the games, and also the sense of progression.  The quests and puzzles were tricky, but not so much that you got fed up and gave up on them.\nWasteland 2 seems to have taken all of the bad bits of the fallout series and left out the good bits.  There's lots of trudging around the wasteland with not much to do.  You encounter vastly overpowered enemies early on, you have to cycle through reams of pointless speach, progression through ranks is slow and painful with little reward at the end, the missions are nonsensical and give you little clue about what you are doing.  The last point is the worst part about the game.  I've trudged about for hours trying to fathom out what the hell I'm supposed to do to complete the first missions.  I ended up being attacked by most of the main characters and having to kill them!  I'm so gutted that I paid top whack for this game, as I really wanted to, and really tried to enjoy it.

reviewText:
I found the game to have serious game design flaws that make me regret the purchase.  May this be a warning to others.

First there is way to much useless clicking involved. Seemingly every action requires another useless click. For example: characters don't just level up, one needs to call in to HQ then pretend to read the useless exchange with the caption then click through a series of boring dialog options only then can one go to assking skill points. Seriously I was annoyed by this even the first time around. You have to do this each time a character levels up ...

Here is another: assigning an item to a hotkey is not just dragging the item into the hotkey slot, you have to right click the item (even though the help says right-click to use, you have to disregard that) then click the assign hot key then click the hotkey. The interfaces are a little sluggish so you won't be clicking all that fast either.

Maps: The maps are tiny, cramped and sluggish. One seemingly needs to always rotate the map back and forth not to miss a detail. There is always another zone to load there is no sense of exploration or adventure.  All the background are prerendered and non mostly non destructible. It is very difficult to figure out quest objectives - some objects are indestructible" until some quest objective is finished but still show up as targetable - so you end up wasting ammo on them.

Combat: The game interface is unforgiving in combat - it is hard to tell which character is in LOS of another thus in danger to get into a friendly fire incident. Combat alway seems to play out the same way
date: the enemy bum rushes you - and because the AI is dumb it has beefed up stats to make up for that. See that big rabbit that you shot four times already - it still has an insane range and attack power and still has the ability to quickly take down a trained well armed ranger. It is just bad game desing.\n\nTravel: The map travel is boring and uninspired
recommended: who wants to watch an icon moving on a map - there is this seeminly pointless difficulty setting of having toxic fumes appear out of nowhere thus killing your entire party. WTF game design is that?\n\nI really tried to like this game but unfortunately it lacks the simplicity and fun factor of old school tactical games such as XCOM or Jagged Alliance."

reviewText:
Great game full of  bugs
Overall a great game. You can spend hours just building your squad, making sure that they have the right mix of skills, knowledge and weapons to survive and conquer. Which really leads you to invest in the team member you build and train. I restarted the game so many times to make sure that I was covering all bases and leaving the right gaps for recruitable NPC's to fill. This has kept me in the first part of the game for a while now. However, having an exciting and deep background story I don't mind going over it again as it allows me to  pick up on things I've missed and uncover new dialogue that I would have otherwise missed.

There are more bugs in the game than I would expect from a product no longer in beta. Though not catastrophic, they can take frustrate and take away some of the fun from and otherwise well designed and thought out game. Also the models could use some attention as the seem to lack any real depth or contrast and on that note im also finding the camera system too constrictive in the way im not able change the veiw in all of the directions I would like. Camera snapping to charecters during combat is also an issue, it completely resets veiws and im finding myself having to constantly readjust to get the veiw back the way it was after each charactors turn instead of the black screen it leaves me with. There is also a problem where the terrain and light source seperate not allowing panning of the camera during combat when trying to move a charactor which I was frustrated with a few times. Using ladders during combat can lead to some very interesting animation where you can expect to see the charactor ascend the ladder when it should be descending and just recently my whole world map reset after a raider battle. Although the forums say there wil be patches, by the time they're released I and im sure many others will be onto a whole new game.

Although I do enjoy playing the game I also enjoy playing alphas and I think that a lot of the features this game lacks or has wrong feels very similar to an unpolished product that should otherwise be less than $20 and have Beta stamped across it. The only real saving grace at the moment is the depth of story as the game at $40 should look more like $20 in this condition, after all there are games at this price point that outstrip Wasteland 2 in a lot of ways. So would I recommend it? Not at this price. However I do enjoy playing it but would like to see it cheaper until fixed. $40 for a buggy, glitchy game or $40 for X-com? Perhaps more time in Beta and less rushing to push the game onto shelves could have seen an amazing game to rival RPG's its predecessor inspired" but instead
date: all we really get is a great story full of bugs.\n\nI've noticed people hating on bad reviews so I would like to say that this is my opinion of the game if you don't like it then that's yours. Don't be lazy

reviewText:
First, if I do not recommend a game, that does not mean it is bad. It is just not so good that amount of money/time one gonna spend is justified to what’s he gonna get.

That being said, here is a list of things I found disappointing (list is incomplete and unordered):
Repetitiveness of using skills to get random scanty stuff from chests, safes, etc. One cannot know beforehand if there will be random contents in a box or not. It gets boring, and save-loads before each box makes it even more miserable.
Unrelated skills and attributes make some of latter inferior.
Some of the weapon types are inferior to others by design. One cannot know beforehand (one third of the game it is becoming clear, and you lost about 25 hours already).
Some of the skills are not needed to to be taken at all as some of recruits will have them. One cannot know which ones beforehand. So player is doomed to waste either time to restart the game, or read spoilers in guides, or waste skill points which actually needed to upgrade needed skills as difficulty of the game makes a sudden jump up in about half the game.
There are not enough locations to roam, gameplay is a bit too linear.
If the game has a squad-based combat tactics in it, why do characters walk a crowd and there is no way to choose a formation before the combat starts? Especially sudden scripted combats.
No way to revive fallen surgeon. Even paid doctors who rarely happen to be nearby cannot help. Sorry, lad, load your game.
How comes leaders of two different towns are both into other men’s wives?Overall it is actually a nice game, which should be recommended to a person who has spare 150 hours of time and desire to repeat one half of a game to learn what should and should not be done at character creation. Maybe GOTY edition will fix some of the issues, but I am not up to repeating this adventure.

reviewText:
This game represents crucial event in RPG world. Specifically the collapse of hopes for a game worth Fallout 1,2 (or Baldurs gate 2 or Arcanum, etc.) to be ever made.

Wasteland have no deep character developing system. In fact it is pretty linear. General rule is the further you are in game, the better skill is required. Good thing is that half of them are almost needless.
Open world is not so amasing to explore due to small size of it. Although world looks pretty unrealistic and empty, what could be allright for an indie game, but not 6 million dollars game claimed to be great.
Tha game is definetly not a marauding simulator. Looting requiers a lot of skillpoints to be spent on coresponding skills. Upon what you have random content of crates and safes. Limited time, eh?
There is no expansive net of quests neither complicated requirements for non-combat skills and atributes for this quests.
But the worst part of the game is combat.
Enjoy.
voteText: 14 of 26 people (54%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In short, Wasteland 2 tells a story about what you cannot do - open doors, chests or safes, hit enemies or talk cunningly. Mostly at the beginning of the game to be fair, but even later on there are several objects to interact with that often cause you to fail critically when using a maxed out skill on them. You then either have to accept this and carry on or load a previous save game and try again.

Given the fact that the loot often is not worth the trouble, option 1 should be the way to go (or ignore the possible loot in the fist place), but that's not what I expect of a game. Reloading (and again and again sometimes) is a slow and tedious process. May be I'm not getting the point and Wasteland 2 then is not the game for me, but on the other hand this is a personal review and all about how I like it.

There's more boring stuff in it, like quests which have you to visit the same places a few times over without the possibility to quick travel. Given the size and layout of some areas and the way they are connected to other areas sometimes causes you to sit there for minutes and tell your team to go back and forth. That's a way of extending the play time. One I don't like at all. Especially if the quest giver sends you more often than needed to the same place when all that has to be done could have easily been accomplished on the first visit.

Personally I didn't care much for the story. Cannot really identify the cause though. I found myself mostly rushing through the dialog options, only scanning for relevant key words to get through quickly - which is a shame because I think the writing itself seems to be fine. But I couldn't connect the the world like I did when playing Fallout 1 and 2 for example. In the end I tried to solve all open quests and finish the story so I could mark this game as completed.

Technically I had severe performance issues in some (mostly indoor) areas on my Linux machine and encountered several bugs. The Linux version of Borderlands 2 for example runs much better here.

I'm not saying Wasteland 2 is a bad game. Most people seem to like it. But you have to tolerate a couple of things which just annoy me to the point the fun gets significantly spoiled. All in all I'm too disappointed to recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just playing the beta, but my god, it was time to have a Wasteland / Fallout (1 or 2) type of game in which the developer does not hold your hand pointing you to go from arrow to arrow, no Sir! This is a game for a true armchair general, utilizing turn based combat; the gentlemen's way to fight. Including full 3d top down violent depictions of violence of the murdering of your fellow men.
This is the type of game in which you take your time to plot your next move. Not Run N' Gun, but Think then Shoot. this is going to be a huge timesink for me. And i'm already in love with this the same way a piggie loves his mud.

reviewText:
I am so happy Brian Fargo and his team managed to pull such a fantastic experience. I also want to thank each and every baker for giving us the chance to play again a fantastic game like the ones from our childhood.
I didn't play Wasteland 1 because I was to little. My first post apocalyptic game was Fallout 2. I remember that a very good friend of mine got me Fallout 2 and I was thinking that this is crap I mean I didn't like the graphics at the beginning of the game at the Temple of trials. Boy was I wrong. I felt in love with that game and after 2nd I played the first. After that I only liked Arcanum but although it was a great game it was not in the Fallout setting. Fallout Tactics was released and the graphics were great but that was not the Fallout I grew up with.
Interplay lost the licence to Bethesda and so Fallout 3 was born. I liked it but it was like Fallout Tactics more of a spin off then the real thing. Fallout : New Vegas was great though thanks to Obsidian.
But now we have the opportunity to play the real prequel of Fallout and what a great time this is for CRPG.
For the ones that are asking how is WL2 compared to Divinity : Original Sin I have to say that I really like that game but I don't like the setting as much and the dialogs seemed they repeated a lot. And now about the game itself :
I like it from the beta. I played it since the very first beta and I just love how it has been upgraded and improved in every single way. I managed to finish the beta.Now that it's finally out I am trying to take my time and enjoy every pixel of it. I am not at all bored by having to start from scratch and I already managed to do the good part in Rail Nomad.
The story is strong and very mysterious. The choices do matter in short and long terms.
People complain about the graphics but I do like it a lot. I really love the gore in combat and the death animations.
The Unity engine is great and I really like that we can have a bird eye view of the party.
The music is incredible and Mark Morgan shows us what a talented man he is.
My only complaint is the lack of stealth ond steal but I can live without them. I know that steal tend to break the barter system.
Every day since release I just want to finish the work day so I can come home to play.
This game is the perfect example of the games that we love can have a big success as well as the dumb ones that have flooded the market in the past years.

reviewText:
This game is awesome. It's challenging, complex, rich, funny, and detailed. If you keep the game in zoomed out isometric mode the graphics are immersive and vibrant. There's a lot of blood. The sound effects are fantastic.

If you liked the BGs, IWDs, Fallouts 1 & 2, and so on, this is the game for you.

Easily the best CRPG experience I have had in absolute ages. Blows trash like Dragon Age out of the water. I stayed up until 6am last night playing. Haven't done that since BG2.

Only criticisms: The NPCs are a little thin. Combat could be more dynamic.
