reviewText:
Not disappointed!

First of all, Fallout 1 and 2 (FO1/2) were some of my all-time favourite games when I was younger. I never played Wasteland 1 and only heard of this when I started playing Fallout, by which time it was already 'dated' and I never bothered to play it (which might have been a mistake!). I was quite disappointed by Fallout 3 (though New Vegas redeemed the franchise for me). Yes, it was graphically more advanced but it totally lacked the feel and freedom that FO1/2 had. Sure there was a ton of stuff to do and the world was rich, but where it lacked was the way you customized your character and your inventory. One of the things that made FO1/2 great was the sheer amount of weapons (most with multiple ammo types/modes) and it always felt that stuff was scarce and you had to use the right tool for the job.

So when Wasteland 2 was announced I was apprehensive: Would it stand up to FO1/2? I am pleased to say that I am not disappointed, and in some areas it even surpasses it.

Here are a list of things I love about this game:
- The party system. It has been a while since we had a great game where you can control all members of your party (another great game recently being Divinity Original Sin). Even FO1/2 only had a main character plus one companion model. The fact that I don't have to discard 90% of items because my main cannot use them is very refreshing. I also don't feel like I am missing out on stuff because among all members of the team someone will be able to cover it.
- Meaningful skills. Every skill (well maybe almost every) is useful throughout the game and needs to be constantly leveled. However it's not hard to build a party that covers everything. And this again goes back to the party system. You need to create a team that complements each other and not just dump everything into guns. In fact one member in my party only had a rudimentary fighting abillity but turned out to be the most crucial to success throughout.
- Tons of items. Lots of weapons, all customizable. At the same time ammo is scarce, especially at the start. Rely on melee to save bullets (this is reminiscent of one of the first fights in FO1 when I had a pistol with 3 bullets...).
- Tactical combat. The combat is fun, positioning matters and many a fight can be won by changing tactics or preparing better by positioning the team. Combat doesn't always start at line of sight which gives you the opportunity to get everyone in a favourable position.
- Meaningful decisions. I wont spoil too much but the decisions are there and meaningful and not just a simple try A, reload, try B. Sometimes it's only hours later that you realize what effect your actions had.
- Humour. There are some great easter eggs in there that add to the humour. It's not as overboard as FO2 was but it has the same wacky ideas.

Some areas where the game shines less:
- The graphics are somewhat outdated. Personally I don't see this as too much of a problem (they are nowhere near bad) but if this concerns you, it might be a problem.
- There is a LOT of text. Don't expect everything in voiceover. Very little is covered. Again, not a problem as the dialog is well written and worth reading, but nothing for people with short attention spans.

Overall I would thoroughly recommend this to anyone who loved FO1/2 or any classic RPG.

9/10

reviewText:
As a fan of Fallout I've waited a long time for a game to live up to its legacy, finally the game i was waiting for showed up, only had to wait about 20 years ;)

I never did play wasteland one back in the day but I've since seeing where it all started made me to step back into the same world.

Wasteland 2 has your standard fallout 1/2 combat system, with a bit of classic xcom. It's turn based and dependent on your stats and placement and a number of other factors. when not in combat you can move your party around real time. I find the compromise perfect for giving you enough control in fights while not slowing down the game too much.

I'm very happy with the game and recommend it to anyone who likes this style of RPG.

reviewText:
My first night playing the final version of this game I found myself up past 3am. This hasn't happened since the Mass Effect series and Skyrim.

The theme of Wasteland 2 is consequence. This is very much the same as Wasteland 1, but more pronounced. Everything you do has consequences, not just the little things like missing a target on the battlefield or epic things like the survival of mankind; though, those are certainly there. Your choices decides what individuals, factions, and settlements survive. Who you help affects who will help you in turn and even make new enemies. Despite the natural technical limitations of any scripted game, inXile has managed to deliver a game that provides a near a living, breathing world as I've ever seen. Even if that world is a radioactive wasteland rasping out what could be its last breath at any moment.

There is a certain level of complexity to the game, but the character system (attributes, skills, equipment, and combat) is simple enough that you can grasp them quickly. The reason for this complexity quickly becomes apparent as you find you can use different skills to try to get around the same obstacles, offering you multiple approaches to the same problem.

This freedom cascades in all things: how you build characters, how you approach encounters, the soluitons you choose, and the direction you take. Where there is a certain amount of gating (e.g. you must have these rad suits to safely proceed), you are free to explore, ignoring missions and quests as you like. This exploration can be quite rewarding as you find shrines and caches, but it can also get you in trouble as you face enemies more powerful than you. Again, consequences. Enemies don't level" with you; so if someone's too tough
date: just come back later.\n\nThere's still some bugs
hoursPlayed: especially once you leave the desert for overgrown marsh of LA
voteText: but none of them are game breaking and I'm sure they will get shaken out."

reviewText:
Really enjoyed this game.

+ Old-school like post-apocalyptic world-saving :-) (a bit like Fallout)
+ large world
+ quests with multiple choises/endings
+ ~50h for a relatively fast playthrough
+ large amounts of lore-text, descriptive texts

- large amounts of text :-) If you don't like reading walls of text then this game isn't for you. Very little voice-acting
- minor bugs (e.g. lower-tier radiation suit doesn't get thrown away if you get the higher tier; can't sell)
- sometimes not enough info for quests given (I would like to see a game which does the questlog like morrowind. A transcript of the conversation.) -> needed to consult wiki for some quests
- not the best graphics
- could use more diverse audio


If you are into oldschool post-apocalypse RPGs, like to spend a little time to get immersed and don't mind reading text then this is the right game for you.

If you want the best graphics and are a fan of 'show, don't tell' -> better get one of the newer Fallouts

reviewText: What I like about this game is it doesn't hold your hand from the start. The character building is deep enough that you have to really think about rounding your team out. For instance you might not want a heavy gunner and an assault rifleman because they use the same kind of ammo, which can be sparse. Every fight requires some strategization, from avoiding triggering environmental stuff to positioning your shotgunners so they don't also pellet the guy in front of them. The game is also difficult enough that I don't feel bad about savescumming. At first I was honestly wondering why there wasn't an ironman mode because that seems to be so popular nowadays, but I see why. This is one of the few games lately that can keep my attention for hours on end. It might not be for everyone but I highly recommend it for people who enjoy CRPGS because so far it's gone toe to toe with the classics and has me curious about Wasteland 1.\n

Anyway, it is rare to get a sqad based game ala Jagged Alliance, let alone one set in a post-appocolyptic world.  I did have fun exploring the world despite the bugs.

I would rate the combat mechanics as a 5 on a scale of 1 to 10.  They are servicable and certanly can be improved.
The skill gain system is quite dull, such as the next rank just adds 6% to some ability (hit with a guy, unlock something, disarm something, etc...).

Some of the puzzles in the game are not very intuitive.  I had to google a few of them, but hopefully if you wait a few months, there will be some nice faqs.  Even after reading the solutions to some of them, they are things I would have never figured out.  For in one area you find a screw driver.  In another room there are some odd looking tiles here and there.  No tool tip, just odd looking.  The thing is, there is no hint that you need to use the screw driver on these tiles.  Even given that, if you use the screw driver on the wrong tile (of the right kind) it tells you that you can't use the screwdriver on that.  So that would lead you to think that isn't the right use for the screw driver.  However there is one tile which looks just like all the rest of the tiles that say You can't use the screwdriver on that" that you CAN use it on
date: which has the tresure you are looking for.\n\nThen there are other objects you find that have NO CLUE as to thier use
recommended: but indeed are useful to someone
hoursPlayed: somewhere.  Here is a hint
voteText: the stuff you get out of toasters IS USEFUL to SOMEONE SOMEWHERE.  It may even be useful to someone in another act.\n\nAnyhow
helpfulPercent: you might be wondering why I am recommending this to buy with the above said.  Despite all that
votesHelpful: it is a fun game.  I enjoyed the exploration and the story.  I did not finish it because it was too buggy in the 2nd act.  Maybe I will someday because I am curious as to how the story turns out."

reviewText:
[This review is NOT for Director's Cut, it is for Standard Edition - Director's cut only adds to this]
If you like post-apoc games, this might be for you - especially the very patient, more old-skool users who have LOTS of time on their hands...

No really, I mean lots of time, sometimes, a bit too much honestly.  In-case you don't get it PATIENCE MUST BE ONE OF YOUR VIRTUES, otherwise completing this game WONT be.

Load times are quick [1-6 seconds on SSDs], gfx are okay (for this year, could be better...) sound is appropriate including periodic voiceovers that are well done and music that is quite fitting and will make FO 1&2 players feel right at home (Mark Morgan).  Good job getting the Fallout music man to come back.

Went through and got the repeaters, and then had to go to the Ag center, to do the next mission, and the whole while I'm doing this, another outpost is claiming it's getting clobbered, and now I'm poisoned, and don't have a clue what to do.  You feel a bit helpless, and at fault, and not entirely in a good way, but that may have been just me.  There is entirely too much going on at once and I'm unable to concentrate on this mission enough to solve it, while still having to go to another place after this is done.   First hour or two went pretty smoothly, hours three and four I'm out of ammo, there's entirely too much ammo management for me to put any more effort into it so in most of the battles half my guys were without ammo and getting massacred by rabbits on easy (well almost).
May want to invest in some unarmed skills at some point, just keep in mind to save enough skill points to get your gun skills up too or you won't hit ANYTHING.

Will eagerly be waiting for Fallout 4 as this definitely is not Fallout... not 1 not 2 not any of them.  Too much inventory juggling - that was the icing on the cake and I'd have rather eaten the plate whilst I tried to figure out what to do!  A shared inventory screen would have been a wonderful invention with individual character inventories being limited to slots guns, armor, trinkets, etc.

Pass this one up until you've exhausted the fallout series as of late.  It can be a good game, but you will struggle to afford enough ammo unless you loot everything and take every last bit of junk you can scrounge.  There is a barter perk but it brings at most 10% discount/10% bonus on bought/sold items.  It's not that this game is bad, it can be very unforgiving and hard to keep your guns loaded let alone hit the target until your gun skill is maxed.

For those playing on a RADEON video card, I can attest that there isn't much gfx issue at all sans the water-building interior in Domonta - a little bit of flickering, but can still play fine.  You're only in there for the duration of one battle anyways so regardless, it won't be too much issue.

I have updated my review a bit, after playing 30+ hours (it is a long game, I'd say im half-way through it), and it feels like a touch of fallout tactics along with fallout 2.  I'd have to say that players who enjoyed the late-90s playthrough of Fallout 1 and 2 will feel at home here in the setting - all the way down to accidently nuking some religious cult - oops... heh.  Though I will say you can with assuredness tell that this is the first-go-round for some of the people creating the game, it is NOT shoddy work by any means.  There is much fun to be had here, and much humour to snicker at if you have the patience.   This isn't DooM, this isn't run-and-gun and blast through everything with reckless abandon...this is it's own game.  A 25-40$ USD price-tag seems appropriate here, and I think most people would be satisfied with the game for this.  That being said, it isn't nearly as crashey as Fallout 3 and New Vegas were out of the box (or possibly even now years after release), so don't let me sell it short.  Watch some videos, read the reviews and decide for yourself.  Try not to get discouraged before getting to level 15-20 or so with your characters, as it gets much more rewarding when you can actually afford ammo AND hit the target in battle.  I would also mention on this last note that the age-rating for this game applies to both the violence and the difficulty mentally that you may have if you lack extremely good problem solving skills (teenagers barring some ingeniously crafty ones may have trouble).  Good luck.

Recommended to take a field medic-surgeon, weaponsmith, locksmith/safecracker, and someone with keen perception and good with knocking down obstacles with you on your first try, you'll get more characters in your party at a later date if you so choose.  You still won't be able to do everything your first time.  This game for most will be good for more than one play-through.

Just buy up all the ammo & health-items you can afford, seriously.

reviewText:
Looks like lots of reviewers are already familar with this genre (like the classic fallout series). Well, as a newcomer, I'm writing this review for all rpg newbies like me out there.

- Background:
The world is destroyed by nukes, hundreds of years passed. Your home area is isolated by radiations, you don't know much about what's beyond them. You're(will be) a new member of the Rangers, an organization trying to keep order and peace of the area. It's not about the nukes(generations passed), but more about the post-apocalypse-world-people-sucks-thing-ness.

- Gameplay
Top view, you control four characters(Unless they're dead) + followers you picked up. You talk to people, get quests, get random abandoned loots yadi yada.
Annnd most importantly, the battle. it's turn-based. Every character gets a turn(some get more often than others - fast and smart ones). You can attack, move, ambush etc during that turn, each move using up your points for that turn.

...how do I explain this game...It's freakin' huge, for one. I don't know if this is the usual standard for this genre, but the devs thought of everything, really. For example, you can use lockpicking on a locked door, but if you fail...you can try again. Of course! I didn't even think that was possible for some reason the first time, but then I realized that it makes much more sense. But if you make a 'critical failure', the lock mechanism breaks and you can't lockpick it anymore. BUUUT you can repair it back with your 'mechanical repair' skill and try again. Also if all of that fails, you just smash the door by force(which also has a chance of critical failure).

Same vibe goes for the battle. I learned not to shoot enemies with sniper rifle when my teammate is in the way the hard way.

All your characters can die, and the game will keep going. Unless all of them are dead, of course. In that case, the game says, Well
date: all of you died in the wasteland. We don't have fancy ending for that
recommended: few people will even remember you anyway...bye bye"\n\nIt's intended as a game where you're NOT supposed to reload after a failure
hoursPlayed: I think. It's like the game's saying
voteText: "Oh
helpfulPercent: you failed! Well
votesHelpful: take your responsibility
votesTotal:
live with the consequences from now on. We've already prepared another ending for ya...and it will affect your future quests as well"

[THING I'D LIKE TO BE IMPROVED]

A few things

reviewText: Wasteland 2 is an absolute masterpiece of ccrpg storytelling and gameplay, it rivals if not blows its predecessor out of the water in the best of ways. The original inspriration for the Fallout series, it's easy to see why Brian Fargo wanted too breath new life into this once dead series. My only hope is that we will see it grow into a new series, as this is a game deserving of more than a few sequels.

Early Access Review

reviewText:
Some of you know that our own indie After Reset[afterreset.com] was born in the moment when we simply got tired of waiting for a true old-school Fallout 3 (Van Buren), in the moment when we understood that no one other than us, the gamers would do that. For a long time we were left with a very skeptical mood toward Wasteland 2… And it lasted until last week, when we got its release version on Steam.

Guys, it turned out to be very interesting! I.e., this game, of course doesn’t have anything in common with either Fallout 1&2&T, or with After Reset RPG… But it doesn’t even have to be like them, or even be a classic RPG. It has its own interesting style/setting/mechanics/gameplay… In general, I personally don’t understand what exactly its secret is, but it’s really cool and fun to play. I played all weekend without stopping (and there’s no end or border in this game), and I’ll be very happy to back Wasteland 3!

One nuance: two times in the beginning I thought of deleting the game after creating a character (a sentiment I’ve heard from plenty of gamer friends). I really didn’t like the character portraits, and I don’t like to play as a big faceless group. But Brian Fargo has slyly provided for the ability to load your own portraits and delete the others besides your own character from the group. We’ve prepared a character portrait pack from After Reset especially for you: http://indiedb.com/games/after-reset/downloads/after-reset-rpgs-custom-avatars-for-wasteland-2.

I’m sure that even if you’ve had doubts, with our pack, Wasteland 2 will sparkle with fresh colors for you! You have to play it; the game is really worth it!

- Richard Nixon, Black Cloud Studios, http://afterreset.com

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is the first of hopefully many games made for people who like proper RPGs and not (just) explosions and chain bikinis.

It's an old-school RPG, meant to be played with thought and investment, but not so much thought and investment that it'll scare away newbies. Basically the best game of the last 4 years, hands down, even though it's not without flaws.

Of course, any gamer worth its salt will have played, finished and enjoyed plenty of critically bugged and flawed games, because, in the end, a bugs can be patched, crappy design can't. And Wasteland 2 is a diamond with a couple of rough edges, at most.

Brilliant.

reviewText:
An excelent Wasteland 1 sequel. If you except Fallout Tactics then this is as close as you can get. If you expect Fallout 1 or 2 then you have the wrong expectation.
It is nonetheless a dark disturbing tour of a post apokalyptica, one can only say: lucky are those that died.

They created this world and atmosphere so well that there are places that just make you full of hatred for the injustice seen.
A very told tale that emphacises your characters to be not just brutes but rather smarty pants for the wastes are more dangerous for fools.

reviewText: Just played the game for about 3 hours and I think it's safe to say that the game delightfully brings back the memories of original Fallout (not the Bethesda FPS series that mostly lacked atmosphere).\n\nConserving action points by skipping turns plus the ambush system is clever additions to the turn-based strategy gameplay, I'm absolutely enjoying it and even though I'm controlling multiple characters, I'm easily able to command them; there's almost not a moment I say No don't do that
date: do this!" because the team system works good enough.\n\nAll in all
recommended: it feels like late 90's again. Well done."

reviewText:
What a game. one of the first Kickstarter successes and the first of a return to the isometric top down RPG's of the early 2000's.

Wasteland 2 follows on from Wasteland a few years after the end of the first game. You play a group new recruits out to investigate the death of a fellow Ranger, but get sucked into something much bigger.

It doesn't quite have the depth of games like Baldurs Gate, but the humour it gives, the world it portrays and the character you meet are really diverse, from your lowly farmer to the suicidal mini-nuke cult thing who's name escapes me!

If you grew up with BG, or IWD, this is very good return to those nostalgic days.

reviewText:
Update: I changed my review to not recommend in order to purposefully lower the rating of this game on Steam. Quite simply when I kickstarted this game, Brian Fargo liked to go on and on about how they wanted to get away from big Publisher models, always being on the hook to publishers just seeking profit. But then they have been going out and trying to force developers with complete success so far, to change the names of their games if it contains the word Wasteland.

You know its funny, because thats exactly something a publisher would do, they would throw money away pursuing these things instead of making games like Brian Fargo claimed thats what he wanted to do. Its understandable to engage in these legal matters when a game is intentionally trying to ape your stuff, but in every case the only similarity between titles, was the word Wasteland.

Have the courage to stand for something InXile, no one is going to try and USURP the Wasteland IP by making ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little indie games. I won't be sending you anymore of my money(unless you get the Fallout IP back and make Fallout games). So yeah, Never again.


Original, still true review below:

I have about 110 combined hours between Wasteland 2 Classic and the Director's Cut.

I backed this game on kickstarter and was pleased with Wasteland 2, to get the Director's Cut after for free was a huge bonus for me.

The game itself plays like a squad-based Fallout 1 and 2, but in its own 1980s style post-nuclear setting. The RPG elements are solid but the game is combat focused which I am happy for. You get a number of useable skills to to do quests with, find hidden objects and loot. There is a ton of flavor text everywhere you go which help adds to the immersion and feeling of the game which I love. The music is a perfect ambient style soundtrack which hits all the right notes and there is an ambient soundtrack for areas aswell to help add to that immersion.

There are tons of things to do in the wasteland and plenty to shoot aswell. Lots of weapons to choose from and different types of armors to wear. You can find clothing to dress your rangers up if you want, or will need to find clothing if you get it burnt off in combat!

I think if you enjoy squad based turn based combat, you'll like this game. If you enjoy post-apocalypse settings, you'll enjoy this game. If you like to read and use your imagination, you'll like this game.

If you liked Fallout 1 and 2, you will like this game.

I found a Speak and Spell(remember those?) and pawned to the vendor for 8 scrap, it doesn't get much better than that.

9/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't give amazing reviews of games often. But this is a must have game for anybody who likes long games and likes to use their heads. The story line is just amazing, but I hope you like to read. This game will make you think and punish you if you just want to click through it. Just buy it and play it. Period.

Note* I feel like playing this game on easy or normal would not do this game justice. I am playing it on Veteran. Great challenge and I have found myself wondering how I am going to proceed with limited supplies and such. Also, you can seriously ♥♥♥♥ your game up at the very beginning. Characters get perma-death and if you don't have the characters or resources to proceed, this game can become unbeatable. Be smart!

9/10

reviewText:
An excellent game, a truly spiritual heir of Fallout 2.

It's challenging, and while in my opinion the opening plot is not very immersive, it soon catches up and with its great, fallout-like gameplay (not the bethesda pewpew one, i mean the real fallout gameplay) you'll be soon wanting for more level after level.

The combat is fun, never repetitive, and your choices affect how the game develops.

Absolutely a must have.

reviewText:
The Incredible feeling of both the original, gory Wasteland and the Infinity engine games is recaptured in Wasteland 2. Death awaits behind every corner and every bullet can explode you like a blood sausage.

The exploration is solid, the combat is great, the side characters are hilarious and at low levels you can get killed off by rabbits.

Buy this game, buy it now.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a modern throwback to a long-gone era of gaming, when CRPGs were epic, and it wasn't uncommon to play one for weeks and still not reach the end; an era before hand-holding, where your decisions had real consequences.

Pros:
Huge amount of freedom with character skills and attributes
Choices matter, truly affecting how the game's story unfolds
A very large number of playable characters that can join your party
Interesting story with decent voice acting
Intuitive turn-based tactical combat
Several, several hours of gameplay
Evokes memories of Fallout, X-COM, and Baldur's Gate.
Cons:
Not all bugs have been worked out, but I've not run into anything gamebreaking
The graphics could be optimized better; even on a pretty modern system, I lag at the mid-range settings
Steep learning curve - you will probably start over after getting the hang of things (but it's worth it)
Calculations for skill usage are a bit too simplified - and attributes only affect combat.
Requires time to commit to the game, due to the length.
In short, it's right up my alley, but for those unfamiliar with the genre, or who are looking for a super deep experience like Planescape: Torment, it may not be their cup of tea.

reviewText:
Phenomenal. This is what happens when you let talent of the likes of Brian Fargo and his dream team of writers and designers (and Mark Morgan) create the game they wish to make: a love letter to classic CRPGs full of rich descriptive text and atmosphere, amazing depth in options, laugh out loud ridiculousness, and several truly chilling moments. In an age of gaming where we've grown tired of pressing the win button, Wasteland 2 throws hundreds of possibilities in your direction and doesn't even pretend to try to hold your hand, allowing you the joy of discovery and surprise as your decisions often leave no clear cut winners.

You'll often find yourself under-equipped and struggling to keep your party members alive, tossing those last few rounds of ammo to a teammate and praying for their 35% hit probability to go your way after enemies have left you devastated. And right when you think you've gotten the hang of things, new scenarios will put you firmly back in your place.

Wasteland 2 is a shining beacon of what games once were, and a sensational example of what they very well can be today when the fans - and not profits - come first.

reviewText: This game is super good. Combat is like X-Com light and is servicable but pretty simple. The story and world is pretty generic, but there's a ton of stuff to do and things to read, with over 800,000 words total (!).  The game really rewards exploration, as a result, it's very nonlinear and there are a bunch of secrets. There's a lot of cool faction stuff, plenty of choices that determine the fate of each area, and a pretty insane level of detail to boot. Probably the best Kickstarter game I've played yet.

reviewText:
For isometric RPG veterans like myself, this is a game I have been itching to play ever since the Baldur's Gate re-release reminded me why this genre can be so great. Wonderful writing, haunting atmosphere, a universe that straddles the line between believable and silly (though the use of CDs as jewellery is a bit much) and the satisfying sound of a bullet (or bullets) tearing through some schlub's skull make this a must for those craving a hit of old-school Fallout.

Even better, if you remember the original Wasteland, there's tons of lore call-backs here to reward your playtime. Knowing the exact details of Highpool or Base Cochise isn't necessary, though - exposition galore takes care of that for series newbies.

I would like to see skill use streamlined, through. It feels like a few clicks too many just to perform a hack or lock pick.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I am close friends with some of the developers of this game, however - I do not feel that this compromises the integrity of my review.

I grew up playing the original Fallout, and other isometric-ish RPGs on the infinity engine. I've always had a soft spot in my heart for them and I honestly did not think I could ever return to that feeling.

A friend picked up Wasteland 2 for me prior to release - I had my reservations when I started playing, but those went quickly out the window.
Sure, it is said you can never go back to paradise -but you can come pretty close.
I've just recently had the chance to finish my playthrough of Wasteland 2, the time and fun I've had from this title easily justifies the cost. However I don't think that is what I should leave as the primary point of the review.

I am not one who enjoys replaying games, especially ones driven by a central narrative. I rarely find games that truly capture my attention and interest these days but Wasteland 2.. Well lets leave it at the following point:

After completing Wasteland 2, I immediately wanted to reload my mid game save and play back through again with a different approach and playstyle to see how it affected the outcome of the game.
I've not done that since the 90s. :)

Loved this game, my game of the year for 2014.

reviewText: I can't in good conscience recommend this game. Having played it from start to finish, I found the plot lazy, the game mechanics needlessly complicated/annoying, the characters one-dimensional, and the player's agency seemingly absent. Going against enemies with energy weapons? Better strip down to your undies! Find something that's locked? Better hope you have the correct out of SEVEN potential skills needed to open it (Safecracking, Lockpicking, Computer Science, Alarm Disarming, Brute Force, Demolitions, Toaster Repair (?)) at rank 10. Slaughtered every member of a militant cult? Nope, according to the game's post-script, they went on to slaughter everyone in the area because you didn't stop them! Buy Fallout 2 instead.

reviewText:
Just play Underrail for a true classic isometric RPG made recently... Im sorry Brian Fargo, but this is a letdown. I came upon this realization after my team got killed through a building. Because that square crate placed oh so conveniently in the battlefield will shield me better than a building.

Every negative review so far speaks truth. This feels like a Beta. Bland combat, weak/unintuitive skill point system, paper flat npcs, horrible interface, poor camera view controls (why cant I pan down and see what my rangers are seeing?).

Gameplay is just a letdown. Story? Is pretty meh so far. Definitely feels like a 'Fallout-lite'. Not very gripping.

Honestly if you want to recreate the Fallout magic" this is not it. Try Underrail

that actually emphasizes its gameplay and experience first and dont fold to the hype for Wasteland 2.

reviewText:
Wasteland was one of the first RPG / Turn based strategy games I played as a kid so definitely has some nostalgic value.

That said Wasteland 2 is a very well executed follow up. There are not many games I have the attention span or make the time to complete and after 80+ hours I was sad when it was over and am considering a second play through on a harder difficulty.

The writing is amusing and if you like turn based strategy the combat is great.

If you like games like XCOM, Advanced Wars, Fire Emblem in a Fallout setting with more RPG and story elements give Wasteland a try.

reviewText: With tons of lore and plenty of content, I found my self pouring hours in to this game. Wasteland 2 may not have the best graphics, but for a game on a budget, it did pretty good. The game definately does things better than some games that came out in 2014. However, there are a few bugs. Such as characters not wanting to follow where you tell them to and your mouse disappearing, but usually these can be fixed with a quick restart of the game out return to the main menu. I found myself laughing at the little things in Wasteland 2, as well as reading it's what seemed like endless lore, doing it's numerous side quests, and replaying the game to see the affects of the choices I did not make in my first run. In all I give Wasteland 2 a 9/10 since there are some bugs that need to be fixed and the character customization could use some work ( the characters look pretty bad and ugly close up), but in all the game is really fun.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I am close friends with some of the developers of this game, however - I do not feel that this compromises the integrity of my review.

I grew up playing the original Fallout, and other isometric-ish RPGs on the infinity engine. I've always had a soft spot in my heart for them and I honestly did not think I could ever return to that feeling.

A friend picked up Wasteland 2 for me prior to release - I had my reservations when I started playing, but those went quickly out the window.
Sure, it is said you can never go back to paradise -but you can come pretty close.
I've just recently had the chance to finish my playthrough of Wasteland 2, the time and fun I've had from this title easily justifies the cost. However I don't think that is what I should leave as the primary point of the review.

I am not one who enjoys replaying games, especially ones driven by a central narrative. I rarely find games that truly capture my attention and interest these days but Wasteland 2.. Well lets leave it at the following point:

After completing Wasteland 2, I immediately wanted to reload my mid game save and play back through again with a different approach and playstyle to see how it affected the outcome of the game.
I've not done that since the 90s. :)

Loved this game, my game of the year for 2014.

reviewText:
At 130.5 hours, I still haven't beaten this ♥♥♥♥ing game. This is the first time since New Vegas I actually pursued the side content actively and I love it! The Ranger customization really gives you a sense of connection to your team and there are some really interesting NPC characters you can interact with, some can even join you in your mission.The game itself is quite fun, holding simple, yet fun, turn-based combat combined with a well paced leveling system, a wide array of different skills your characters can spec into, and writing that you can tell had a lot of love put into it. I can tell the devs of Wasteland had a lot of fun and enjoyment with this game, returning to the roots of classic video games with their encouragment of exploration and higher difficulty.

Overall, I'd say this game is worth your time. Though with any game it may take some getting used to. This is very different from the typical video game that comes out these days, retaining it's old concepts of exploration, branching paths, missions that can be failed without a game over (most of the time) and even have worse consequences than a game over, and requires you to manage who is talking with whom when you have a charisma guy in your party. It's still fun, and if it's on sale you should go for it.

Also you can repair toasters to get random ♥♥♥♥ out of them. You can also pick up ♥♥♥♥ and sell it for lots of cash. 10/10

reviewText:
To start, if anyone is having crashing problems on WIN 10, type -force-d3d9 into launch options on Steam. Haven't had a single crash after that.

About the game, Wasteland 2 is not for everyone. Not by a long shot. It requires patience, thinking and in some cases, nerves of steel. The top-down view and turn-based combat may turn some people off. It's a hardcore RPG where your choices, starting from the very beginning at character creation, have lasting consequences throughout the game. If you're looking for an experience similar to the more recent Fallout games, you won't find it here.

The character creation is intimidating at first, especially for newcomers to these types of games. There are tons of skills and you have no way to know in advance which are useful and which are more situational. I suggest consulting a character creation guide, but if you want to do everything on your own, one tip: make a team of specialists. After character creation, it's good to keep in mind these three things: Talk to EVERYONE, LOOT everything that isn't bolted down (or if it is, Brute Force can help with that ;)) and do EVERYTHING you can before moving to the next area. If you miss something, it might mean missing out on quests, companions or loot.

The combat is tactical and turn-based. Director's Cut added precision strikes, which are not too useful at the beginning but can be lifesavers late in the game. It also brough some flavor to the combat system, which can be somewhat tedious at times. I found most of the quirks to be quite useless; their downsides were either too bad or they were too situational.
Same goes for perks, they were a nice addition, but when selecting perks I had difficulty finding ones that were actually useful. Overall, precision strikes, quirks and perks feel somewhat like an aftertought; they're there and they're nice to have every once in a while, but they aren't really crucial to completing the game.

The weapon rebalancing of DC was a welcome addition. Assault rifles and Snipers are still king, but Shotguns, for example, now actually have some use. SMG's and Handguns still suck, though.

Overall, I definitely recommend this game to everyone. While it can be somewhat tedious and difficult at times, it's still a whole lot of fun. The world is huge and there's plenty to do, like blowing off the heads of raiders or solving feuds peacefully. BUT DON'T PRESS THE BUTTON AT RANGER CITADEL!

reviewText:
This is a very unqiue game!

Wasteland 2 game play is much like I know from Jagged Alliance: Back in Action (love it, check it out!)  Although Wasteland offers you more character customization ad a great storyline that offer choices!  These Choices will affect the game a lot and are the most rewarding on completing the game. Besides that theres weapon customization (up to four upgrades per weapon depending)  a plethora of varied enemies.

After most games I play I uninstall them and move on to the next.  But with Wasteland I used my (automatically) saved character I finshed my first run with.  Very rewarding to continue (replay) the story with character you invested in and move into a course other that your first run.

I don't feel the need for scientific approach on how the game scores.  All games have pro's and cons. If you have a decent enough graphic card and rig you should experience a great looking game with intuative gameplay that takes you for a great ride.

It is a great game.

reviewText: I can't in good conscience recommend this game. Having played it from start to finish, I found the plot lazy, the game mechanics needlessly complicated/annoying, the characters one-dimensional, and the player's agency seemingly absent. Going against enemies with energy weapons? Better strip down to your undies! Find something that's locked? Better hope you have the correct out of SEVEN potential skills needed to open it (Safecracking, Lockpicking, Computer Science, Alarm Disarming, Brute Force, Demolitions, Toaster Repair (?)) at rank 10. Slaughtered every member of a militant cult? Nope, according to the game's post-script, they went on to slaughter everyone in the area because you didn't stop them! Buy Fallout 2 instead.

reviewText:
Video games critic “Yahtzee” once remarked that he didn’t understand single-player RPGs. What is the appeal? With their emphasis on story over gameplay, why not just read a (good) book? Why interrupt the (maybe good) story with some of gaming’s weakest gameplay?

Since then he’s likely discovered that there ARE good RPGs, and that good RPGs don’t emphasize story over gameplay; rather they emphasis both.

In fact, the only key difference between an “RPG” and, say, a shooter like Half-Life is that in an “RPG” the development of your avatars’ virtual skill is emphasized (via leveling up, getting more powerful items, etc.) over your muscle memory skills.

And here we have Wasteland 2, and like most old- AND new-school RPGs, it manages to emphasize neither gameplay nor story.

You may at first find this hard to notice if isometric (“old-school”) RPGs are new to you. Even I was smitten. So turned on was I that, a dozen hours into the game, I donated $30 to InExile’s Torment project (OOPS!), to be followed an hour later by Wasteland 2’s depressing emptiness finally crashing down on me (♥♥♥♥!!!). Its gameplay proved to be just drudgery. To get a picture of it, imagine XCOM, but not anywhere as good, and with the saving angel of “reloading the last save” always being available? Now consider that to play without the reload function would render the game impossible to win within a lifetime, OR SO easy (because you can change the difficulty at any time) that there’s hardly any drama at all. Now add to this an inventory system that demands so much of your “play” time (a time-destroying chore similar in fun to data entry, except you don’t get paid). Then throw in the various versions of locked doors and chests and whatnot that all have their own skill trees. I want to underscore the fact that this last feature is neither fun nor intellectually stimulating, and that you need to do it to win the game. If, InExile, you are going to make your players spend a lot of time deciding where to invest their skill points, then at least make the payoff’s worth it. Make it so there are AWESOME rewards for opening stuff—a cool joke, a sexy weapon or armor set that you won’t find from enemies or shops—not just , soon-to-be-forgotten items.

[There are also bugs, which, to their credit, they’re continuing to address.]

Now for some almost good news. The writing is almost good.

Because of the setting—a nuked one—they, like Bethesda, have gone the mostly-serious tone route. There are moments of cruelty in the game that invoke the horrors of real, demonic human beings, atrocities that happen in, say, Syria and the Congo. And sometimes it’s effective. For example, there’s a scene where a character died a horrible death, and as he or she lay dying, he or she told my party to deliver something to another character in some town. Well, I went to this town and got distracted.

And many hours later, across the Arizona map away from the town, I thought, “Oh ♥♥♥♥! I forgot to deliver that object!” And I trudged across the game world back towards that town, knowing that it would put me in boring battles with weaker enemies. That is a moment of video game art that taught me something about myself.

Moments like these are rare in the game, and the writing is mostly grim for no other reason than to remind players that nuclear holocausts are bad.

As for strong characters; I think the leader of the Desert Rangers is named General Vargas. There’s also the Matthias guy. Aaaaand those are all the names I remember from my 50+ hours of playing.

As for the plot, it’s an uninspired, boring cliché. To give you an idea of how zero it is, consider this. During the first half of the game, in the Ranger HQ, there’s this nuclear weapon in a museum. And when you press the wrong button, the place explodes and you get a Game Over screen that says, due to there being no Desert Rangers, Matthias and his Robot Army conquer the human race. In other words, InExile do not care about their own story enough to make a truly mysterious (or at least funny) enemy; this of course explains why the plot twists are so pathetically predictable that they basically don’t exist.

The NPCs talk a lot of “who is this Matthias person” emptiness, to which I respond, “OH C’MON, HE’S OBVIOUSLY A BORING ROBOT HITLER!”

[Robot Hitler, by the way, would be a more compelling, entertaining villain than Matthias.]

So if the intellectual bits are rare, and the characters are boring, and the plot is boring, then is it funny?

Nope. There’s at least one homage to a famous comedy. But basically that’s it. Visually they could have done many funny things—this is a 3D computer game, after all—but basically we got nothing. What missed opportunities…..To underscore how much these devs missed the mark, consider this: early in the game there’s a place you can opt to rescue from a giant flora infestation. What the developers could have done with this was pit your Rangers against, say, killer salads, aided by giant, banana-toting bananas. But what did InExile do? ZOMBIES! They made it so the plants infected the local fauna, turning them into zombies. Jesus Cliché Christ.

As for the graphics in general, it’s black, brown, green and grey. There’s some red for blood.

I do like the bullets flying and the body parts falling, especially when said body parts fall because someone hit the person with a blunt object. I also like some of the lasers. And the large robots look cool. Mostly I like the fact that you can dress your group like the Three Amigos. That was fun for twelve seconds.

The game also features sound.

SCORE: 3/10

Back of the Box Statement: “Is there too much happiness in your life?”

reviewText:
+ Branching quests with multiple viable solutions and diverse outcomes.
+ The choices you make affect the world in meaningful ways.
+ Tons of content with very little filler (unlike Dragon Age: Inquisition).
+ Solid writing.

- Assault rifles are OP and make every other weapon type seem comparatively useless.
- Combat doesn't have a lot of depth or variety.
- Game was pretty buggy at launch, particularly the late game (though this may be fixed by now).
- Graphics ain't too pretty.
- Some skills are overly specialized (like Toaster Repair and Blunt Force).
- It's easy to screw yourself over if you don't have a lot of experience with CRPGs.

Conclusion: If you enjoyed the first two Fallout games, you will likely enjoy Wasteland 2. If you didn't, you probably won't. Also, if you only care about combat and don't care about things like quest design or reactivity, you'll probably get bored.

reviewText: I could not agree more with the folks at IGN. This game is everything we were found of in the post-apocalyptic games of yore. I relish the story, complexity of the locations and people you interact with, and the discoveries you make based on the style of characters you play and the consequences of your actions, be they for better, or very much worse.\n\nI look forward to playing it through again, and hope in the future to see it expanded upon, refined further, and the engine given out to the community to create love letters to the wasteland with their own stories, and maybe even tribute games that never were 'quite' finished that could use the breath of life.

reviewText:
To start I might already mention it as many before, as a person who enjoyed a lot first 2 fallout games I do enyoj this game very much. Why?

1. It  has enjoyable and clear CHARACTER CREATION, you choose and make your crafted characters to fit a specific roles. If you like some theory  crafting then you will enyoj crafting your own core 4 characters, if not you can choose the presets. thought it is not as complicated as the ones in fallouts.
2. The actual COMBAT is more like the one in Xcom thought not as thight and combat orientated, still enjoyable with potential of some annoyances which comes of how the combat starts(I might have missed something) but as far I know combat starts when you hit enemy or when enemy spots you and attacks you unless you construct a character so it will always see enemy way before hi sees youand can realiably set up fights for your team. Also some unclearances about field of wiev if you use high cover. For some maybe combat would be slightly too boring, which has a higher chance of happening if you are playing on the easy difficulty.
3. The ingame GRAPHICS might not be as good as some might want them from 2014, it varies from place to place.
4. The interactable Characters, NARRATIVE, NPC dialogs, impact of chouses in quests and dialog choises is there, and creates great feel of emmersion.I havn't finished the game but as far I have goten to I would say that they have nailed everything about this section, even the voice acting that is there is very damn good(and I have to mention that in the old-school spirit most of dialogs are in text mode only) also the humor is pretty good.
5. Seems that they have fixed most of quest bugs during beta (havn't experienced any bugs this far).

TO SUM UP
If you love the RPG and general story side of these kind of games (like fallout games),
if you like tactical turn based combat with randomness aspect, if you like crafting characters (making your own roles) some theory crafting this is THE game for you.

reviewText:
Overall I would recommend this game.
BUT.
it severely lacks in my opinion good story and atmosphere. I never felt captivated by the story like I did coming write off of Shadowrun. The text also was so small and hard to read even with it set to large" I felt like it was more of a nuisance reading the bland material than it was worth especially when its on this typewriter styled display that does nothing to add to the game.
The gameplay itself was alright. Not the best turn based game I've ever played but I had a lot of fun with it even if it lacked actual options other than headshot and ambush which you cant even really use unless you stack your attributes for AP.
The guns were awesome! Even knowing a lot about guns in "reality" I had fun with them even if they had a lot of mistakes such as the SPAZ shotgun is actually an AA12 in your character's hands.

I really enjoy Fallout and this helped my Fallout4 anxiety a lot.

Random encounter maps are all boring and pretty much the same I think there was honestly like four different maps.

reviewText:
Let me tell you about Wasteland 2.

I was out on a mission after having managed to strike a truce with a potential enemy who'd already flattened my crew more than once. The guy who tried to land the Desert Rangers in trouble with them is scared for his life because I dobbed him in as the true culprit - even after he helped me put things right, even after I said I wouldn't. He runs off to get his scaly mates all wound up and ready to make trouble.

I think about it for a split second then headshot the stupid bugger. He can have his little hissyfit, but there's no way he's stuffing up this unexpected and welcome truce, Not while my sniper's rifle is loaded.

Then I realise the effect this game is having on me. I'm horrified with myself. I rationalise the decision: the guy was too dumb to live; he'd have only got more innocent people killed; he was trying to covertly start fights he couldn't finish; at least if I put him down like this the other mob wouldn't torture him to death or something. I'm even more horrified at the rationalisations. I wonder if the game even has an event path for what I just did. Would his friends jump me next time because of a bug, or did he need to actually make it back to his friends to trigger that situation? Would there still be a truce when I got back? Did I really take care of the problem?

The problem. Huh. That problem had a name. And friends. Possibly a family.

This game is getting me to play like an amoral hardcase for the first time ever (usually I do my best to be a good guy) - and I simultaneously love it and fear it for that. Not because it's fun but because everything is a moral grey area, every success has a bit of failure in it, and it's rare for everyone to make it out alive and unscathed.

10/10

reviewText:
To start I might already mention it as many before, as a person who enjoyed a lot first 2 fallout games I do enyoj this game very much. Why?

1. It  has enjoyable and clear CHARACTER CREATION, you choose and make your crafted characters to fit a specific roles. If you like some theory  crafting then you will enyoj crafting your own core 4 characters, if not you can choose the presets. thought it is not as complicated as the ones in fallouts.
2. The actual COMBAT is more like the one in Xcom thought not as thight and combat orientated, still enjoyable with potential of some annoyances which comes of how the combat starts(I might have missed something) but as far I know combat starts when you hit enemy or when enemy spots you and attacks you unless you construct a character so it will always see enemy way before hi sees youand can realiably set up fights for your team. Also some unclearances about field of wiev if you use high cover. For some maybe combat would be slightly too boring, which has a higher chance of happening if you are playing on the easy difficulty.
3. The ingame GRAPHICS might not be as good as some might want them from 2014, it varies from place to place.
4. The interactable Characters, NARRATIVE, NPC dialogs, impact of chouses in quests and dialog choises is there, and creates great feel of emmersion.I havn't finished the game but as far I have goten to I would say that they have nailed everything about this section, even the voice acting that is there is very damn good(and I have to mention that in the old-school spirit most of dialogs are in text mode only) also the humor is pretty good.
5. Seems that they have fixed most of quest bugs during beta (havn't experienced any bugs this far).

TO SUM UP
If you love the RPG and general story side of these kind of games (like fallout games),
if you like tactical turn based combat with randomness aspect, if you like crafting characters (making your own roles) some theory crafting this is THE game for you.

reviewText: This game in uninspiring and tedious even given the fact that I did not complete a fraction of the side quests.  The narrative and graphics are subpar and the game is only recommended for fans, or those with a high tolerance for reading lots of text and navigating poorly programmed inventory screens. There is alot of tedious inventory management in this game and I have played Fallout 1,2,3,NV.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a decent CRPG, Game is worth playing especially if you loved the old Fallout games and wish Van Buren was real.

The character creation is intimidating at first, but the manual will explain things. For the most part it avoids having any single attribute as a dump stat, although charisma and luck come close. The skill system could use some work. Three dialogue skills is two too many, and a lot of non-combat skills are just various ways to open loot crates, although there are several cases where high repair or demolitions are needed to progress in a quest. Strangely, your attributes only affect your derived stats - the majority of which are sadly hidden from you - but have no effect on your skills.

Combat is a huge part of this game, and while it is fun it's also rather simple. It uses a turn based system similar to Fallout, but you get control of each member of your party. There's an ambush attack similar to overwatch from XCOM which is pretty useful, but there aren't any aimed shots except for headshots, which are pretty boring. The weapons are seriously imbalanced, with assault rifles becoming really good about 1/3 of the way through, and godlike in the end-game.

The quest design is decent; there are a handful of major quests in both areas of the game that are pretty complex and fulfilling to solve but the majority of them are short and combat focused. The quests in the first half are more polished while the back half feels rushed and incomplete.

PROS
The game successfully incorporates tips and training pointers as you progress early on in the game. Rather than have to go through boring tutorials, you learn along the way.
Absolutely loving the Ambush option available when you encounter enemies. Makes for excellent strategy and placement and forces you to consider approaches for maximum benefits as you encounter enemies later on.
The Unity Engine is nice looking, with details in landscapes.
The game is realistic in that you need to be prepared to take on encounters by having clear lines of fire along with readied weapons. Shooting an enemy who's in front of another friend isn't a good idea...
A planned approach with players who have specific perks like lockpicking, etc are beyond valuable early on in the game.
The devs have a wicked sense of humour with very colourful language all-around in the game...


CONS
-When you are investigating in real-time an area, I find the map option lacking. There is no map function already built into your display. You can alternate to the map by pressing 'm' but I'd rather have it as part of the overall picture itself as you move your characters around.
-Some of the penalities associated with shooting are not realistic. I have one merc crouched while another one behind him is standing up firing with a rifle and he still manages to friendly fire the guy in front of him. Stupid, and the devs should have taken this into account.
-Some of the shooting mechanics are way off. I have a merc with a rifile crouched who cannot take a shot at an enemy who is diagonally across from me.
-The AP for rabbits is ridiculously overgenerous. They can scamper across half the screen and still carry out an attack.
-The enemy AI seems to have crazy high AP...
-No regional Pricing for India I need to wait for a year to buy at suitable price.

reviewText:
First off, I love this game.  I recomend it highly, it was worth my 60 dollars to play it in the early release it is definitely worth the 40 dollars it is now.   It has come a long way since the Early Access review that I did, so I am updating it now.

This game plays very much like Final Fantasy Tactics or Fallout Tactics (minus the real time option).  In it you will create 4 of your own Desert Rangers and then head out into the wastes and explore, and either clean up the wasteland or kill everyone and thing in your path.  Along the way you can recruit many extra characters to your cause, each with their own personality and traits, up to 3 may travel with you at any given time.

The difficulty of the game varies sharply depending on how you choose to play it.  Early on most enemies you fight will be much weaker than you are, however you are not forced to play the game in any linear fashion and as such you may wander into areas with much stronger enemies than you are prepared to face (not that you can't win but it can be brutal).

The ability to go where you want and do what you want flows throughout the entire game.  You can sweet talk people into giving you what you want, threaten them (with the proper skills) or if that fails shoot your way through.  Wall in your way?  Use a grenade.   Person make you mad?  Shoot him, or don't.  Raiders take over a town?  Negotiate or kill them it's all up to you and how you want to play.  Most choices have concequences further down the line, some amusing and some well down right destructive, even when you think you are making the right choices nothing is ever black and white.

You will collect all kinds of weapons and armor, and most weapons can be customized by stripping down others for base parts.  Everything from WW2 rifles to futuristic laser weapons are represented each with an optimal range, armor penetration and rates of fire.  In battle many of your enemies will show up with different kinds of weapons, often enough you can kill them an take it for yourself.  The various enemie types also force you to prioritize targets: Do you kill the big guy with the sword made out of the one way sign (yes, they really are swords made out of sign posts and one way signs) attacking your medic, or do you take out the guy who is still too far out to hit you but is charging with grenades that will hurt everyone?  Oh and friendly fire is a thing, don't try and use a shotgun from behind your own people.

Character progression is handled in an RPG like fashion with skill points gained at every level and ability points every 10.  You can be a generalst and do a bit of everything but nothing well or you can specialize each of your characters (highly reccomend you do) into different things.

I broke my basic team into:

a) Sniper / Lockpicks / submachine gun - gave me nice range and something when stuff got closer
b) Sniper / Perception / Kiss A** / Submachinegun - can see traps still shoot far and sweet talk
c) Heavy weapons / Safe Cracking / Assault Rifle - HMG to mow down eneies - rifle to consere ammo
d) Energy weapon / First Aid / Rifle / demolotions - can remove traps and is the field medic

Then I picked up and kept in my party a

e) A drunkard shotgun specialist whom I also turned into the groups weaponsmith (because drunks make the best weapons right?)
f) Lady scientist who can hack any computers and is handy with a pistol (and later rifles)
g) Young kid who's life I saved,  he started with brawling and ended with rifles pistols and the ability to talk to strange animals.

I built my team knowing that I would go to a specific place and pick up a particular npc.. how you create your team is entirely up to you and playing around with different builds is half the fun.

- Pros -

- Great turn based combat.
- Easy to understand mechanics
- Fun!
- Lots of humor built into the game
- So many different ways to resolve things in the game
- Ability to break your own missions through poor choices (and sometimes good ones) requiring some creative solutions to be used to move on.
- Solid strategies will win most fights.  Using cover, hitting clusters of enemies with a grenade etc.
- Ammo doesn't grow on trees, making conservation of rounds part of the strategy.
- All different kinds of weapons with all kinds of pros / cons built into them.
- Not all weapons are a straight forward upgrade, sometimes you just have to try them out.
- Each person can only carry so much weight, there is no way to be Rambo and run around with 1000's of rounds of ammo and infinite first aid kits.

- Cons -

- Did I really just wipe out an entire town on accident? Oops.
- Random battles can be major easy or completely overwhelming.  Luck plays a part.
- Bah stupid AI won't stop throwing grenades at my clustered people.
- Drunk bugger keeps going rogue on my party and getting himself shot to pieces.
- Some fights, more so early on can be extremely difficult to get through.  The first boss fight was really bad for me as my squad was almost dead and did not expect the guy to attack me since we were talking at first
- Ammo can be hard to come by in the early game, forcing you to either use weapons your team isn't skilled for or to spend all of your money on nothing but ammo instead of armor / weapon mods / first aid kits etc.

reviewText:
As I am not really experienced in writing reviews, but since I just completed the game, l would like to share my experience with others whom are still deciding to buy it or not. I am dividing it in several stages: Character Building, Storyline, Combat and Gear.

==
Character Building
==

I found it really challenging to build a team that would last me through the whole game, just because there are too many skills to choose from for only 4 characters of your team. I had to make a new game 3 times to find out that it's actually better to leave a couple of skills out, which you will find on other followers (even better progressed) later on in the game. - Rose for example has a really high computer skill and handgun skill.-  Apart from the skills I think there are limited but reasonably enough faces and clothing to choose from to make a pretty random team.

EDIT: After I made new game on highest difficulty, it came to my surprise that I could use me old rangers again, still having all the skills and abilities from my previous end-game. Knowing this I can reccomend new players to start and complete an easier difficulty and then use the same experienced (veteran) rangers on higher difficulty to make it easier! Changed my rating from 7/10 to 8.5 after knowing this.

Rating 8.5/10

==
Storyline
==

Depending on the choices you make, the storyline will change in many, many ways. Sometimes it doesn't turn out the way you want, and you can't do anything about it because of one of your previous choices. I quite liked this because it makes making choices more difficult and you will have to think ahead to make sure everything turns out ... o.k.

Dialogues are sometimes crazy long, and very tiring to read it all. You will be clicking a lot. Mind you, read carefully. Sometimes you will need information in order to make the right choice. Having an advanced speech skill will also come in handy to unlock several special dialogues which will help you get things easier.

The main story takes you and your team into the wasteland of Arizona to plant a couple of radio repeaters on several radio towers and re-establish broadcast range for your fellow rangers at the Citadel. During this mission you will stumble upon a lot of people whom need your help... or do they? You decide.
After going through a lot of trouble to get the radio going again, you will fly to Los Angeles, where you will have to clear the name of the Rangers and bring good to the people of LA. You will soon notice that you're not the only one trying to gain power in LA and find yourself in conflict with several organizations that will stop for nothing until they have it. Make the right choices to make the right alliances and save the world from extinction.

Rating 9/10

==
Combat
==

Combat is pretty much the same throughout the whole game.. this doesn't mean that it’s boring though. You will have a limited amount of action points per character, depending on your skills. Both moving and shooting will cost action points so use them wisely. Some combat phases can be really challenging because of the environment you're in. Gain advantage by seeking higher ground and make sure that you get a lot of cover, it will definitely save your life multiple times. A higher combat initiative allows your team to act more often in a battle and will surely come in handy when you fight 10 baddies at once.

Rating 6/10

==
Gear
==

You will be happy to know that you will be able to choose from a lot of weapon types to use. And you can even put modifications on them! A big variety of weapons and weaponmods allow you to create your own personal weapons of mass destruction. The only thing I found disappointing was that you will be using the same weapon for a long time until you proceed into a new area. They are also pretty expensive in the shop. Make sure that you make the right decision on bringing the guns you find with you, or turn them into scrap metal to sell.

There is also a lot of clothing to be found in the wasteland. You will stumble across the weirdest hats, shirts and pants which together make an even weirder outfit. Make sure you try everything on!

Rating 8/10

-------------------------------

So after having said all of this, I would very much like to recommend this game to people who like a game full of adventure, mystery and action with a lot of choices and plot twists. The overall rating of this game for me concludes:

7,9/10

A few extra tips:

* Save a lot!!
* Always reload before battle!!
* Stock up on ammo!!
* Take cover!!
* ENJOY!!

Mr. Grey*

I never got to finish the game, but I would still recommend it. Alas, it's has almost no replayability, due to the quests being quite limited and story line only going down one path. Still, it's fun. Would recommend for people who want to play an old Fallout style game.

reviewText:
This is my Jam! Honestly, once Director's cut dropped, and I started tweking different builds and installing custom potraits, I felt like a kid in a candy store. It was a lot of fun, the new traits system gives a lot of flexability to make cool stuff. Honestly haven't had this much fun with a game since I was seven. After the disappointement of Pillars, and the overrated stuff I kept buying, Wasteland 2 is the only saving grace in my library, and Alien: Isloation.

It's smooth, combat is tactical, characters have weight because of how varied you can go with skils/stats/traits, and you will need a guide to find out all the solutions to quest. Iv'e been through it four times and still have read about things I haven't done yet. This might be the only win for Isometric fans, after playing it going back to the old games is hard, due to being used to how smooth and quick things are in WL2. Except for maybe Divitiny Sin, but I haven't played it yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

May 1st 2014

59 hours on record, not 24.

I've been playing Wasteland 2 for a while now and figured I should write a review. I hardly ever write reviews but I feel that this game deserves it. When i first bought it (a week or two after release) the game was buggy to say the least. A bit boring during combat and the story was dry...

...then the patches started rolling out. The game became beautifully designed. The artwork is amazing, the combat feels solid and easy to use. The story feels like a true rpg. I'm getting to know my characters like I did in Fallout and Skyrim. I was really excited when this game hit Steam and I had high hopes. Still being in Beta and being apart of the process has been amazing. I have enjoyed every patch and have no complaints. I can wait to see what it's like once it's fully released.

If you have any doubts about not liking this game wait until full release, but if you want to buy it now and help the dev's create a game more to your liking this is the company to do it with. Thanks for reading!

Feel free to message me with questions about the game if you feel like getting the average player's more in depth review.

-Dantehood

reviewText:
Instead of telling you stories of what games that are similar to Wasteland or not, i'd simply tell you in short diary-form what you will encounter in your first 15 hours. Decide if that's your cup of tea or not.

(This is from the point of view of a late-adopter that waited until release (except some 20hrs sneak peak) to dive into this. I have not read any forums/guides/walkthroughs or whatever. No spoilers!)

- Read about all values/statistics and their interdependency. Think about what your group should be able to do
- Best group ever! Will rule the wastelands!
- First larger mission. Got stuck. Should have read the NPC-Dialogues. No pretty quest-pointer taking my hand. Ok, like in the old times now!
- Walk into a fight feeling like a boss. This group can't loose! Got my ♥♥♥(es) handed over some seconds later. Bad lizards! Half the group is wasted, no ammo left, no medipacks to heal.
- OK, Reload! No problem!
- Lose one dude more this time
- Start all over again. Thinking about lowering difficulty this time. Ego wins. If anyone would see that...
- Walk into the next fight. Prepared you are! Fighting skills maxed, you have! Such clever, much thought, wow!
- Survive the fight, come to the conclusion it was stupid to NOT have secondary skills too.
- Restart. Lowering difficulty to match my...skills...noone will ever know!
- Got a perfect group now! Everythings equalized. Should be efficient!
- Met a new groupmember. Cool. Made 4 of my chosen secondary skills redundant. Still some others missing. DAMN IT!
- Restart. FOR THE LAST TIME!
- Clearing everything of <SPOILER WOULD BE HERE>. Except that one door. Need a skill i haven't covered. DAMN IT!
- Should i restart? NO!
- Screw that door. Oh there's another door i cannot open. DAMN IT!
- Fights become controllable, i guess i start understanding. This is fun!
- A Bossfight. Dead in some seconds. I suck at tactical combat. Time to admit it.
- Finally did it. Piece of cake! Hard but doable with luck. I had luck.
- Open next door, critical failure. DAMN IT!
- Reload last savegame. DAMN IT! Before the boss. Forgot to save afterwards. DAMN IT!
- Died again.
- Time to write a devastating review! REVENGE!

Do i recommend it? YES! Though it's really not everyone's cup of tea and quite anachronistic. Is it worth it's full price right now? Considering such epic failures like, e.g. Archeage, that are selling for like €144,-. Yes it's worth these 50,-
Already put 15 hrs into it, and only scratched the surface i guess.

reviewText: This game is a little to hardcore and unforgiving.  Even on the lowest difficulty setting its easy to find your characters out of ammo and with no scrap to buy more.  I gave it the best attmpt I could before i grew tired of the turn mechanics that ultimately result in dead party members from low skills or lack of ammo and before anyone says use melee, that just results in seriously wounded characters that once again die from thier wounds.  Trust me even on the easiest setting its wasnt uncommon during my game play to have characters with only 46 hp crit for over 30 dmg in one hit by an enemy.  Id hate to see what the harder settings numbers look like.  If you want a turned based game with shooting and some melee thats a lot more fun then this play XCOM.  Its the same game but smoother and more enjoyable in my opinion.

reviewText:
Not being a fan of the original, I wasnt as excited by the prospect of a sequel as a lot of other people. However I am a fan of the genre and generally like RPGs of any type if they are well made so I thought Id give it a shot. This game IS well made, but thats about all its got going for it.

There is something about this game that just doesnt do it for me. Ive just played through Baulders Gate and Shadowrun Returns and compared to them, this game is flat and boring. I have no interest in the story line and the quests themselves are too dam long and boring. Theres no clear sense of what to do next and if you do things in the wrong order, you end up having to back track all over the joint.

Traveling the wasteland is a pain in the ♥♥♥. Requiring you to stop at these stupid oasis to replenish your water supply is unnessecary and adds to the boredom. I know it was part of the original game, but that doesnt make it a good idea.

Games that have voice acting are fantastic, it really adds to the atmosphere and gets you into the game. This game has voice actors, but they only some NPCs use it and only with what they first say. I understand the fact you cant give every NPC a voice sue to space constraints, but those that do speak should speak every line.

Im a bit mad at how much I actually paid for this game. If your thinking about getting it, wait till a sale when its like $5 or below. Otherwise your just wasting your money.

reviewText: TL;DR- This game is amazing as far as RPGs go. The tactical combat is challenging and rewarding. The storyline is solid and  cohesive. As someone who didn't play the original before I got it along with this game I feel that the devs did a great job at staying true to the original while making a wholly playable and engrossing sequel, paying homage to the players of the 1st game while not entirely alienating their new market. Simply one of the best role-playing games I have had the pleasure to play in the last decade.\n\nWasteland 2 made me feel like I was playing Fallout-Advanced Edition. Yes the post apocalyptic genre may be reaching its saturation point, but to pull it off with the style and flair that the devs did with this game is truly a feat that others should feel beholden to match in the future. Back in my day *takes a slug off of a clay jug marked XXX* players used their imaginations to fill in the holes that graphic and framerate left empty and Wasteland 2 managed to bridge that gap with nuance and gusto. I felt for my characters. I lovingly crafted their skills to conquor all that the wasteland had to throw at me. I was treated to inside jokes, 80's humor, and a difficulty that suited my playstyle (played on hard difficulty). If you're looking for a great tactical RPG, this is a sure bet. If you're looking for a storyline that will keep you playing to the end, start clicking the buy button now. Dim the lights. Crank the speakers. And sit down for a while and witness true RPG entertainment at it's best.
