reviewText:
I’ve only played the Original Wasteland game very briefly a long time ago, however I’ve spent countless hours playing the pre-Fallout 3 Fallout games on PC which were inspired by Wasteland. Now I’ve played Wasteland 2 for around 7 hours, it’s not a fast paced game, this has only been enough time for me to complete one of the first main missions.
- Overall I was very happy with the game, personally it was awesome to see a modern Fallout-like game with a traditional isometric view and detailed text descriptions of everything seen and done in the world.
- However I found that I spent way too much time having to loot one loot container after another as well as sometimes fighting identical enemies repeatedly.

http://youtu.be/DfGcRcBmcsQ
http://youtu.be/U4P28iQRIvQ
In the character creation the graphics aren’t very appealing. However when you actually play the game you don’t usually view things so closely.
-----Generally the actual graphics looked good in my opinion. But personally I’m satisfied as long as it’s a competent modern three-dimensional adaptation of Wasteland and an adequate improvement compared to the two-dimensional Fallout titles.
-----What I was really impressed by was actually the textual description of entities and objects in the game. They provided more interesting details about everything you see.
-----I also really liked the text dialogue that my companion expressed during combat rather than being mute. It really made the character seem more alive.
-----Most of the character models looked fine, especially humans who featured a lot of variety. But I really got tired of seeing the same unimpressive giant bunnies again and again.
-----There were also a couple of locations which I was not impressed by. One area was just a big empty square. While another fenced you into lanes which I don’t think fit well into a world that I believe should feel very open.
-----But I was really impressed by many of the other environments that I saw. I liked how you could rotate the view, this would reveal objects you couldn’t see previously.
-----Many environments looked handcrafted and irregularly shaped. I think this platform has a lot of potential even for other games with a fantasy theme.

I liked the character attributes and skill system. However the benefits of investing into some attributes didn’t seem worthwhile. Likewise investing in combat skills seemed to suffer from strong diminishing returns.
-----I set out to play this game in an unusual way. I didn’t want to micromanage a squad. So initially I took only one ranger. This didn’t work out so well initially.
-----So after playing for an hour I started over and I redesigned my starting character. This time I created a more intelligent character so that they could multi-skill and thus take on multiple roles.
-----Early on there is a high level character who you can recruit named ‘Angela Deth’, I took her along with me because going solo with a low level character is actually very difficult. So the game almost let me play the way I wanted to because I didn’t have to take a whole squad.
-----I don’t mind the turn based combat, but it’s one of the reasons the game is slow paced. I knows it’s more traditional. But I would have preferred a real time system where you could pause and redirect the action.
-----Occasionally my companion would go out of control in combat and make actions without me directing her. How do I make her do this all the time? I’d rather my NPC teammates were more autonomous. I don’t want to have to tell them to do every little thing.
-----Outside of combat for the first several hours that I played, I couldn’t move my characters individually for some reason. So I wasn’t able to rearrange my character before entering combat
-----This was a bit weird. I don’t know why this happened but eventually I was suddenly able to direct them individually.
-----In games like this I feel compelled to search every nook and cranny in a level for loot. Especially because you really need to do so in order to scrape up enough ammunition to fight and enough medical supplies to survive.
-----I know it’s a post apocalyptic game and scavenging may be the ‘thing’ to do. But I think I easily spent half of my seven hours of game-play looting and managing my characters’ inventories. That was tedious.
-----Why do I have to ransack the property of people who I am supposed to protect? How do my characters carry all those guns and where do they keep them, just to sell at a vendor?
-----I wish there was a better system for acquiring better gear. Perhaps credit towards an interchangeable load-out based on each characters rank and experience levels?

So yes, I definitely have my gripes about this game. But I was very happy to play it. This game proves that Fallout 3 didn’t have to make the shift to FPS. Not sure that I will have more time for Wasteland 2 though.
-----I’m happy that the price has come down. The previous $60 price tag was a major reason that I had not purchased this game quite some time ago.

Click here for my YouTube gaming channel

reviewText:
Un RPG old school, miam à première vue.
Bon c'est pas beau, normal l'argent est parti dans le système de jeu.
Bon le scénario est aussi original que dans un bouquin d'Arlequin, allez on va dire que c'est pour se focus sur le RP!
Bon le système de jeu est aussi original et varié qu'un Jagged Alliance, là je suis désolé je ne trouve plus d'excuses.

En gros, le jeu est moche, la direction artistique nous dégueule des couleurs dans des tons trop proches, l'univers est laid et ultra classique.
En gros, la partie RPG parait très dévelopée, wahou tant de compétences non reliées au combat! Du choix!
En fait non pas vraiment de choix, vous allez être fortement incités à prendre toutes les compétences réparties sur vos persos. Où est l'intérêt de faire des compétences si variées si au final on les monte toutes à 4/5 car tous les 2 mètres un coffre/mur/meuble va vous demander d'utiliser chacune des différentes skills de crochetage". Le résultat ne représente aucun intérêt.

Parlons-en du choix

reviewText:
So, if you take the term 'CRPG' really seriously and enjoy getting in fights about how modern RPGs aren't 'real' RPGs, and you wish it were still the late 1990s, this is a great game for you and you don't need to read the rest of my review.

On the other hand, if you enjoy isometric party-based RPGs but also might like to see some progress from the last 15 years or so of gaming history, Wasteland 2 is kind of a letdown precisely because of how stubbornly it emulates the UI fiddliness of Fallout 1/2.  Get ready to remember which party member owns a shovel, switch to them, activate the shovel item, and wait while a progress bar fills up, every time you want to dig something up.  And this isn't just shovels, it's *every specialized skill*.  You're not realistically going to put together a party with more than one girl or guy who knows Safecracking or some other random ♥♥♥♥, but the game will never let you just click on the safe and have the one Safecracker open it.

The maps suffer from a similar level of fiddliness.  You will have to memorize where in town that random questgiver is, or come back from a fetch quest to wander all over wondering where his shop is among a town of identical-looking dwellings.  No quest markers is fine, I don't think that the player should have telepathic knowledge of where stuff is ahead of time, but when you're looking to turn in quests (and the characters would already know where shopkeeper X is) it's just a hassle.  Isometric design also means that the level designers hide crates in places where you need to rotate the camera to find them ... which is fine, but after a while, it's not clever, it's just irritating to have to rotate the camera every time you enter a new room or potentially miss out on loot.

I could go on with examples of the weird sort of micromanagement that Wasteland 2 requires of the player (there are many more), but you get the point.

Bottom line, it feels like a game that came out in 2000, not 2014.  If you're fine with this, go ahead and get it (but you probably already did).  If you're not, and especially if you haven't played Fallout 1/2 to death, there's really no reason to play this instead of Fallout 1/2.

reviewText: How could a game with this much effort and thought and love put into it still kind of suck? I've been eagerly watching the development of this game for quite a while now. Upon finally playing it, I am sad to report that it is far inferior to any of the recent (or classic) Fallout games. Just like Wasteland 1. They can't quite seem to hit on a winning formula.\n\nYou command a squad of desert rangers as they try to stop Very Bad Things from happening, mostly by killing all kinds of things in turn-based combat. Your rangers have absolutely no personality, and are combat units with a portrait. You can recruit other wastelanders to you cause, and they do have personalities, but for some reason the developers made the recruitable characters absolutely awful in terms of statistics. Managing your team of fighters is a chore instead of a joy. The interface is awkward and clunky, with strangely reversed controls. Typically, left click is go there" and right click is "use/take/kill that"
date: but this is reversed in Wasteland 2 with no option to change it.\n\nIt all comes down to a statistical analysis of the utility of various statistics and skills
recommended: with a larger dose of probability-based gameplay. It reminds me of business school
hoursPlayed: and is just about as fun. I literally had to make an Excel spreadsheet to keep track of who was going to learn which skills. The developers of Wasteland may have been groundbreaking and inspired the Fallout series... but they've pretty clearly shown why Fallout was a cult classic and Wasteland was quickly forgotten."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After half-hour playing with the character creation and then a good solid 90 minutes of play I am impressed with the game so far and am very much enthusiastic about seeing the end product. The gameplay is very similar to Fallout Tactics and the Jagged Alliance games, which I reckon suit it immensely, and they have retained the feel of the original Wasteland with the grim tones and occasional quirky humor (gotta love using the Smart A$$ skill to befuddle a bunch of raiders in a certain set encounter which allowed me to pass by and set up an ambush ^_^) so that is scoring top marks with me.

The only downsides so far are the occasional bugs (for one, doing alt-tab to chat with a friend who asked how the game was resulted in a crash - ironic!) which one can easily forgive given that it's still in Beta; plenty of time to chase up those issues.

So in the end I'm giving it 8.5/10 and highly expectant of giving top marks for the final release.

Now time for me to dive back in and get to saving what's left of Arizona; it's a dirty job, but someone's gotta do it...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm fairly new to the whole Turned-based strategy game genre at which I only played Shadowrun Returns, XCOM, and Divinity: Original Sin and now Wasteland 2. So with my experience out of the way now I might as well get on with it!

Wasteland 2 has not been regretted at all for an early access purchase, as to where I will be spending a lot of my time playing this game when the game fully releases! I feel that a lot of gamers anymore lose interest into these games, because it's not action 24/7 but I would say that these games now have got my attention and this game has taken over my life so far!

Pros:
1.) The environment is very detailed where it doesn't look pixilated at all and from that shows the time it took the developers to give a great Post Apocalyptic experience.

2.) The variety of skills to master in at which can change a lot in the future of game play from Toaster Repair, to being a Kiss ♥♥♥ to survivors. These will keep you thinking on which will be best for each character and from that can alter what your character can do.

3.) Character creation is very generic as to any other RPG element, but there's nothing wrong with that at all! Create your own character and make him/her a minigun wielding badass! But if you're not comfortable with creating your own character (or squad), you have preloaded characters to choose from at which have their own specialties for you.

4.) The combat system in the game can be very tense and frustrating (in a good way)! Every combat you encounter has you looking for anyway to wipe out your enemies as fast as you can from breaking through their coverage, to flanking them with your sniper. Every battle is definitely tense from where a simple 80% or above chance to hit still will miss (most frustrating thing in the world!!!!).


Cons:
1.) A few minor glitches in the game which is common for a early access game, but some are still effective even though you reloaded the game before that glitch happened.

2.) For my perspective and for anyone else who isn't too familiar with Turned-based strategy games, I had to restart the game a couple times as to where I screwed up and once you screwed up, you might as well restart and fix your mistakes. It may not seem like a con for others, but to me it's kind of frustrating to be restarting this game just to get it right.


Verdict:

I highly recommend this game for when it comes out, or even if you would like to play it right before it comes out! As for anyone who is considering buying the game full price, I would say that you wouldn't be disappointed in this purchase and would be looking forward to more hours of this game!

reviewText:
RELEASE VERSION UPDATE: Initial beta/backers review found after.

This is it. This is the big one. For many people, this is one of the most anticipated games of the year - the great inspiration for Fallout, the driver of classic RPGs, the callback to a genre slowly reviving. One of the first big huge Kickstarted games. After two years in development, how does it hold up? Spoilers: it holds up damn well.

Wasteland 2 is a classic RPG in the style of Fallout 1, 2, and Tactics. In fact, the original Wasteland was the inspiration for the Fallout universe, and shares many similarities and concepts with Wasteland. You take control of four fresh-faced Ranger recruits, sent out on a task to make yourselves worthy of your badges. What ends up happening is a journey across Arizona, and then some.

The game starts off with character creation. You can choose to create your own Ranger from scratch, or pick a pre-made Ranger from a list. The pre-made characters are alright, but for most people, you'll want to make your own customized Rangers. You can distribute attribute and skillpoints as you see fit, change your Ranger's physical appearance, and even stick in his/her own little bio and a custom portrait.

After setting yourself up, you end up in the Arizona wasteland, right outside Ranger Citadel. You are greeted by General Vargas, a veteran Ranger and an old character from Wasteland.  Another Ranger vet, Ace, has just died in action, and you and your team are sent out to investigate his murder and finish his mission as a trial. Succeed, and you all become official Rangers.

At first glance, one can immediately note the biggest downside to the game - graphical fidelity. While I personally feel that the graphics do not detract from the game, and in fact works to further the atmosphere it sets about creating, it is easy to see that the game is not about the shinies. Its easily trumped by Divinity: Original Sin in terms of fidelity, but that is not to say the game looks bad. It is simply objectively dated, even for a Unity-based game. Performance also leaves something to be desired - on a GTX 765M, the game hovers at about 40-50fps, sometimes dipping below to 30. Whilst expected for a new release, it certainly does not look like it should be choking up a moderately good mobile GPU as far as it is.  However, the graphical style the game takes is very immersive - you have varying environs, from lush greens to barren browns, and everything in between. The wasteland feels desolate and real.

Wasteland 2 is set in an isometric, top-down view. You control your Rangers overhead, order them around by clicking in the world. There are two world types - the main world, showing you Arizona and the rest of the area, where you go around between smaller local maps, looking for oases for water, and avoiding rad clouds, then the local maps, which is where you explore, do missions, talk to people, shoot people, all that good stuff. Combat is turn based, engaging when you run into hostiles or turn other people hostile by shooting at them/having a negative interaction. Characters take turns in commiting actions, with each action costing certain Action Points to do. Your characters can use a slew of weapons, from going in fisticuffs, to heavy armanents such as bazookas and heavy MGs, all of which can be skilled up. Positioning is key, with certain weapons being effective at certain ranges, and cover helping you avoid damage. Damaged Rangers can only be healed up with medkits, pain pills, and trauma kits if they bleed out. There is no idle healing, which means every fight has to be planned, and you have to have enough supplies to last.

Overall, I feel that Wasteland 2 offers a refreshing jump back into cRPGs, bringing the spirit of post-apocalyptic games from the past well into the 21st century. If you love turn based games, old RPGs, post-apocalypse settings, then you'll love (or absolutely hate - in a good way!) Wasteland 2. Give it a try.

_________________________________________________________________________________

Wasteland 2: One of the first gigantic projects on Kickstarter, the revival of an era, the granddaddy of Fallout, the great leap back for inXile.

Is it any good (so far?) The short answer:  yes, yes it is.

Wasteland 2 is one of the biggest, most high profile projects funded through Kickstarter – indeed, funding for the game came after Double Fine Adventure’s own successful Kickstarter. The game raised roughly 3,000,000USD, well exceeding its goal of 900,000USD.

The game follows up on Wasteland, which was the basis for many elements in the Fallout series. Many elements seen in Fallout can be seen here – radioactive wasteland, Rangers building up a civilized society, raiders, tech-fanatics, militant religious fanatics are all present in the game, clearly showing how much it influenced other games later on.

Gameplay is very much Fallout like as well. You explore the world with your party, with the world map being just that – a map that you navigate your party blimp through. Movement is dependent upon your water supply – you lose water, you die. Thankfully, there are hidden oases all over the map, giving enough opportunities to refill water to quench one’s wanderlust. In local areas, one goes about with the whole party, with your selected member doing the interactions. Conversations follow a keyword system – anything you observe in the environment might pop up as a keyword for characters in the locale, while some words in conversations can lead to further inquiries as well. Some conversation options require certain skills to be at a certain level, and can lead to clearing certain obstacles in a peaceful manner. Combat is turn based, following an AP system similar to, again, Fallout. On this, I cannot say much – I’ve only played less than two hours, and so far, the early mobs were easy enough to wipe without having to worry about cover and positioning. Even then, I did take a noteable amount of damage, and would probably lose my party members if I continued to do so.

Wasteland 2 runs on Unity – so far, in this current beta build, there are no graphical options to speak of, besides resolution and an overall graphics preset. Setting it to Fantastic with an i7-4700MQ and GTX 765M, the game looks fantastic – it pushes Unity to the edge. However, this being a beta, performance is not spectacular – fully zoomed out, FRAPS was showing around 24fps to a max of 30fps, which is barely passable. Dropping presets down to standard did not help performance, so I am assuming this is a “beta is beta” issue, and will be patched before the actual launch.

Is Wasteland 2 worth your time right now for 60USD? I would say, yes – if you can get past the beta-ness of it (you’ll have to download and print the reference sheet as there isn’t much of a tutorial in game), it is a good sign of the return of cRPGs and TBS games with rich narrative and an open approach to quests. While it wouldn’t hurt to wait, if you’ve been on the fence on it and can’t wait, it’s a solid game beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For what I've played of it, I'm pretty impressed!  Combat is interesting and tactical, the VO and dialog are spot on, and you have to use your skills intelligently in the world.  For example, you need to actually choose to USE your tech skill on the broken what's-it, there is normally no dialog telling you what to do.  I'm also really happy the see the game feature a 4 person party where you can custom create every character...I made the A-Team lol :)!

Now if you are on the fence about buying this in its early access phase, I would say...

If you are really passionate about old school RPGs and you want to show your support monetarily, go for it.  I have faith this will be a good game, and I am happy for any support that this game gets.

However, if you are just looking to play a great RPG...wait until release.  The game is definitely incomplete, and if you play through what's available now, you are kind of spoiling the experience for yourself by playing the roughest version it will ever be.

reviewText:
*sigh* Another day, another crushing disappointment.

So look, the combat is uninspired and boring. Now, it isn't bad because the options are limited, it's bad because it's design is so shallow abd the tactical options are so very few. Fundamentally combat boils down to two options: Click on target to attack or run away, not exactly deep or engaging stuff.

The story is reasonably good, at least from what i've seen, but the dialogue therein emits the overwhemingly pungent aroma of particularly strong cheese.

Graphically the game doesn't look too much of an improvement over fallout 2, indeed the low poly character models are just all kinds of wrong in a game being released in this day and age. Some might give Wasteland a pass for being an old school game, i'm not one of them, whilst I agree that graphics aren't everything, when you're trying to create a game like this, atmosphere and immersion are fundamental, having my eyeballed flicked every few minutes by those low res, low poly models and the peculiar animations does not lend well to the mise en scene when it comes to creating a convincing narrative. The graphical fidelity is something that struck me almost straight away and remains the elephant in the room the entire time, it's incredibly jarring and blows away immersion from the outset, the lack of atmosphere in the game is truly disappointing considering it's a game that would have benefitted exponentially from some sense of environmental depth of scene. The other aspect of this is that the animations are so poor. The way people hurry about is deeply unnatural, and indeed combat animations are every bit as unconvincing. This all adds to the game's lack of depth and continually smashes any sense of immersion to pieces.

There's a whole raft of smaller things that bug me too, for instance, the lack of a day/night cycle, which even the original Baldur's Gate had, which could have added a much needed layer of depth to that chronically boring combat - creatures that only come out at night, reduced visibility, the need for different tactics at different times of night. That's just one example of the smaller things, and before anyone dons their majestic white armour and starts foaming at the mouth, consider this: The investment level was huge so far as crpg games go, so why exactly does the gameplay feel so shallow? You cannot honestly tell me it all went into the sparce voice acting or the fmv sequences, and it's abundantly clear that it didn't go into the engine, so what gives? Where did the money go?

Still, all told, by far my biggest gripe is how low rent the game looks and plays.

Fargo set out to make an old school game, and whilst he has achieved that, unfortunately, I suspect in literally doing so, he has failed to take full advantage of modern technology and game design techniques. Like so many dinosaurs of the industry, it seems he too has failed to adapt, just because you're making your vision does not mean that you should shun the good that has come from the advances in both technology and the games industry at large. What irks most is that this was a game with a £3m development budget, for a crpg it should have been absolutely jawdropping with an investment like that. That, above all else, is what makes Wasteland singularly disappointing, and also raises some rather pointed questions about just where the hell that £3m went, because it sure as ♥♥♥♥ doesn't look or feel like it went into the game itself in any truly meaningful way.

Larian came out of left field with an absolute stunner of a game this year with Divinity, maybe i've just been spoilt by it and can't look at Wasteland in the same light when you hold the two side by side, but to be honest, when you look at what Larian achieved with a budget a fraction of the size of Wasteland, I can't help but feel that Briand Fargo, for all his good intentions, was taking the ♥♥♥♥ when he released Wasteland into the wild. Divinity is now far and away the market leader in the crpg market, and not because of a huge budget, because the guys and girls at Larian had the kind of vision and sense to use what they have available to them to the absolute best of their ability. I can't help but feel that not only was development time on Wasteland squandered, but also kneecapped by Fargo's single minded determination to make something 'old school'.

the tl;dr boils down to this: if you're a fan of Wasteland 1 or the original Fallout games, and can look past a distinctly shoddy game engine, then you might find something to like here. Otherwise, wait for a very significant sale, or just take a pass altogether and play Divinity or Xcom instead, both are vastly superior alternatives that do what they do a good deal better than Wasteland ever can, or I suspect, ever will.

reviewText:
Let all comparisons to Fallout 1 and/or 2 be retroactively rendered null and void with the same nullification applied to all comparisons henceforth. Simply put: if you are looking for an experience like the original Fallouts, keep looking. This isn't any fraction as good as either of them because it simply isn't good at all.

I can forgive an ENORMOUS quantity of technical faults. Bugs, bland combat, and graphics that were obsolete 10 years ago simply don't phase me if the less tangible aspects of a game are exceptional. These aspects include, in order: writing, character interaction, and world interaction/immersion (coherence, reactivity and a sense of player agency). Fallout 1 and 2 had these in spades and although no game can touch Planescape: Torment's character interaction, I at least never felt like I was running around with faceless, generic AIs for companions.

I should've known by the fact that you create an entire party (versus one player character who represents you) that the most meaningful and elusive elements of an RPG would be missing (the feeling that you're a participant in a world). The difference between Fallout and Wasteland 2 is like the difference between Baldur's Gate 2 and Icewind Dale...except Icewind Dale advertised itself correctly and successfully executed the thing it was trying to do/be.

I don't know if it was laziness or simply a lack of skill that produced this heap of a plot, but it feels like it could be either and/or both. At around the 12 hour mark, I hear the radio transmission about becoming immortal, invulnerable, disease free and beautiful...Combined with the mysterious robotic/synthetic threat, the 'faction' known as Children of the Cathedral and the basic ability to put 2 and 2 together, I deduced that the plot was something to do with turning people into robots. Not unlike Fallout 1's Children of the Cathedral being a front for the Master seeking to turn people into mutants who are long-lived, disease free, stronger, faster, better, whatever. That's so much not unlike it, that it's EXACTLY like it. You can't even call that an homage...because homage doesn't mean 'blatant ripoff'.

And the writing that everyone is showering in praise? Here's a stool - I mean writing - sample from Wasteland 2: A lone road stretches on. A dry wind whips at your back with the sandy shards from decades of lost hopes and dreams." That's the line of text you get on entering The Prison...which is a former prison now occupied by raiders. So not only is there no visible/audible wind/swirls/eddies/gusts
date: the other half of the description is hard to connect to a place that housed criminals in the past and present. I'm not sure that I care about the hopes and dreams of murderers...and unwarranted melodrama aside
recommended: it's just too lengthy and hard to read...the second sentence should've been broken up into two. Compare this with a description from Fallout 2: "Before you stands Hakunin
hoursPlayed: the village shaman. He appraises you with his crazy eyes from somewhere in the world only he inhabits." Not only is that less cumbersome/awkward to read
voteText: when you actually see and speak to Hakunin

reviewText:
Colossally overrated.
-Most skills are just keys to open up different kinds of boxes
-The game is a tunnel with only one way forward. You need all the skills to open all the boxes along the way, and that's it.
-Sometimes, but not often enough to matter much, the tunnel branches for a moment before it merges again.
-Characters are simplified and have personalities as thin as cardboard. You'll find more character depth in most FPS titles than this.
-The animations are unfinished and lazy.
-Combat looks and feels as real and visceral as your average MMO title.
-There's a lot of dialogue, but very little of it is meaningful in any way. You just click through it all and move forward in the tunnel.
-In fallout 2, playing a character with vastly differing stats changed the entire game experience and modified the plot. Here it changes your action point amounts and HP.

In short: This is not the worst game out there, but if you want to play your next fallout 2, keep waiting. It isn't here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game so far, don't let the indie adjective fool you. It is well polished, designed and executed and does not feel like a basement/garage made game at all. Character creation and customization is everything you'd hope for, for a Fallout-esque game. The combat is interesting and dynamic, feeling much like the original Fallout series and Xcom series. I don't usually shell out such positive reviews, but this one deserves it.

I've played a lot of other games on 'early access' that were 'indie' and this one easily surpasses all of the others I've tried. Give it a go, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
This is an adequate game. When I had a lot of free time, I didn't mind investing a few tens of hours to appreciate W2's strong points. Now that I have less time for gaming, there are enough better games that I won't play Wasteland 2 again (although I'll probably reinstall to look at the Game of the Year version).

In this review, I'll compare it to X-COM: Enemy Unknown and Skyrim, which seem like natural comparisons for different aspects of Wasteland 2. (I assume Fallout 3 is a more natural comparison, but I never played it.)

Good parts
Weaponsmithing: Interesting and fun. Deeper than the smithing system in Skyrim but easier to understand.

Roaming freely: Exploring in W2 isn't as rewarding as Skyrim, but the hybrid turn-based system combined with exploring makes Wasteland 2 feel, if not bigger, at least freer than X-COM: EU.

NPCs: Several but not all NPCs are well-written. NPC interactions add something that wasn't in X-COM: EU, but they're not at the level of Skyrim.

Bad parts
Lack of tension in combat: X-COM: EU's well-designed maps and the soldiers' vurnerability made combat a taut, exciting chess match. In Wasteland 2, the lack of cover, friendly fire (by itself a great addition), and soldiers durability (on seasoned difficulty), made combat an exercise in lining up American Revolution-style and rolling your dice against the enemy. On seasoned difficulty, my soldiers never went down except to friendly fire. Ranger difficulty made combat more difficult, but the outcome of combat never felt like the result of skill or strategy.

Mediocre writing: For me, the writing was good enough to made up for the uninteresting combat through the end of the Arizona section. The Rail Nomad camp and Happy Valley set up interesting scenarios. However, the narrative lost momentum after the start of the California section. When the game essentially copy-pasted the Rail Nomad scenario for another level, I lost interest.

Skills: More than half of the skills feel like they were added to pad the game and provide a sink for skill points. For example, Skyrim had one skill for picking locks. Wasteland 2 has 5 or 6 skills that serve exactly the same function. What's the difference between lock picking, toaster repair, and brute force? Nothing. Skyrim's two melee combat skills are fundamentally different and highly customizable. Wasteland 2 has 3 melee combat skills that all work exactly the same. Skyrim had one speech skill. Wasteland 2 has 3 speech skills that all work exactly the same. Skyrim has two healing skills (restoration and alchemy) that could not be more functionally different. W2's two healing skills are almost exactly the same (although some of the status effect descriptions are funny). At least half of the skills in Wasteland 2 are unnecessary clones of other skills.

Overall, Wasteland 2 has some strong points that are overwhelmed by it's weaknesses.

reviewText:
I so want to like this game... The story is nice, the writing is good, but the combat is awful. The gameplay is dated, maybe it can appeal to retro gamers or people who mistake boring mechanics with hardcore. There is a lot of boring combats, which is slow and crappy.
The hard consequences that the game touted are...subpar so far. Fallout New Vegas felt more alive and your actions had more weight than here.
To talk in details about the combat system, think fallout without any combat options (no called shots) and moronic AI. You just trade blows with hard-hitting melee sprinters or eagle eyed ranged NPCs that suffer from a preference to eat lead by leaving cover if someone is next to them. It's turn based, but with no tactics (you could call the cover system tactical if you were very nice) and as such it ends up being slow.
The character creation system is poor and having no perks and lackluster attributes leave not so much to the imagination. The skills are varied and made necessary if you don't want to trudge throught the combats.
The dialogues are sometimes a tad strange and you end up with some stereotypical NPCs. They try to put a veneer of gray on your choices with cynicism and realism"

reviewText:
I'm a die hard Fallout and Wasteland fan. While Fallout 1, 2 (which i consider being the greatest game in history of mankind) and even Tactics and where great games, Fallout 3 and New Vegas where FPS abominations, now worthy of Fallout name. So i've waited and waited for a true Fallout successor. Then i've got Wasteland 2. Am i disappointed? Hell no!
Wasteland was father of Fallouts and Brian Fargo was father of both. You can feel his touch in every aspect of Wasteland 2. From wonderful post-apocalyptic setting, through deep development of Your characters, interesting quests and NPCs... ending with what made Fallouts such great - adult, dark humour and morally grey world, which You can shape as You want.

TL:DR - forget about Fallout 3 and New Vegas. Wasteland 2 is the true successor of old Fallouts. While in terms of gameplay it feels more like Tactics, all in all it's a wonderful and complex RPG, in which You'll spend tons of hours playing. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a party based RPG set in a post nuclear war USA. The player controls a squad of Desert Rangers, whose mission is to protect civilians and maintain law and order, but now an army of robots want to wipe out Humanity, and its up to the Rangers to stop them. I never played the original Wasteland, but I'm a massive fan of RPGs, and I certainly found alot to enjoy in this game.

Combat is turn based on a square grid, with each action such as moving, firing, reloading and healing costing ability points, similar to Xcom or Shadowrun. Its very tactical, and you also have to pay attention to factors like cover, line of sight, weapon range and friendly fire. The maximum party size is seven, four of which are created by the player, and the others have to be recruited as you progress through quests.

There is a wide variety of abilities to put points into when levelling up. You can use several different types of guns and melee weapons, but also non-combat skills including lockpicking, safecracking, computer hacking, trap disarming, machinery repair and more. These skills are very useful because many quests can be completed in multiple ways, by finding alternate routes to enter a building or unlocking extra dialogue options.

The story is really good and there are lots of interesting characters and groups. From drug gangs to slavers and religious fanatics, there's always somebody more crazy in the next town. Many quests involve a conflict between two or more factions and the player has freedom to choose who to support, but you'll rarely find an obvious good guys" faction

reviewText:
This game is XCOM meets Fallout. It has the dark humour and post-apocalyptic setting of the Fallout series, with the punishing, perma-death combat of the XCOM series.

The graphics aren't amazing, but they're adequate for the game style. The music is atmospheric, the writing is fun, and the voice acting is hit-or-miss.

The gameplay is great for people who like this sort of turn-based squad combat. All the usual elements are here: objects in the environment provide cover, hits are percent-based, and actions cost AP to execute, which replenishes each turn.

My only real complaint is the navigation on the overworld map, which seems like a cop-out from making an interesting overworld. Whenever you aren't in an encounter area (random encounter, dungeon, town), your party is represented as a marker on a huge map of the American Southwest, which will slowly move toward your destination in the way Indiana Jones travels-- a line drawn on the map.

It's fun to create characters, and the combat is challenging but rewarding.

Well worth the purchase price.

reviewText:
First up, I thoroughly recommend this game.  It's an old school isometric RPG, and it's excellent.

It has it's flaws, but overall they don't undermine the experience, the worst I could say about this game is that there are some balance issues, and there are elements of the game that feel rough and unfinished.

I think it suffers from kickstarter-itis .. where a developer seeks a budget on the KS platform, achieves or exceeds it, then works to that budget.  Back in the day, a company would outlay their own capital and not make money until the product was released, now kickstarter covers development and profit goes into someone's bank account.

The problem with this (understandable) model is that there's not a lot of room for stretch and polish.  You either wildly exceed the kickstarter or you don't - and if you do, let's face it, there's probably a bit more of a 'loose' approach with project management and a higher budget for chicken chow mein.

I think there are functional elements of the game that should have been deeper, and there are story-telling elements that fell onto the 'nice to have but not essential' list and got cut.

Incidentally, I haven't finished the game yet, I'm about 75% through (I think).

Here's my view on the Good/Bad

Good:
- graphics and theme are nice
- world map and random encounters makes you feel 'there'
- radio chatter from different factions is immersive
- background lore (the rangers, their character, their personalities) .. all good
- combat: for the most part is satisfying and tactical
- story: although contrived in places, overall the storytelling pulls you in and holds your interest
- conversations and character writing is good for the most part (but also a missed opportunity)

Bad:
- weapon balance has some very bad decisions, energy weapons in particular range from OP in some situations to useless in others.  I say balance, but I don't really care too much about balance, what bothers me is some of the weapons are balanced is .. well, not logical and doesn't fit into a consistent and realistic universe
- Skills & Attributes: for me a real missed opportunity, they disconnect.  Example, Charisma doesnt effect conversations.  Seriously.  There's no randomness or discreet skill impact on conversations, just gatekeeper skills hardarse/intimidation, smartarse/logic, kissarse/charm .. and those skills are just numbers.  Likewise the balance of stats and skills is not really intuitive and clever in it's design, I guess in a way the game suffers from being compared to Fallout 2 in that regard.
- Contrived/Illogical writing:  there are some key points where the writing is a bit .. contrived.  No matter what you do, it's pre-ordained that the outcome will lead you from A->B->C, doesnt matter if you're evil or good.  If I were to analogise with pen&paper roleplaying, it's basically having a GM who can't 'think on their feet' .. the underarching story should be invisible, it should feel like you have total freedom and YOU (the player) are calling the shots .. instead, there are a few key points in the story writing where you feel more than a bit led by the nose (worse, there are some points where you only have a couple of options and those options don't allow for wide variations in character, one specific example you have 3 options to respond to a challenge from your CO, and each of them forces you to lie.


Overall, I give the game a solid 8.5 / 10 golden jabberoos.

reviewText:
I am happy to say that this was probably the best game I purchased off of STEAM for the entire year.

PROS:
~Super rich detail in everything.
~Maps are huge.
~Ability to create your own 4 person squad from the get go.
~The ability to have a max of seven people in your party! How awesome is that!?
~Lots of guns.
~You can set up ambushes/surprise attacks. Also, attacking from higher ground and behind cover equals PWNAGE! I've even had enemies throw grenades at me from low ground only to have them hit something and hit their allies instead. Awesomeness for sure!
~Every single skill is usable unless you don't want to. And that simply makes some aspects of the game much harder.


CONS:
The game is extremely well done, and the only issues I could possibly have with it are not being able to zoom in on the map display, which can make missing parts of maps an easy thing to do, leaving you wandering back and forth until you get frustrated. Then again, I may not have noticed where I was supposed to go. Either way, it's an extremely minor thing, especially when the maps for most places are quite huge, many consisting of other areas you have to travel to in order to search the area fully. The other thing I would have liked is voice acting for everything. But I suppose I am spoiled like many others these days, where pretty much every game out now has voice acting throughout.
Overall, two little things that don't deter from my experience whatsoever.

reviewText:
Positive sides
Really good old school Fallout 2 like RPG
Exceptional attention to details.
Your actions actually have impact on the world and the world reacts to them one way or another.

Pretty stable technically
Negative sides
Graphically it is slightly above Fallout 2 (although it is funny to see a man cut in half by a fist)
Not a big selection of weapons and armors
Conclusion
Considering the price of the game and the ammount of time you are going to spent with it is definetly worth it. I took my over 120 hours to dig up every hole and secret in the game (even those on Redondo beach)

reviewText: Wasteland 2 brings a unique style to RPG games. Giving off a fallout type of vide through out the whole game had amazing easter eggs to find and tons of interesting dialog. The combat was great and simple, Despite the minor bugs involving the camera glitching out durring combat but fixing itself after the next turn. Wasteland 2 state that there is 80+ hours.\nThis may be true for some, yet for me it left me wanting more after finishing the game in under 60 hours. (All quests, side quests, locations, caches, characters, easter eggs, and pretty much everything was achived with a amazing immersive experience.-For me at least in under 60 hours) All and All wasteland 2 brings back the nostalga of the original wasteland and orginal fallouts. I would have to recommend this to everyone that loves the first wasteland and the fallout franchise. Although i would say i was abit annoyed by the fact it isn't open ended in terms of being able to continue to play and explore after the ending credits. I cannot however recommend this at its current pricing. the amount of content is great yet still is lacking in key areas. Best to wait for sales unless its a must have right now.

reviewText:
Alright i'll get right to the point,  this game has numerous technical issues and often requires outside help as there is very little explanation for most missions. My only wish for this game was that the world was 'more open' and that the last 10-15% of the game felt rushed. Now that the criticism is out of the way heres what you will like.

The meat of the gameplay is the RTS [duh] which is slick, and relatively smooth but often forces the player to watch all enemy moves [forces the camera to lock onto each hostile unit] but that is a small setback. The weapons and wearable cloths look great, with a fair amount of customization [not great but decent]. The combat is fun, and challenging and for loot hoarders such as myself there is ALWAYS something to loot, scavenge, and steal. The diologue system is great, but requires characters to upgrade non combat skills which can be frusterating for some, but offer rewarding new story archs for the player to follow which are otherwise impossible. I highly recommend creating you're own ranger or two [remember to specialize them in something] and create a backstory for them - makes you feel invested in the game and makes the player care who lives and who dies.

However anyone with a heart can tell this game is a love letter to the fans who have been waiting for decades to indulge themselves within the wasteland universe. As with most love letters they at times try to hard, and on occassion written in haste. This is evident in some parts of the game [specifically late game]; despite this the effort and excruciating detail that went it to this game shows how much InXile wanted to make this game for others and for themselves. The story is great, the side quests have meaning and concequences with numerous outcomes all expressed in the epilogue which most will be more than satisfied with the thorough and satisfying ending; which leaves just enough loose ends to imply a wasteland 3 could see the light of day in the near future [ I hope anyway]. This is one of those games where I want to scream at the developers to take my money to support the game with new content [full expansions preferably] hoping containing a new area  map to explore.

The epilogue this game provides will take a modest 5 minutes to read, and it manages to wrap this game up in a satisfying way. I'm a major gamer having thousands of hours on steam alone [doesnt even count for my console based games] and I can't say I havn't been as satisfied with an ending in years, I'd say the ending is similar to dragon age inquisition neatly wrapping up everything.

reviewText: I can see this as the type of game that if I had more time I could lose over 200 hours in it and still have things to do (like fallout 2)  The first part of the game is rather slow, but the second half is really quite quick and extremly enjoyable.  As with some kickstarter/small studio games there are some quirks, such as the ending scenematic and some odd crashes, but for me this doesn't take away from a very enjoyable game.\n\nA lot of people compare this game to Divinity, and I really don't think there is a contest.  This game is markedly better in most regards, but I do like both games.  The main difference is that Divinity has harder combat and more tactical combat, but doesn't have a very deep plot and has parts that are time sucks for the sake of being time sucks and just call it being difficult.  I like both games, but Wasteland 2 offers what Divinty doesn't, more polish, more depth, more plot, and frankly it is pretty funny.

reviewText:
Played 31 hours in 3 days. 10 hours in to first play through decided I didnt like my setup Main menu'ed and New game.  The Game is amazing the Character creation can take an hour or more trying to fit all the skills your want in to 4 characters you quickly learn you cant have what you want, time to pick what you think you'll need.

While I see alot of comparing it to Fallout 1&2 no one mentions how close the game is to Fallout tactics the combat is almost a clone.  Fallout tactics was also a squad based game with the same Map system for travel.

All in all I love the game, Best $40 I have spent this year the replay value is high and it makes me feel like I was a teen again, Playing Fallout on a computer that could barely run doom.

( Edit ) Having Completed the game I feel I should fill out the reveiw Some more.  First The Battle system does get a little bit boring shall I say? but its to be expected in a battle System of Turn Based and Guns in the end you know what is going to happen you'll hit that wall for every shot hits. The AI does tend to simply Rush at you rather than use cover but again to be expected from this type of game ( Fallouts where all the same )  But the story and the choices you make unlike normal RPG they carry a certain weight too them which after the first one or two you make and you realise this you start to question your actions, what to say to the NPC's what the out come might be and how to push it the way you want.

All in All I loved the game it felt Fleshed out and complete to me, I did not see any of the bugs the others have added to their reviews infact the only issue I did was that the Camera locked at one point and I had to Alt + Tab to fix it.  I will Play again, many times. I feel that if you want a game where choices do matter and who you Shoot changes the game this is the game for you.  I look forward to some DLC too.

10/10

reviewText:
While I missed the original Wasteland I got to play every game in the Fallout series. I believe that this game is a worthy successor, albeit not as good as the early Fallouts. It has the same perspective as Fallout 1 and 2, but is now using a 3D engine. The game is a fair bit more combat heavy compared to Fallout 2, but unlike Fallout Tactics has a far deeper role-play element to it.

Details

+ Character creation is quite deep with plenty of attributes, skills, and derived stats. You get to create four characters at the start of the game and up to three more NPCs can join your group at a time. There are enough skills to make you want to create specialized characters for different purposes. There are skills for using different types of weapons, social skills, ability to perform certain actions such as lockpicking, safecracking, using computers, medical skills, etc.

+ Combat is turn-based and has a feel very similar to the early Fallout games except that you get to control a party instead of just one character. NPCs that join your group will sometimes choose to do their own thing if you do not have a character with high enough leadership. You get a certain number of action points to perform actions during a character's turn such as moving, using one of the weapon's firing modes or an item, reloading, and so on. Cover exists and increases both aim and defense of a character in it. When and how often characters get to move depends on their combat initiative.

+ Game is long and completing it with all of the sidequests can easily take 60 hours. There are plenty of different locations to explore and while there are radioactive walls that prevent you from going to certain places before you are supposed to in the story line you generally get to decide where do you want to go.

+ Story and writing are both solid. A lot of quests have multiple solutions and in a number of cases social skills can help avoid confrontation. Decisions you make will affect the ending and the ending itself will clearly show the results of your actions with slides explaining what will happen to every place you have visited.

+ Great ambient soundtrack from the same composer who created music for Fallout 1 and 2 as well as Planescape: Torment and a number of other games.

+ While overall graphical quality is quite poor by today's standards and character models especially could use an improvement, I feel like the designers and artists have made the most out of a kickstarter budget.

- Most of the loot in the game is completely random and changes on reload encouraging save scumming. It is completely possible to crack a well-protected safe only to find a few bullets in it while a game reload could give you a nice weapon instead. Furthermore most of the loot is broken down into tiers based on location or your place in the story line so there are often points in the game when you know your party is equipped with best equipment possible until you progress further making looting until that point completely unexciting and even becoming tedious with how plentiful containers are. Also a number of items that are marked as junk end up having a purpose in some of the quests.

- Some balancing issues make certain weapon types completely useless throughout the game. If you choose wrongly in the beginning you will feel screwed later on.

- Due to how plentiful combat is higher difficulty levels require very specific character builds to make the most out of combat initiative and action points in order to progress. If you want to create a role-play party my advice is to stick to the default difficulty level.

- The game still had plenty of bugs upon release, especially in the second half of the game. The very last few areas also feel like they have been a bit rushed, but at least the game ending is satisfying.

reviewText:
I love many things about this game. I dislike very few things.

But what is most important is that this game has the wondrous feeling of escapist post-apocalyptic exploration flavor I thought we had lost forever.

When Bethesda butchered Fallout III (and although Obsidian salvaged it) -- I had no hope that I would feel the way I did in the late 90s again. I was an impressionable kid, getting owned by floaters and centaurs, unprepared, Sulik bursting like a dumba$$ riddling Vic with holes-- but I loved every moment of it.

Wasteland 2 took me to that place once again, especially as you progress through the game, it becomes an old school classic that we were sorely missing in our lives for the past 20 years.

This game is an heir to the likes of Baldur's Gate 2, Fallout 1&2 and of course the grandfather of them all, the original Wasteland.

Thanks Brian & Co. for the liquifying energy weapon animations. Thanks for the non-linear love this game got. Thanks for all the times you listened to the community and backers. Thanks for sticking to your ideals and not caving in like Bioware at the onslaught of console idiocy. Thanks for Ertan the Satanist.

Thanks for returning us 90s kids back to the world intelligent, brutal and immersive cRPG gameplay.

reviewText:
Game is great. Thanks for living up to the expectations that I had set of the inXile team during the kickstarter. Really looking forward to Torment: ToN as well.

My one... complaint? Eh, contemplative point? Leveling up and how it restores you to full HP from a call on the radio. I like it in a sense from the standard level up -> insta heal, but I feel a full heal lets me game the system a little too much (put members who are about to level up in the front, have them soak damage, level them up). I feel a 25% heal over a 100% heal would've suited the sense of the game abit more, ya'know, survival instinct and all that.

But hey, if that's the only thing I'm picking out then the game is doing pretty well ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this digital deluxe edition to 1) everyone who liked the original wasteland, fallout 1 and 2 or fallout tactics and want such games back, 2) people who like to support crowdfunded games by independent producers, 3) people who want to participate in a beta process.

The game is obviously in a beta stadium, but the game looks overall promising. If you want games with tactical, turn-based combat and adult but funny rpgs in isometric perspective with an open world and choices and consequences heres a possibilty to make such a game come true. Big publishers dont seem to want to finance such games. So the gamers have to, allowing the developers to produce a game without restrictions from publishers.

You get some digital goodies and the game when its finished. The current beta is also lengthy, at least about 8-12 hours. There are still some major bugs to be fixed, optimizations to be done, some mechanics to be included, and some heavy balancing issues to be solved, but according to inXile the beta should get updated regulary and they also said, they are going to add a few maps to the beta over time. If you want to debate aspects of the game and report bugs to make the game better, you have possibilties to voice your opinion - if you like to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far so good, Wasteland 2 is shaping up to be a great buy but in its current state I would hold off unless you a) like beta testing or b) are nostalgic for Fallout 1+2.

The game is much more combat focused than the early Fallout games but its combat system is definitely an improvement over those games. The visuals are also very pleasing and level of detail is nice. Your actions do have consequence to the world and some choices will cause certain areas to be inaccessbile, this makes me think that multiple playthroughs will be necessary in order to experience most of the comabt.

Other than the obvious issues associated with being early in beta such as missing or limited content there are some major issues.  There is little feedback for most of the skills and during combat it is hard to tell how many action points some actions cost. There are also numerous bugs and pathing issues that can be frustrating but most won't ruin a playthrough.

I would hesitate to buy this game now while it's in its infancy and with its current 60$ pricetag it is a sizeable investment. Down the road when it becomes more finished I would highly recommend this game. Based on the current direction I am estimating that this game will be a very enjoyable RPG.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Many years ago as a young teenager, I beat the first Wasteland game. My copy was on a couple of 5 1/4's, and my drives were single sided, so there was some floppy flipping involved. And there was the paragraph book. But I cherished that game like no other at the time. For me it was in a class of it's own, way more interesting then the bard's tales or m&m's or wizardry's, with a silly sort of dark humor built in. Blowing up the hotdog stand just about made me pee myself laughing.

I was very happy to see it lovingly resurrected as a kickstarter project, but didn't find out about it until I saw it on steam, so I missed out on backing it. So I went ahead and grabbed the steam beta copy.

After playing the beta copy for a little while, it is very obvious that this is a very well done game with high production value. The voice acting is the best I've heard in a game in a long time. The combat is satisfying and fair. The ui makes sense. Objectives feel worth doing. You would be doing yourself a dis-service if you didn't pick up a copy of this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of old school Fallout games or the original Wasteland, even XCOM and want to play a game to where the developers care more about the game being GOOD (sorry GREAT) compared to appeasing to huge numbers, then this game is for you.

The dark humour, the morbidness, the random LOLs and things you just have to be old enough to understand or something you've experienced.  It's almost like this game is littered with easter eggs.  I love it when you snuff the life out of something.  The combat logs are nice too as well.

This game is very well thought out, runs smooth, looks great and is great fun.  This game isn't even fully released yet and it's top notch.

This game for sure will take up 40+ hours of your time.  Exploring, leveling, questing and messing around.  Do a game being a nice guy, do a game being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, or being a pyscho and just murder everybody and every goat. ....poor goats....

One nice feature they also put in is all the different ways you have to access something, IE:  oh a locked door.  I can lock pick it...or..spartan kick that ♥♥♥♥♥ in....or....use lots and lots of explosives....MacGruber would of wanted it that way.

If they see screaming goats on the internet, it goes in the game.  It just goes to show the amount of passion and joy they put into this game.

I highly recommend if you love this style of gameplay!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is based on the early access so I will try to be reasonable with how I feel about the game.
The game reminds me so much of Fallout 1 & 2 with support for higher resolution. The graphics are nothing spectacular but it doesnt have to be since the game focuses more on user experience and immersion. Yes immersion! I'm not a big fan of reading especially long dialogs but this game does it well by letting you visualize what's happening in the world via text (type writer) and npc barks. It totally allows you to use your imagination without even realizing it. Yes, there are a bunch of typos that I've noticed which affects my experience personally, but then again it's still on beta. I like the fact that the quest log system does not treat you like a dumb person, unlike Fallout 3 where it shows you on your compass where you need to go. Instead the log gives you details of what you've accomplished so far and what you need to do next. I'm playing the default difficulty (seasoned) which is very challenging and the loot system is well thought of. The scarcity of ammos and health pickups allow you to decide whether you should go back to citadel (home) by travelling which is by the way is very very dangerous, or just keep pursuing hoping that you'll maybe get lucky and find some loot or vendors along the way. There are also a lot of interesting items you may find such as sega genesis console, neogeo, and even a used condom. I think they are irrelevant to the game but it's defnitely entertaining. I probably won't sell them. It would really be awesome if the developers can go even further with it and allow you to give it to a person in citadel to place it in citadel collection room or something, to display your awesome finds.

The controls are pretty good, it's could be improved though. But I liked the fact that I can play it with just the mouse, so I don't have to hunch down in front of my keyboard. I can just sit back, relax, with one hand on the mouse. It accomodates old gamer like me who's retired and doesn't have to work and just allow the kid inside me to just enjoy what I've missed when I was growing up working too hard. No more stiff necks and sore elbows. But like I said it can be improved. Also, if I may add, I really like how the cursor system was in fallout 1& 2. I think it's actually one of my favorite and memorable to me that right-clicking changes the cursor behavior to walking or action command. I can't remember if it was double click the walk mode to run but that would be awesome option. instead of holding down shift key.

I like that they stayed away from static camera, but sometimes I wish there's an option to turn it back to static camera because the camera can get a little clunky sometimes. When you're tryign to find the travel zone it can get very frustrating, I think the way to solve this is by minimap (starcraft like)  which you can click on an area in the minimap and move the camera to that spot, which is currently not in the game. Speaking of map, I wish they have the option like in fallout 1 & 2 to have some kind of a town map that you recently visited to allow you to just go directly to a certain part of the town instead of walking all the way from the travel zone just to talk to one guy, then walking back all the way again to get out of the town. By the way the first time i took a ride at the crane elevator at highpool i was like, Oh cool"
date: but after doing that for about 10 times I'm like "Okay..."
recommended: then I'd noticed one of my party member was left behind so i have to go through the cutscene again just to get my other team mate. I know it probably took some time and even effort for whoever designed this but it get's annoying especially when you're on the go. I'm not sure if there's vehicles in the game that you can ride like in fallout 2

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where to start... The game is awesome. I'm an early backer and I've played every beta that has been released, as far through as I can. Many of the bugs/issues noted by previous reviewers just simply aren't there anymore so a lot of the Cons of the reviewers just aren't correct.

If you loved the original wasteland and you like turn based combat and actual movement strategy (think X-Com where if you move the wrong position you're toast) and a place where choices have real consequences then you will love this game. If you like all action and no brains then don't get this game. While it isn't a deep cerebral game, you do have to think about the solutions to problems (there are almost always two solutions or more to every problem). The isometric view isn't for some people but for those of us who came from the original world of RPG's it's an old friend that gives you a better view of the battlefield.

Some in-depth points. This is a deep story and if you played the original you will appreciate a lot of the subtle humor. The NPC's almost all have a background - you don't though and you don't ever grow" into a personalilty with a back story. I happen to like this approach where you get to explore your world without worrying about yourself too much. However
date:
almost every path through the story will shape how other people view you and it will either help you accomplish missions or make it much more difficult.

Pros: Everything. Basically if I was going to wait for a sequel then I would want it to be this.

I don't really have any Cons for this game. Everything is beautiful and well done. It is a very replayable game (I've mapped out about 9 different paths that I want to (or have tried) try. In addition sometimes having certain NPC's with your party allows you to unlock areas or conversation paths that you could not otherwise discover.

The team did a great job and I hope to write up a complete walkthrough in addition to the getting started guide which I'll update once the game goes live."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I spent over 50 hours play testing the hell out of this game and wow with very little money they came up with this I am shocked about how good this is and I never write reviews period.

Bad:
some stupid bugs game braking bug in damonta where if you blow up the gate and do your mission you will not be able to pick it back up if you leave after hooking up the radio tower.

Armor and weapons- idk if the game creator’s don’t wants you to have an op corrector but there needs to be way better armor and weapons so that way you are up to par with even the toughest sob's.

merchants - have it restock or at least throw it to normal and easy mode.

customizing units- why are they so weird and stiff looking and lack luster there should be a better customizing in the beginning and then some generic ugly looking caricatures and why when I put on steel armor do they not look like the bad mf er atleast look it how xcom did it.

lastly why do i even want to help these guys out if there is no point in helping the ncps. They should have some type of territory or buddy system that if you help them out you actually gain something like they best warrior follows you and not just to drive the story plot. So I’m asking not throw flaver text but give me a reason to care about them and not just mow them down.

Side note the lag and other dumb issues will in time be resolved so I wanted to keep these out.

The Good

There is a lot in here first. The voice acting is very good from what I expected to be just text and that is it.

The different weapons that the game lets you chose and upgrades so that your play style is your falt if it does not work (wish there were more customizing)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is quite polished now, although there are still some annoying bugs, but most of them can be fixed by restaring a game. Not how it should work; but oh well..

I wanted to dislike this game because it was expensive and my first impressions were not thatt good. Mechanics seemed to be clunky, dialogues were cheesy.

Now after 24 hours of gameplay in total, I can say that this game is pure genius. Period

It so much reminds me of the good old RPG games. I am always thrilled to see a new area, meet new NPCs, get new quests. What is odd because I met such a game years ago is that it will not spoonfeed you the solution. You will need to figure out how to solve things.

Maybe my biggest plus for the game is the map editing. Almost all of the maps are interesting with many hidden things, side areas, various ways to approach a combat. Very intelligently designed.

Of course it still needs polishing, my biggest pain is that even if I spent countless hours playing it, probbaly the nexy big patch will reset my progress. Also it would be very good to notifiy in game if an area is not accessibe yet. I spent quite a time trying to find out how to get in the prison then I read that it is not available yet...

All in all, it is an awesome game, Brian Fargo is still the god of intelligent and quality RPGs.

reviewText:
A true Desert Ranger, what a journey it was to become one. Wasteland 2 has captured the essence of computer role playing games, the best indicator of which is the giddyness you'll feel when you think about doing another playthrough. It has an astounding wealth of good writing in it, so many encounters, quests and dialogues that are simply joyous to experience. The best thing is, that so many of these things can play out differently, depending on your party and your actions. A reactive world with a deeply emotive story.

On your adventures through the sands, towns and cities, the game accompanies you with amazing music and visual style. The art and sounds immerse you, creating an atmosphere, that is both truly gritty in its post-apocalyptic splendor and darkly humorous with countless references and jokes. It's a world you want more of, a world you want to experience and are constantly thrilled to see what comes next.

Combat is tactical and bloody, you will be able to attain all kinds of weapons, hilarious and deadly, and the death animations with the combat action descriptions make it purely Wasteland. Thoroughly enjoyable action from beginning to end. Different playstyles are well taken into account, playing with a bunch of melee bruisers or a squad of dead-shot riflemen, it's all equally satisfying. Though let's just say, that my favorite remains pummeling four raiders into red mist with a single well-placed burst from an automatic shotgun. Brutal and awesome.

You will be creating characters of any variety you wish, and you will fall in love with them. The attribute system, skill system and a cool variety of cosmetic customization are a joy to tinker around with. As you play the game you will learn more about how the game progresses with the type of characters you've created, or NPCs you've recruited, and you'll be excited to try out different things next time. It's a game that keeps on giving.

Do yourself a favor, if you've liked the 90's cRPGs, and play this game. It has been a long wait, but we finally got a game worthy of being up there at the top, with the best cRPG classics. Many games fail to deliver memorable moments, but this one, just like the good ones before it, has you fondly thinking back at the great things you've experienced with it.

reviewText:
Phenomenal, just what I had expected and more.

After 50 hours I have finally beaten the game and that with skipping some side quests mainly in the second half of the game, Rarely does a game give you so many choices alot of which are tough moral choices that have very real effects on the game, every NPC except on is killable (The commander in Sante Fe), you can play the game in every way you can think of and killing everyone or betraying the rangers are legit options that you can make and they wont stop you from progressing in the game (they will make the game harder though and I am going to start a game where I am going to kill everyone right after I finish writing this) and dont think killing everyone doesnt have benefits, unlike in other games if you kill a marchant all of what he was selling is takeable.

Some people claim that the combat is the weak part of the game but I have to disagree, the combat feels great, it can get annoying sometimes with some extremely hard fights and with some enemies being able to run completely insane distances.

The story is well writen and there is not a single bad guy" that fights you because you are evil no one is really bad or good

reviewText:
You have already read the reviews of others and the positive ones are correct about the game. Although I would like to inform you of a few caveats.

The game difficulty is well balanced at the normal suggested difficulty setting but starts to break while it is increased. Unlike Fallout Tactics, as the difficulty in Wasteland 2 increases the only change is quantitative. Your aim probability decreases, enemies do more damage etc. but the AI remains the same. Beating a battle set piece doesn't make you feel like you played well it mearly feels like you got lucky over and over again.

One last pet peeve. The issue here is the half turn discrepancy between setting up your squad before combat and the first turn of combat. Since you can see battle coming you are able to plan ahead for it by setting squad order but the second battle starts all of your squad move just a little out of place and destroy all chance of strategic combat.

reviewText:
Short version: this is not a great game. It will not be remembered for years to come as a high point of the genre. It will not spawn remakes and imitators. But it's still good enough, and frankly, if you like your combat turn-based and your texts long and well-enough written, you have no choice this Autiman, but to spend some time playing Wasteland 2.

Now, let's dig in to see what went wrong.

Character development

At first, character development looks good enough. For the first half of the game, you will value every Skill Point you get. Unfortunately, after that it becomes evident that character development is quite limited in Wasteland 2. You can spend Skill Points to get slightly better at hitting enemies. Or opening locks. Or disarming traps. Et cetera. But if you try to make two characters with the same specialization (say, Sniper Rifles), you will develop them in pretty much the same way. There are no ways to make a character unique: no Perks, no Feats, nothing of that sort. Why didn't the developers add such feature to the game, I can't imagine. It's not like it would require expensive voice-acting or even additional 3d models...

At the very least, they could have borrowed a page from Shadowrun's rulebook, and give special abilities or bonuses at certain levels of skill. I don't really see a need to give my Sniper 10 in sniper rifles, when all it gets me is a few more percents of To Hit chance!

Combat

Combat here is turn-based and slightly more varied, that in Fallout 2. This is all good that could be said about it. Lacking abilities, this game offers little in a way of infulening the outcome of combat in dramatic way. This is especially dissapointing after GREAT combat in Divinity: Original Sin.

In terms of combat, Wasteland 2 is far behind not only D:OS, but also both Shadowrun and X-Com. This is made worse by strange balance, which allows enemies to mostly negate all your careful placement of characters by running a very long distance in a single turn (this is not a bug: with bug, they had pretty much unlimited running range, now it's just too big).

Story

Should you expect a great, thoughtfull story from a game that has Toaster Repair in its list of skills? I guess you shouldn't. But I still was disappointed by a pretty cliche main quest.

Another bad mark here is tired trope where heroes take about 15 minutes to solve problems which locals could not solve for years. Negotiate a peace between two warring tribes? A bit of shooting and one dialog. Convince a community to stop ritual cannibalism? Two dialogs! Now, you shouldn't probably make the player feel like they are negotiating for peace in Middle East, but this is borderline insulting.

Dialogues

Dialogues here are all right. Text are well-enough written and I had no wish to skip them.

Still, there are to little Skill Checks, and lack of complex trees lead to shallow experience. Compare this to Arcanum's dialogues with Persuasion...

World

Post-apocalyptic games, books and movies are not known for a well-tought-out worlds. They are often seem more like a zoo. See here
recommended: this farmers worship an unexploded nuke; and those town took their god from an old folk song!"\n\nWasteland 2 did nothing to change it. Still
