reviewText: Wasteland 2 brings a unique style to RPG games. Giving off a fallout type of vide through out the whole game had amazing easter eggs to find and tons of interesting dialog. The combat was great and simple, Despite the minor bugs involving the camera glitching out durring combat but fixing itself after the next turn. Wasteland 2 state that there is 80+ hours.\nThis may be true for some, yet for me it left me wanting more after finishing the game in under 60 hours. (All quests, side quests, locations, caches, characters, easter eggs, and pretty much everything was achived with a amazing immersive experience.-For me at least in under 60 hours) All and All wasteland 2 brings back the nostalga of the original wasteland and orginal fallouts. I would have to recommend this to everyone that loves the first wasteland and the fallout franchise. Although i would say i was abit annoyed by the fact it isn't open ended in terms of being able to continue to play and explore after the ending credits. I cannot however recommend this at its current pricing. the amount of content is great yet still is lacking in key areas. Best to wait for sales unless its a must have right now.

reviewText:
Alright i'll get right to the point,  this game has numerous technical issues and often requires outside help as there is very little explanation for most missions. My only wish for this game was that the world was 'more open' and that the last 10-15% of the game felt rushed. Now that the criticism is out of the way heres what you will like.

The meat of the gameplay is the RTS [duh] which is slick, and relatively smooth but often forces the player to watch all enemy moves [forces the camera to lock onto each hostile unit] but that is a small setback. The weapons and wearable cloths look great, with a fair amount of customization [not great but decent]. The combat is fun, and challenging and for loot hoarders such as myself there is ALWAYS something to loot, scavenge, and steal. The diologue system is great, but requires characters to upgrade non combat skills which can be frusterating for some, but offer rewarding new story archs for the player to follow which are otherwise impossible. I highly recommend creating you're own ranger or two [remember to specialize them in something] and create a backstory for them - makes you feel invested in the game and makes the player care who lives and who dies.

However anyone with a heart can tell this game is a love letter to the fans who have been waiting for decades to indulge themselves within the wasteland universe. As with most love letters they at times try to hard, and on occassion written in haste. This is evident in some parts of the game [specifically late game]; despite this the effort and excruciating detail that went it to this game shows how much InXile wanted to make this game for others and for themselves. The story is great, the side quests have meaning and concequences with numerous outcomes all expressed in the epilogue which most will be more than satisfied with the thorough and satisfying ending; which leaves just enough loose ends to imply a wasteland 3 could see the light of day in the near future [ I hope anyway]. This is one of those games where I want to scream at the developers to take my money to support the game with new content [full expansions preferably] hoping containing a new area  map to explore.

The epilogue this game provides will take a modest 5 minutes to read, and it manages to wrap this game up in a satisfying way. I'm a major gamer having thousands of hours on steam alone [doesnt even count for my console based games] and I can't say I havn't been as satisfied with an ending in years, I'd say the ending is similar to dragon age inquisition neatly wrapping up everything.

reviewText: I can see this as the type of game that if I had more time I could lose over 200 hours in it and still have things to do (like fallout 2)  The first part of the game is rather slow, but the second half is really quite quick and extremly enjoyable.  As with some kickstarter/small studio games there are some quirks, such as the ending scenematic and some odd crashes, but for me this doesn't take away from a very enjoyable game.\n\nA lot of people compare this game to Divinity, and I really don't think there is a contest.  This game is markedly better in most regards, but I do like both games.  The main difference is that Divinity has harder combat and more tactical combat, but doesn't have a very deep plot and has parts that are time sucks for the sake of being time sucks and just call it being difficult.  I like both games, but Wasteland 2 offers what Divinty doesn't, more polish, more depth, more plot, and frankly it is pretty funny.

reviewText:
Played 31 hours in 3 days. 10 hours in to first play through decided I didnt like my setup Main menu'ed and New game.  The Game is amazing the Character creation can take an hour or more trying to fit all the skills your want in to 4 characters you quickly learn you cant have what you want, time to pick what you think you'll need.

While I see alot of comparing it to Fallout 1&2 no one mentions how close the game is to Fallout tactics the combat is almost a clone.  Fallout tactics was also a squad based game with the same Map system for travel.

All in all I love the game, Best $40 I have spent this year the replay value is high and it makes me feel like I was a teen again, Playing Fallout on a computer that could barely run doom.

( Edit ) Having Completed the game I feel I should fill out the reveiw Some more.  First The Battle system does get a little bit boring shall I say? but its to be expected in a battle System of Turn Based and Guns in the end you know what is going to happen you'll hit that wall for every shot hits. The AI does tend to simply Rush at you rather than use cover but again to be expected from this type of game ( Fallouts where all the same )  But the story and the choices you make unlike normal RPG they carry a certain weight too them which after the first one or two you make and you realise this you start to question your actions, what to say to the NPC's what the out come might be and how to push it the way you want.

All in All I loved the game it felt Fleshed out and complete to me, I did not see any of the bugs the others have added to their reviews infact the only issue I did was that the Camera locked at one point and I had to Alt + Tab to fix it.  I will Play again, many times. I feel that if you want a game where choices do matter and who you Shoot changes the game this is the game for you.  I look forward to some DLC too.

10/10

reviewText:
While I missed the original Wasteland I got to play every game in the Fallout series. I believe that this game is a worthy successor, albeit not as good as the early Fallouts. It has the same perspective as Fallout 1 and 2, but is now using a 3D engine. The game is a fair bit more combat heavy compared to Fallout 2, but unlike Fallout Tactics has a far deeper role-play element to it.

Details

+ Character creation is quite deep with plenty of attributes, skills, and derived stats. You get to create four characters at the start of the game and up to three more NPCs can join your group at a time. There are enough skills to make you want to create specialized characters for different purposes. There are skills for using different types of weapons, social skills, ability to perform certain actions such as lockpicking, safecracking, using computers, medical skills, etc.

+ Combat is turn-based and has a feel very similar to the early Fallout games except that you get to control a party instead of just one character. NPCs that join your group will sometimes choose to do their own thing if you do not have a character with high enough leadership. You get a certain number of action points to perform actions during a character's turn such as moving, using one of the weapon's firing modes or an item, reloading, and so on. Cover exists and increases both aim and defense of a character in it. When and how often characters get to move depends on their combat initiative.

+ Game is long and completing it with all of the sidequests can easily take 60 hours. There are plenty of different locations to explore and while there are radioactive walls that prevent you from going to certain places before you are supposed to in the story line you generally get to decide where do you want to go.

+ Story and writing are both solid. A lot of quests have multiple solutions and in a number of cases social skills can help avoid confrontation. Decisions you make will affect the ending and the ending itself will clearly show the results of your actions with slides explaining what will happen to every place you have visited.

+ Great ambient soundtrack from the same composer who created music for Fallout 1 and 2 as well as Planescape: Torment and a number of other games.

+ While overall graphical quality is quite poor by today's standards and character models especially could use an improvement, I feel like the designers and artists have made the most out of a kickstarter budget.

- Most of the loot in the game is completely random and changes on reload encouraging save scumming. It is completely possible to crack a well-protected safe only to find a few bullets in it while a game reload could give you a nice weapon instead. Furthermore most of the loot is broken down into tiers based on location or your place in the story line so there are often points in the game when you know your party is equipped with best equipment possible until you progress further making looting until that point completely unexciting and even becoming tedious with how plentiful containers are. Also a number of items that are marked as junk end up having a purpose in some of the quests.

- Some balancing issues make certain weapon types completely useless throughout the game. If you choose wrongly in the beginning you will feel screwed later on.

- Due to how plentiful combat is higher difficulty levels require very specific character builds to make the most out of combat initiative and action points in order to progress. If you want to create a role-play party my advice is to stick to the default difficulty level.

- The game still had plenty of bugs upon release, especially in the second half of the game. The very last few areas also feel like they have been a bit rushed, but at least the game ending is satisfying.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 was one of those games that really speaks to older generations of games. There are many good as well as bad design features, but overall it's an enjoyable experience if you're willing to put yourself through it.

Upon starting up your first game you create a party of four Rangers and can choose their stats and skills, select character appearance options, and write a quick bio should you so desire. Of course, one of the things that is limited by the standards of old crpgs is that you can't play your character too far off the path of the desert rangers, but still the story is interesting and features a lot of unique ideas that might just get you to crack a smile.

Now there is a ton of dialogue and text in this game, but of course that means a lot of conversation options come up time after time. You'll find your self clicking things to get them out of the way, and of course sometimes this can get you into confrontations without any clear indications. Since I like to schmooze my way through many of these it was kind of annoying that there werent more options to use the skills associated with conversation, but at least they were there.

The combat mechanics were probably the most fun. I played this game at the second highest difficulty on my first try and didn't have too much trouble. There are some frustrating things, like enemies walking 150 tiles across the map straight up to your characters on the first turn and punching them in the face, but so long as you're prepared you can usually deal with this by lobbing out grenades and rockets. That being said, there are plenty of different weapons to take advantage of and they are all useful and unique in different ways. Some character stats are more useful to combat than others, so it helps a ton to diversify your party because the situations that arise require different skills and weapons. Some enemies are tough to take out with light weapons, but easy targets with energy guns, and vice versa.

As a piece of advice you will be binding quick save to the key closest to your keyboard hand, and pressing it often. There are times where it is not always clear what you have to do, and if you do them in the wrong order you can get into situations like endless combat for HOURS before you give up and reload. It's truly unfortunate that unorthodox situations do this to the player, as it feels restricting at times. I remember early in the game trying to expedite a mayoral race, and did as many helpful tasks as I could save for one that I could not find. Turns out the doctor, who said he didn't need any help, actually needec you to use your surgeon skill on his patients... seriously? I spent hours trying to figure this out before looking it up.

Another gripe is that you will spend hours just walking across maps, for no purpouse other than you're going back and fourth for quests. There are sometimes ways around this that open up after having done enough to open up a quicker passage, but usually by this point it doesn't even matter anymore. You'll experience this enough to come to hate the experience. You'll be getting out your chair to find something to distract you for three minutes while your party walks around, and sometimes you have no idea if where you're going is going to help your quest. Truly this was the most frustrating aspect of the game.

Yet another thing, many characters have the same portraits, even important ones at times. I really wish that they had taken the Baldurs Gate appreach and only gave important characters unique portraits. And the portraits, they look like they were painted by a college student. They werent bad, but felt lacking. Sometimes it made the characters you meet less unique, as they just sort of blend into each other.

Now it might seem i'm going off on the negative aspects of the game, but these are things you should know before you start playing. It's by no means perfect, but hightly enjoyable. Comparable to Shadowrun Returns, where as shadowrun had a really focused story and an enjoyable simplicity, Wasteland 2 has a very big and diluted feel with explosive chests falling out of the sky and arguably more interesting combat mechanics and a big world.

reviewText:
Let's start with the bottom line - If you liked Fallout 1/2 - Get this game.
Buy it now , stop wasting your time.

This game is great.
It's an absolute throwback to post apocalyptic games of the 90s-2000s with some modern parts.
I say some - because it mainly sticks to mechanics invented in the 90s , not a lot of inovation.
That said - the game has very good writing , lot's of player choice and interesting skill trees that evolve nicely.
Good thing you start with a party of 4 to be able to divide the skills between your characters - because you'll be totally surprised of how useful some skills are over others.

I'm 50 hours into the game and reached the last fight - it's very challenging and I feel I might have reached it too early which is a bit of a bummer.

Regarding bugs - the only one that affected me was the 32bit memory issue. this would mean - when using high textures - it will crash when moving into / out of maps constantly.
This is especially absurd because it's only for the lack of 64 bit support on mac.
I'm playing on a MBPr 15 - which can run this game easily and it crashes all the time.
Solution - lower the texture maps one notch.

Another bummer is it doesn't really support the Retina resolution
date:
There is no reason for me to play on my native non retina resolution when my screen can easily work on double that resolution / at least at 1080P.

Other then those issues - no complaints whatsoever.

Looking forward to playing much more."

reviewText:
Review as of 10/21/14 (and you'll understand why I included the date shortly)

In brief, Wasteland 2 is a mostly-awesome Kickstarter (TM) funded game tainted by some very bad decision making.

The game picks up where its predecessor left off, you are recruits for the Desert Rangers, a peace-keeping force in a post apocalyptic Arizona.  Your peace-keeping activities involve what you, the seasoned gamer, might have come to expect of the genre:  mutants, barbarians, and insane robots.  Where this game shines is in how it utilizes these very typical post-apocalyptic tropes to portray some very realistic and human settings as well as very real consequences for your actions.

This is the most interesting development of this game.  Typically role-playing type games cater to the completionist crowd by making most every quest available and completable.  Wasteland 2 rejects this model forcing the player into branches of decisions and consequences which make other outcomes and objectives inaccessible.  Complicating this new quest model is that these decisions are never simple.  It is not a matter of choosing to save one good guy or one bad guy.  Instead the game asks you to decided from among two terrible choices.  Save this murderer or save this ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The game gives you the option to sit on the fence for most of the quests, however, this comes with its own (often terrible) perils.

Where this game also shines is in the little details.  Specifically the writing and music, both of which are excellent.  Even the voice-acting is mostly well done.  The game also plays like a sort of love-letter to the video game communmity.  This makes perfect sense as this game would not have been possible without the financial support of the fans of this community.

The little details is also where the game falls apart.  The GUI, graphics (the world map), and combat mechanics all leave something to be desired.  Where the game falls apart is the entire last 25% of the game.  Although the game was delayed by nearly one year from its original date, and although it enjoyed a great deal of free beta testing from the Steam Early Access Program, this game was rushed to market before it was polished and complete.  The game literally falls apart at the seams in the last 25%.  This lack of polish creates nonsensical dialogue choices which makes the quests  broken.  Even worse is that the final encounters (those which shoudl be the most emotionally impactful) are broken.  In one I had to manually attack the boss to force a battle.  The final encounter is a simple matter of hacking and slashing your way to victory.  I wasted one attempt looking around for a secret way to complete the encounter and eventually realized you are simply supposed to blow everything up.  This unfortunate final encounter is partially a result of the boring combat system, partially a lack of imagination, but primarily the result of a game which should have been delayed by another year.

It is easy to say this from the arm chair of course.  In another year the game probably would have run out of funding or the audience would have moved on.  InExile has been releasing rather huge patches every week since the game came out, however, one wonders how much a skeleton crew of developers on bug-fixing duty can really accomplish.  Each patch has thus far read like a bible but this game needs a church full of bibles to make the last quarter not suck.  I included the date because perhaps a year from now, if churches full of bibles, materialize, I coule recommend this game.  As it stands I only recommend the first 75%.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this digital deluxe edition to 1) everyone who liked the original wasteland, fallout 1 and 2 or fallout tactics and want such games back, 2) people who like to support crowdfunded games by independent producers, 3) people who want to participate in a beta process.

The game is obviously in a beta stadium, but the game looks overall promising. If you want games with tactical, turn-based combat and adult but funny rpgs in isometric perspective with an open world and choices and consequences heres a possibilty to make such a game come true. Big publishers dont seem to want to finance such games. So the gamers have to, allowing the developers to produce a game without restrictions from publishers.

You get some digital goodies and the game when its finished. The current beta is also lengthy, at least about 8-12 hours. There are still some major bugs to be fixed, optimizations to be done, some mechanics to be included, and some heavy balancing issues to be solved, but according to inXile the beta should get updated regulary and they also said, they are going to add a few maps to the beta over time. If you want to debate aspects of the game and report bugs to make the game better, you have possibilties to voice your opinion - if you like to.

reviewText:
First up, I thoroughly recommend this game.  It's an old school isometric RPG, and it's excellent.

It has it's flaws, but overall they don't undermine the experience, the worst I could say about this game is that there are some balance issues, and there are elements of the game that feel rough and unfinished.

I think it suffers from kickstarter-itis .. where a developer seeks a budget on the KS platform, achieves or exceeds it, then works to that budget.  Back in the day, a company would outlay their own capital and not make money until the product was released, now kickstarter covers development and profit goes into someone's bank account.

The problem with this (understandable) model is that there's not a lot of room for stretch and polish.  You either wildly exceed the kickstarter or you don't - and if you do, let's face it, there's probably a bit more of a 'loose' approach with project management and a higher budget for chicken chow mein.

I think there are functional elements of the game that should have been deeper, and there are story-telling elements that fell onto the 'nice to have but not essential' list and got cut.

Incidentally, I haven't finished the game yet, I'm about 75% through (I think).

Here's my view on the Good/Bad

Good:
- graphics and theme are nice
- world map and random encounters makes you feel 'there'
- radio chatter from different factions is immersive
- background lore (the rangers, their character, their personalities) .. all good
- combat: for the most part is satisfying and tactical
- story: although contrived in places, overall the storytelling pulls you in and holds your interest
- conversations and character writing is good for the most part (but also a missed opportunity)

Bad:
- weapon balance has some very bad decisions, energy weapons in particular range from OP in some situations to useless in others.  I say balance, but I don't really care too much about balance, what bothers me is some of the weapons are balanced is .. well, not logical and doesn't fit into a consistent and realistic universe
- Skills & Attributes: for me a real missed opportunity, they disconnect.  Example, Charisma doesnt effect conversations.  Seriously.  There's no randomness or discreet skill impact on conversations, just gatekeeper skills hardarse/intimidation, smartarse/logic, kissarse/charm .. and those skills are just numbers.  Likewise the balance of stats and skills is not really intuitive and clever in it's design, I guess in a way the game suffers from being compared to Fallout 2 in that regard.
- Contrived/Illogical writing:  there are some key points where the writing is a bit .. contrived.  No matter what you do, it's pre-ordained that the outcome will lead you from A->B->C, doesnt matter if you're evil or good.  If I were to analogise with pen&paper roleplaying, it's basically having a GM who can't 'think on their feet' .. the underarching story should be invisible, it should feel like you have total freedom and YOU (the player) are calling the shots .. instead, there are a few key points in the story writing where you feel more than a bit led by the nose (worse, there are some points where you only have a couple of options and those options don't allow for wide variations in character, one specific example you have 3 options to respond to a challenge from your CO, and each of them forces you to lie.


Overall, I give the game a solid 8.5 / 10 golden jabberoos.

reviewText:
Finally, after all these years, we get a proper spiritual sequel to the first Fallout games. In fact, Wasteland 2 looks and feels so much like a Fallout game that it took me some time to accept that I had no Pipboy, Vault suit or funny perks.

It's a really engaging game with an interesting story (without being revolutionary in any way), with the usual moral dilemmas and multiple paths to complete objectives. And it's great value for money; I personally spent 86 hours on a single playthrough! Granted, I like to take my time more than most, but few games offer me that much nowadays.

It's not a perfect game though; the ending is lackluster and the latter half of the game (with one area in particular) is riddled with some rather annoying (but not gamebreaking) bugs. But eh, I guess the bugs is just another aspect  that emulates the good old Fallout games...

All in all, I'll definetely recommend this for fans of post-apocalyptic settings, roleplaying games and the Fallout series in particular.

8/10 (perhaps even 9/10 if they fix most of the bugs)

reviewText:
The AI is replete with bugs and are highly inconsistent, making most tactical decisions irrelevant. Sheer firepower is the only thing that gets you through the firefights. Your sniper can be crouching in an elevated position and blocking the only way up, and the enemy WILL run the equivalent of 30 odd action points to circle the position just to stand beside your sniper. Likewise the AI npc follower WILL make the same circuit just to stand in front of the enemy to die. Doesn't help that the AI followers have 1 or 2 bullet shot's worth of hp and can't be healed. Even under normal circumstances depending on the AI's whim and fancy they ocassionally develop a sudden ability to produce more ability points than otherwise deemed possible so that they can come and hug your characters in a loving embrace. The AI npc inconsistency has the potential to utterly ruin your attempt for a perfect quest clearance for at least one of the compulsory quests.

There's a general lack of ammunition and medipack drops at the start of the game, so each encounter has to be carefully planned and executed. Unfortunately, in the early parts of the game, much of the available ammunition can only be found in locked/trapped safes/chests/boxes, which require a significant investment into the necessary non combat skills, which affects the distribution of limited stat points for combat skills, further wasting limited ammunition. Not a bad thing in itself, but would require careful planning.

A corollary to the above is, on the long run characters starting with high intel and charm will significantly outstrip all other characters in every single way. One of the earliest followers you can get is characteristic of this. Low intelligence results in inadequate points to spread amongst auxiliary abilities, which results in bombs exploding, locks breaking, alarms ringing, bone fractures, skipped conversation choices and blue screens of death, and crucially, low supplies.

Other than this, an excellent, excellent game. The story is brilliant and the choices you make in the game have implications and depth, though a number are more akin to morally abstract implications.

P.S. There is a hidden choice at the start of the game, though it makes your playthrough a little harder than the standard choices. And remember to pick up the damned shovel.

reviewText: For people who enjoy strategy and rts games like the original fallouts or xcom. This game is simply amazing. Although this is beta the bug problem is still very real. But all in all it's still a great game and I recommend you to get it for the chance at spending an hour creating characters that you love and then losing them in the first encounter with wasteland creatures.

reviewText:
Wow. Think about a mix between Fallout 1/2 and Tactics (an actually good Tactics).

You probably will like this game if:
- you enjoyed Wasteland 1 back then
- you like turn based combat but don't expect it to be like in Jagged Alliance 2
- you like Fallout 1 or 2 or Tactics
- you like post-apokalyptic themes

You probably won't like this game if:
- you need state-of-the-art graphics and staged stories like in Mass Effect
- you expect without exception a Fallout 2.5

You have bit less freedom than in Fallout 1 & 2 but much more than in Tactics. The turn based combat offer many options but doesn't complicate things (think of XCOM:EU/EW, when it comes down to simplicity; not much micromanagement) so it keeps up the pace and therefore the fun! Combat can also be really hard on higher difficulties since there are some medical conditions you can get (e.g. concussion, blood loss, etc.) much more frequently than in Fallout 1 &2 (it was very rare to get hurt in the eyes, legs or arms). While the combat and interface mechanics are simple there are a lot of options, skills and abilities, e.g. to spot a trap on a door you need to activate your skill perception" and it must be high enough. Spotting a trap is one thing but disarming is another thing that require the specific skill. In Fallout there were some skill with little or almost no use like Science but not so in Wasteland 2. Every skill you can learn can be used and some skills that seem irrelevant at first might even used in the first hour (like repairing toasters!).

Do you know the tactical RPG The Fall: Last Days of Gaia? If yes think about Wasteland 2 like a next gen and well crafted and balanced version of The Fall (and Fallout Tactics). Everything just works
date: quests which appear pretty straight forward and easy at first may open up and get more complicated or leads you further than you have expected (think about Vampire: Bloodlines or The Witcher 1) The German version has some troubles with the translation here and there (few parts are poorly translated or not at all) so this may apply to other languages then English
recommended:
too.

The soundtrack does really make you think you're in Wasteland 1 or Fallout 1. It's just well fitting and while depressing it really makes you enjoy and recognize the soundtrack deliberately.

I wish there were more customization options for the character creation but you can use custom portraits like back in the old days of Icewind Dale or Baldur's Gate. Since you probably use a camera angle with further distance it's not a big problem.

The price for this game retail is 30 bucks and for 40 you'll get the Ranger Edition in an amazing looking box with nice additional physical content (plus the Soundtrack from Wasteland 1 and 2). So you get more for your money than with many other triple A titles nowadays
hoursPlayed: physically and virtual."

reviewText:
I was skeptical that a crowd funded game with a 60 dollar initial pricetag would actually end up being a solid title. Thankfully, I was proven wrong. I picked up the game for 40 dollars and so far it has been worth every penny.

Gameplay-
This isn't a game that holds your hand every step of the way, often times you need to think about what you are doing or saying (dialogue) and if you mess up it might give you an undesirable result. Personally, I enjoy it since I feel like everytime i go anywhere new there is a chance to find some need little tidbit or item that normally would not stand out.

Characters-
While it is unusual to find an RPG these days that allows the creation of a party (only other one i can think of is might and magic legacy), it provides an opportunity to make characters specialize in different fields. For example, I have a hand to hand bruiser that has meathead skills (break, hard ♥♥♥ and mechanical repair (not meathead but the best i could do)). Then another character has sniper computer science and smart ♥♥♥. Another cool aspect is that you can assign characters religion, nationality and even their favorite pack of smokes- who knows maybe there is a little easter egg somewhere if you have a jewish asian etc. Also there are optional companions along the way, which can add 3 more faces (max) to your party.

Combat-
Being as it is turn base, it takes patience, but at the same time it allows the methodical approach. A lot of people don't like weapon jamming (requires an action similar to a reload), but i like it considering it adds more variability. If you have like Classic Turn-Based combat then you will enjoy this.

Loot-
I dont like how treasure was dealt with in this game. I find myself normally picking up heaps of junk or 6-7 of the same crappy gun i've been using. It also seems a little odd that there is such an abundance of ammo in an apocalytic wasteland. There are also some hidden items that can be turned into npcs for rewards, so keep an eye out!

The World-
The game utilizes a travel mechanic that places the part on a board" in which they have to travel to different locations all the while you can be attacked by raiders and be mindful of your water supply. As for whether the game is open ended or not
date: I would say yes to an extent. Even though there are optional side objectives
recommended: the path always leads you in the direction of the mission. It is similar to the Mass Effect Series as both have the option for exploration and side missions
hoursPlayed:
but the story missions are required to advance.

Overall-
Have you played Divinity: Original Sin (check)
Have you played Shadowrun Returns (check)
Have you played Fallout 2 (check)
Did you like any of them (check)
Then you will love this (check)"

reviewText:
I'm a die hard Fallout and Wasteland fan. While Fallout 1, 2 (which i consider being the greatest game in history of mankind) and even Tactics and where great games, Fallout 3 and New Vegas where FPS abominations, now worthy of Fallout name. So i've waited and waited for a true Fallout successor. Then i've got Wasteland 2. Am i disappointed? Hell no!
Wasteland was father of Fallouts and Brian Fargo was father of both. You can feel his touch in every aspect of Wasteland 2. From wonderful post-apocalyptic setting, through deep development of Your characters, interesting quests and NPCs... ending with what made Fallouts such great - adult, dark humour and morally grey world, which You can shape as You want.

TL:DR - forget about Fallout 3 and New Vegas. Wasteland 2 is the true successor of old Fallouts. While in terms of gameplay it feels more like Tactics, all in all it's a wonderful and complex RPG, in which You'll spend tons of hours playing. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a party based RPG set in a post nuclear war USA. The player controls a squad of Desert Rangers, whose mission is to protect civilians and maintain law and order, but now an army of robots want to wipe out Humanity, and its up to the Rangers to stop them. I never played the original Wasteland, but I'm a massive fan of RPGs, and I certainly found alot to enjoy in this game.

Combat is turn based on a square grid, with each action such as moving, firing, reloading and healing costing ability points, similar to Xcom or Shadowrun. Its very tactical, and you also have to pay attention to factors like cover, line of sight, weapon range and friendly fire. The maximum party size is seven, four of which are created by the player, and the others have to be recruited as you progress through quests.

There is a wide variety of abilities to put points into when levelling up. You can use several different types of guns and melee weapons, but also non-combat skills including lockpicking, safecracking, computer hacking, trap disarming, machinery repair and more. These skills are very useful because many quests can be completed in multiple ways, by finding alternate routes to enter a building or unlocking extra dialogue options.

The story is really good and there are lots of interesting characters and groups. From drug gangs to slavers and religious fanatics, there's always somebody more crazy in the next town. Many quests involve a conflict between two or more factions and the player has freedom to choose who to support, but you'll rarely find an obvious good guys" faction
date: more often its a case of "which is the lesser evil?". Dialogue is mostly text based
recommended: with only the major characters being voiced
hoursPlayed: but its all well written with lots of dark humour.\n\nI didn't encounter any game breaking bugs
voteText: but occasionally I thought certain quest progressions could have been better. Like the time I drank from a water well
helpfulPercent: got infected with a disease
votesHelpful: and used a normal inventory item to cure myself. Later I found the town's doctor
votesTotal: who asked me to investigate why the people were getting sick. I didn't have any option to say "dude
votesFunny: its your well". The only way to progress the quest was to travel to another town to find a special microscope so the doctor could check out some samples
commentsCount: and discover what I already knew several hours of gameplay earlier.\n\nI also didn't like that inactive companions didn't seem to gain XP. One of my earliest recruits was kind of annoying
column16: constantly complaining about literally everything
column17: so I wanted to ditch him. But every new recruit I found after that was several levels lower
column18: and I didn't want to be weaker in combat
column19: so I was stuck with him.\n\nExcept for those complaints
column20: Wasteland 2 is a really great game
column21: and I definitely recommend it to RPG fans
column22: although genre newcomers would be better off starting with something less complex. It took me 68 hours to finish and I didn't complete every side quest
column23: which is excellent value for money at full price."

reviewText:
This game is XCOM meets Fallout. It has the dark humour and post-apocalyptic setting of the Fallout series, with the punishing, perma-death combat of the XCOM series.

The graphics aren't amazing, but they're adequate for the game style. The music is atmospheric, the writing is fun, and the voice acting is hit-or-miss.

The gameplay is great for people who like this sort of turn-based squad combat. All the usual elements are here: objects in the environment provide cover, hits are percent-based, and actions cost AP to execute, which replenishes each turn.

My only real complaint is the navigation on the overworld map, which seems like a cop-out from making an interesting overworld. Whenever you aren't in an encounter area (random encounter, dungeon, town), your party is represented as a marker on a huge map of the American Southwest, which will slowly move toward your destination in the way Indiana Jones travels-- a line drawn on the map.

It's fun to create characters, and the combat is challenging but rewarding.

Well worth the purchase price.

reviewText:
First up, I thoroughly recommend this game.  It's an old school isometric RPG, and it's excellent.

It has it's flaws, but overall they don't undermine the experience, the worst I could say about this game is that there are some balance issues, and there are elements of the game that feel rough and unfinished.

I think it suffers from kickstarter-itis .. where a developer seeks a budget on the KS platform, achieves or exceeds it, then works to that budget.  Back in the day, a company would outlay their own capital and not make money until the product was released, now kickstarter covers development and profit goes into someone's bank account.

The problem with this (understandable) model is that there's not a lot of room for stretch and polish.  You either wildly exceed the kickstarter or you don't - and if you do, let's face it, there's probably a bit more of a 'loose' approach with project management and a higher budget for chicken chow mein.

I think there are functional elements of the game that should have been deeper, and there are story-telling elements that fell onto the 'nice to have but not essential' list and got cut.

Incidentally, I haven't finished the game yet, I'm about 75% through (I think).

Here's my view on the Good/Bad

Good:
- graphics and theme are nice
- world map and random encounters makes you feel 'there'
- radio chatter from different factions is immersive
- background lore (the rangers, their character, their personalities) .. all good
- combat: for the most part is satisfying and tactical
- story: although contrived in places, overall the storytelling pulls you in and holds your interest
- conversations and character writing is good for the most part (but also a missed opportunity)

Bad:
- weapon balance has some very bad decisions, energy weapons in particular range from OP in some situations to useless in others.  I say balance, but I don't really care too much about balance, what bothers me is some of the weapons are balanced is .. well, not logical and doesn't fit into a consistent and realistic universe
- Skills & Attributes: for me a real missed opportunity, they disconnect.  Example, Charisma doesnt effect conversations.  Seriously.  There's no randomness or discreet skill impact on conversations, just gatekeeper skills hardarse/intimidation, smartarse/logic, kissarse/charm .. and those skills are just numbers.  Likewise the balance of stats and skills is not really intuitive and clever in it's design, I guess in a way the game suffers from being compared to Fallout 2 in that regard.
- Contrived/Illogical writing:  there are some key points where the writing is a bit .. contrived.  No matter what you do, it's pre-ordained that the outcome will lead you from A->B->C, doesnt matter if you're evil or good.  If I were to analogise with pen&paper roleplaying, it's basically having a GM who can't 'think on their feet' .. the underarching story should be invisible, it should feel like you have total freedom and YOU (the player) are calling the shots .. instead, there are a few key points in the story writing where you feel more than a bit led by the nose (worse, there are some points where you only have a couple of options and those options don't allow for wide variations in character, one specific example you have 3 options to respond to a challenge from your CO, and each of them forces you to lie.


Overall, I give the game a solid 8.5 / 10 golden jabberoos.

reviewText:
I like the setting, I like story, I like the gameplay, I like the gore, I like the character builder, I like almost everything. But like always there is one big thing what the developers have messed up really bad.

There are many Recruitable NPCs who are too squishy concerning their attributes and skills. Some RNPCs (or even everyone?!) don't have the same amount of attributes like your selfmade characters. Why?! I don't know... Furthermore their attributes don't fit to theit skills.
And another point... There are still too less RNPCs. Before starting a game, I figured out how I want to play the game. I've read on some community-sites, that you should match your selfmade NPCs with the RNPCs who are waiting for me in the wastelands.
With the given RNPCs I am not able to play the game as I want, not so satisfying. There are always some skills missing I'd like to have in my party. For example I'd like to have all three speech kills (Smart ♥♥♥, Kiss ♥♥♥, Hard ♥♥♥) but then I don't have enough skill points to spend on other important skills.

I hope there will be a patch who changes it.

The combat system could have been much more interesting. It only contains very basic stuff and in most cases the AI isn't very smart. Sometimes enemies are looking for cover but it happens very often that they stand in front of you with no cover. Melee fighters are always rushing to your party, even it is very obvious they won't survive it. Enemies with pistols are also quite stupid. They run to you and try to shoot you, even if you have more guys alive. Riflemen and snipers are smart and take cover and try to get higher positions than you.

Anyway, it's a good RPG with many choices and possibilities. I'm playing it currently on Ranger-Difficulty (3rd difficulty of 4) and I must say, it's still pretty fair. Combat is challenging, but you always find enough equipment to patch your guys up.

The atmosphere very good, most RNPCs have unique dialogues which are quite funny. All the descriptions you get during the game are also so good. There is very much too read, but it's worth the time to spend with it.

So the points which deny a very good" or "excellent" are:
- too less RNPCs
- RNPCs with bad attributes and skill which are not matching the given attributes
- just basic combat system
- "bad" AI (for melle and pistol fighters)

Oh
date: and on ranger difficulty you don't want to miss your outdoorsman-skill. :)"

reviewText:
Summary – 7/10 Good game for those who like post apocalypse setting, top down 3rd person point of view, large variety of weapons.  Buy when on sale for under $20.

Pro:
+ Post Apocalypse setting
+ Lots of decision trees, dialog options
+ Multiple ways to complete an objective
+ Interesting story (bringing law and order to a place of total anarchy)
+ Decent number of quests (about 60-70)
+ Nice unique maps
+ Dismemberment, melting on some kill shots
+ Easy to use UI
+ Humor and funny references especially of the 80’s throughout.

Con:
- Lacks the immersiveness of 1st person viewpoint games  (Fallout: New Vegas, Fallout 3)
- Can’t interact with most of the environment.  Almost all building entrances are blocked and using explosives won’t change that.
- Poor AI – just set up an ambush point on a map send out a meat shield to draw the enemies and kill them as they approach.  Works almost every time.
- Explosives so overpowered in combat.  They never miss even if your character doesn’t have a single point in explosives. Give meatshield a ton of STR (which equals HP).  Have enemy mob him.  He runs out then toss grenades.  Battle won. Rinse. Repeat.
- Game maps are fairly linear (except for Titan Canyon)
- Dull weapon/shooting animations (just one animation for all weapons)
- Non realistic skill (Toaster Repair (really!!))
- Poor stat optimization.  Intelligence > all.  Many stats just not important.
- Too many skills focused on just opening containers (open lock, tumbler, alarm, trap, perception) since you have to divide up skills amongst players to max them all quickly it means switching through multiple players just to open a container.  Pretty poor design.
- Every container is either trapped or has an alarm attached to it (or both).
- Few locations (Less than a two dozen maps in the AZ and CA zones)
- RNG on skills is not even close to what is listed.  50% chance of success really means 10% chance of success at most.  Use PF9 and PF11 constantly can waste 10 minutes opening a chest/safe not very enjoyable.
- Easily broken quests. Lots of reloading to complete a quest.
- No mods or modding community (lack of replayability)

Note my playtime means nothing as I have a small child now and often have a game running/paused on one monitor all weekend even though I may only play 15 minutes every couple hours when I have a few minutes to relax.  Probably only spent 25-30 hrs actually completing the game.

In general if you are a huge fan of Post Apocalypse games like me then you will enjoy this game.

Not too many bugs in the game just a few like:
- Examining ground that says something is buried but not allowing you to use a shovel or any other skill on the ground.  This happened 3-4 times.
- Trying to save after visiting a travelling merchant to offload junk.  Get a message saying “you are in combat and can’t save at this time”  Guess the merchants don’t like the deal they received hehe.
- Memory Leak (At least when you pause the game for 2+ hours and then unpause the game it moves slower than molasses. It’s a pain if you forgot to PF9 before hitting pause. (Use a liquid cooled Alienware rig as my main gaming machine and it’s a beast so they lag/stutter and huge decrease in frame-rate is due to a memory leak).


Though please note that it is not even comparable to Fallout: New Vegas with its fully interactive environment, open world, 1st person view, great soundtrack, number of factions and locations but for a budget/on sale game this is something to enjoy for awhile.  Still not sure why all the most valuable items (skill books) in a post apocalypse world would be stored inside toasters.  Also be sure to PF9 before using any skill then PF11 when it fails will allow you to open every intractable item in the game.  Also press “Z” a lot to find all intractable items.

reviewText:
It is hard to write a review about Wasteland II.

This game does many things in a other way, than many player expect it.
It is a slow game, it has tactical turn based combat, which slowes the pace of the game down.
It has beautiful written dialoges and this dialoges really carry the game, but you need to read them most of the time.
So this slows the pace of the game down again.
From time to time you will travel the world map, and just stare at your position marker for a time,

Overall this game is slow. ANd you need to play it in this slow aproach. Take your time. Read the dialoges, follow the story, make your decisions and shoot the bad guys - which arent that bad, if you really get them to know - most are just another type of crazy :D.

This game is well done, but it is not made for every kind of player.
I still recommend it.

reviewText:
I have too much to say, so...
Do you like Role Play Games?
Do you like freedom of choice and very involving story lines?
Have you ever played Fallout 1, 2 or Tactics ...and if you have, you liked it?

This is the best true-to-RPG-heritage I've seen/played/read about, with lots of decisions to make (both obvious and inventive). This is a game you can pick up and project yourself into the game, play it in your style in an open world where danger has become more common than anything else. This picks up where Wasteland 1 ended (I've never played WL1, but trust me, you don't need to). The universe is better than you would probably expect (thankfully this is an 18 title).

This is one of those games that you can and will pour hundreds of hours into, singleplayer, having one of the best experiences you've had - beautifully made.

Just buy it!!

reviewText: First cRPG I've ever played from start to finish. A wholy engrossing experience with a decent main story and some great side-quests (that are essentially so good and dynamic they become part of your own main story).\nLots of customization and ways to solve different problems. The game is incredibly hard in the beginning but if you build a decent team it opens up after a few hours and by the end you should feel like a badass, though never totally over powered. The combat is a good mix of tactics and gear dependency and overall is very satisfying. When an enemys weapon jams just as he is about to kill one of your characters is exhilarating. Tons of weapons and armor along with vanity items and all kinds of other junk.\nA modern classic in every sense of the word. I bought it for 20$ at a sale and I would buy it for tripple that price. Can't recommend it enough if you can stomach the difficulty and have the time to spare. All around superb game. Buy it, buy it, BUY IT!

reviewText:
I bought wastland 2 while it was in beta. I loved the game from the start, and actually wanted to support Brian Fargo.

It was a great experince playing the beta to the finished verison. Of course any major patch would break your saves, but it's that type of game where you want to restart a few times anyway, more so to play with your Characters stats.

I will say a lot of people have wrote about the game not being very tatical. There is some truth to that, there aren't too many cases where you can strage your characters for a fight, most encounters are just a straight up ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ contest. A couple of hours just exploring the wasteland and looting will turn you into one tough ranger.

In the start of the game it seemed like there would be a lot of choices that would directly effect the game. Basically there is only one major choice to be made in the game and really only effects which character your going to pick up as a side kick.

Some of the weapons don't hold much value, such as rocket launchers. Generally before you can use one the baddies are  on top of you already, or it's just not worth using. But it's interesting that you do have to have  players who are better with riffles than lazer weapons, which is part of the tatical portion of the game. Basically each Character should be very well rounded with two different weapons, more so till about 30 hours into the game. You can't have everyone using the same ammo.

Half the game takes place in AZ and the other half in CA. CA is interesting because things just get very strange. In any post nuclear war game youe expect raiders and mutant frogs, but crazy nuns? I wish the AZ portion of the game had more of the odd ball encounters you ran in during CA. The Characters in CA are more interesting as well as the plot.

What I don't understand is the water movement system. In the first half the game you need to refill your canteens which isn't a big deal. In the second half, the concept just stops. It's minor, I'm not sure why I'm even bringing it up but it seemed like a major portion of the game but slowly got scaled back.

I had a lot of fun with this game, like fallout you play for the story and the ride, not so much the end result. It does have a lot of replayability, but as I said I played it from beta which meant I had several restarts. It does let you import your characters that you have progressed through out the game when you finish.

A lot of the skills overlap, and there is more than one way to open a door generally.

I paid 60 dollars for the game and got a little over 230 hours of pure enjoyment of the game, it was worth every penny. I just hope they make a wasteland 3 or a DLC to the game.

One thing they should add is being able to make your own rangers at your base even after you started. I think that would be a fun concept.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For those who loved games like Fallout, Fallout 2, and Fallout Tactics, You will love this game.
So far it is fun, but I do have my gripes about it, one is the interface moving our team around is a little clunky, next would be the character models, these would be fine if it was the early 2002-2004, but with other games to compair it to, these could had been done a lot better they are very well super low poly to the point they look funky. Same with the textures, if we where all playing pc games on say on the first xbox's hardware it would be acceptable but its 2014. I really hope that the art end of this game is not done yet in terms of improvement. But I am guessing its about as good as its going to get visually.

The other very limited weight/carry capacity, you do your first set of missions up to the first radio tower,  all of your inventory spots are about full, by the time you make it to the second tower your way overloaded, and a town/vendor to sell to  is far far away... and requires you to go though a radiation field, or go way out of your way around it, if you happen to get into a fight guess what you will pick up more stuff that you really have no room to carry. Hopefully the devs can find a solution to this.

Overall great game, but it has many areas of improvement needed, from clunky controls, low polly assets that are almost waving like they are made of water when moving. To the tiny annoyances of inventory and not having a way to offload your loot at more locations besides out front of the ranger station at start of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of old school Fallout games or the original Wasteland, even XCOM and want to play a game to where the developers care more about the game being GOOD (sorry GREAT) compared to appeasing to huge numbers, then this game is for you.

The dark humour, the morbidness, the random LOLs and things you just have to be old enough to understand or something you've experienced.  It's almost like this game is littered with easter eggs.  I love it when you snuff the life out of something.  The combat logs are nice too as well.

This game is very well thought out, runs smooth, looks great and is great fun.  This game isn't even fully released yet and it's top notch.

This game for sure will take up 40+ hours of your time.  Exploring, leveling, questing and messing around.  Do a game being a nice guy, do a game being a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, or being a pyscho and just murder everybody and every goat. ....poor goats....

One nice feature they also put in is all the different ways you have to access something, IE:  oh a locked door.  I can lock pick it...or..spartan kick that ♥♥♥♥♥ in....or....use lots and lots of explosives....MacGruber would of wanted it that way.

If they see screaming goats on the internet, it goes in the game.  It just goes to show the amount of passion and joy they put into this game.

I highly recommend if you love this style of gameplay!

reviewText:
Basically this game is a lot of fun and challenge for the most parts.
But lacks some content which made Fallout and other similar games the best.

Combat:
One of the biggest downs is the non avaible sneak mode. Once your spotted (and you will be at a very long range usually)
every enemy near the one who spot you will enter combat. That part is okay i guess, because if you get spotted by an enemy human guard IRL i guess he would scream for help and the other would still be coming because of the gunfire.

But usually there is huge open areas which are impossible to sneak through without taking a totally different way which anyhow leads up to a combat situation just from an other entry point.
So forget about playing sneaky because there are no stealthboys in this game.

And also the hit ratio seems messed up (or im just really unlucky).

Questing:
I have really enjoyed the quest, its no pointing fingers in this game. You just get a general tip of the whereabout of whatever you'r searching for. It's no arrow pointing you exactly to the location to go. Which is really nice.

If you do the right" thing in a questline its a huge chance you end up with better supplies and another follower to your party (which is always nice because combat is unforgiving
date: if you play on normal or ranger difficulty).\n\nLots of random loot you find will be of interest to various NPC's throughout the world (not the junk items
recommended:
altho it says in tooltip that you never know who might be interested in a junk item. Still haven't found any use of em)

reviewText:
I've always been a fan of post-apocalyptic RPG's and tried the original Wasteland many many years ago.  I was excited when I first heard of the sequel, and it did not disappoint! The gameplay is very good, the story really captivates you, the characters are very well made, and every little choice you make affects the overall story.

My only complaint would be that sometimes I couldn't figure out how to reach certain outcomes. (For example, I ended up getting an entire town accidentally destroyed, because I couldn't find the entrance of the place I needed to enter, and I left the town)

Overall, I think the game is worth the money, and definitely worth my time. I can see myself playing this all the way through multiple times just to see all the different storylines.

reviewText:
An amazing remake of the classic post-apocalyptic RPG of the same name, Wasteland 2 truly delivers when it comes to content.  Honestly, with all the crowdfunding games that under deliver, WL2 actually caught me by surprise with simply how much many locations and situations there are to discover.  This is a complete and well thought out game.

Story wise, there are a lot of choices to be made among the ruins of the old world and the game excels at showing you the consequences of those decisions.  There is a location that became so story rich, I had to actually stop and think about the multi-layers of intrigue before acting on anyone’s request for help because the ramifications affected so many other characters.  (to be fair, this section was so involved that I found my trigger-finger itching for some combat but it was well worth it when it came)

I also found the game mechanics deep and leveling characters was very satisfying.  There’s a ton of skills and your characters become focused on specific builds – one will be your safecrack/lockpick/alarm disabler and another might be your expert in assault rifles and demolitions – but I never felt limited when customizing.  What is equally surprising is that all skills come into play at some point and you are never required (mostly) to have a certain skill to progress through the main storyline; you always have options.

All in all, a great time.  Be warned: it's a time gobbler.

reviewText:
I'm mainly writing this for my friends because I recommended this game to before I spent enough time with it. I had really high expectations for this game but I really can't recommend it.  I wanted to love this game, I mean really LOVE it like I loved Fallout 2 or Jagged Alliance 2 or Morrowind. And I tried so hard to overlook the flaws I saw because damn it, I was waiting for this game over 20 years and I wasn't going to let some nittpicky BS stop me. But unfortunately all the problems I kept encountering just kept building up on each other until I pretty much gave up. Some of these problems are as follows:

The combat is shallow and lacks any sort of tactical feel despite being turn based; You rarely have a need to move your characters and most battles can be won by standing still and spaming attack or maybe toss a grenade. You can crouch or use a headshot but there's no real advantage that I notice to even bother with these moves.

The missions all seem half finished; apparently it's hand holding" to ask for any sort of clue as to what you need to do or even why you need to do it. And all of the quests have multiple ways to "complete" them but if you're looking for multiple ways to complete them in a manner that the devs wanted you to in order to "win" the game then you'll need to rely on online guides because those solutions require an extremely linear path to be followed. And by "win" the game I mean by having the optimal completion where everyone you encounter was happy with what you did. Those endings are there but as I said they're not very easy to figure out.

"Conversations" with NPC's are nothing more than triggering the next bit of dialog by clicking on the keyword; there's no branching at all and you're really not interacting with NPC's in any meaningful way.

Character creation is also an oddity since it breaks the norm in most RPG's by having skills act completely independant of  attributes; ie charisma has no effect on your characters conversation skills or barter.

And lastly there are some really bad bugs that have caused me to lose a lot of game play time; there's 3 quick save slots for a reason and you should be sure to use them.

There's a lot to like here but I'm not going to sit here with a "pros and cons" list because I figure a lot of people are like me: if I'm thinking about buying a game I'm pretty much sold on it already and what I need to know is the bad stuff. Now none of the stuff I said above is so much that it's caused me to hate the game but it is enough to make me wish I had held off and waited for more reviews instead of buying it day one. $14.99-$19.99 is probably a good price point for this game but $40 is too much for what you get."

reviewText:
I bought wastland 2 while it was in beta. I loved the game from the start, and actually wanted to support Brian Fargo.

It was a great experince playing the beta to the finished verison. Of course any major patch would break your saves, but it's that type of game where you want to restart a few times anyway, more so to play with your Characters stats.

I will say a lot of people have wrote about the game not being very tatical. There is some truth to that, there aren't too many cases where you can strage your characters for a fight, most encounters are just a straight up ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ contest. A couple of hours just exploring the wasteland and looting will turn you into one tough ranger.

In the start of the game it seemed like there would be a lot of choices that would directly effect the game. Basically there is only one major choice to be made in the game and really only effects which character your going to pick up as a side kick.

Some of the weapons don't hold much value, such as rocket launchers. Generally before you can use one the baddies are  on top of you already, or it's just not worth using. But it's interesting that you do have to have  players who are better with riffles than lazer weapons, which is part of the tatical portion of the game. Basically each Character should be very well rounded with two different weapons, more so till about 30 hours into the game. You can't have everyone using the same ammo.

Half the game takes place in AZ and the other half in CA. CA is interesting because things just get very strange. In any post nuclear war game youe expect raiders and mutant frogs, but crazy nuns? I wish the AZ portion of the game had more of the odd ball encounters you ran in during CA. The Characters in CA are more interesting as well as the plot.

What I don't understand is the water movement system. In the first half the game you need to refill your canteens which isn't a big deal. In the second half, the concept just stops. It's minor, I'm not sure why I'm even bringing it up but it seemed like a major portion of the game but slowly got scaled back.

I had a lot of fun with this game, like fallout you play for the story and the ride, not so much the end result. It does have a lot of replayability, but as I said I played it from beta which meant I had several restarts. It does let you import your characters that you have progressed through out the game when you finish.

A lot of the skills overlap, and there is more than one way to open a door generally.

I paid 60 dollars for the game and got a little over 230 hours of pure enjoyment of the game, it was worth every penny. I just hope they make a wasteland 3 or a DLC to the game.

One thing they should add is being able to make your own rangers at your base even after you started. I think that would be a fun concept.

reviewText:
I recommend this game to anyone that likes a mix of Strategy with RPG elements. If you like Shadowrun I would highly recommend this to you. Especially if you like the Fallout series because the RPG element in this game is pretty much similar. Think Fallout meets Shadowrun.

Anyway, before you do start the game, if you're familiar with Fallout, like in Fallout, do some research about stat gains and what it gives, and how those stat gain affects your gameplay so that you know what you can cap early on. Same goes for your skills. Except that when concerning skills, you would wanna check up on what skills are commonly needed in the wasteland to survive. Otherwise, you're going to dislike the game even before you're halfway through with it.

My only issue is the formula derived for chances because it seems pretty wonky. For example, most of the times something which is  91% and above and your 1% of critical failure, you would expect it to pass without a critical failure. At most you'd expect just a failure, if not at all. But from what I noticed, it seems this game's chance formula is failure baised. Because even if a high passing rate with 80-90%, critical failure when opening doors and unlocking stuff are pretty damn common for a 1% critical failure.

However, if you can live with that issue, then by all means GET THE GAME ALREADY!

reviewText:
A very entertaining game, if only it had spent an extra year brewing before being served! It's rough round the edges, sometimes the graphics bug out and very occasionally it'll simply present you with a colour cube.

Aside from that, the script is great if a little short, and the story engaging if a little simple. Some of the stats do seem a bit wonky, and you can guarantee that all your enemies have twice the Action Points that they logically should have... but it's not impossible to play and it'll take you a few days to power through, or a week of more casual playing.

If you liked the original, you'll like this.

reviewText:
I like the setting, I like story, I like the gameplay, I like the gore, I like the character builder, I like almost everything. But like always there is one big thing what the developers have messed up really bad.

There are many Recruitable NPCs who are too squishy concerning their attributes and skills. Some RNPCs (or even everyone?!) don't have the same amount of attributes like your selfmade characters. Why?! I don't know... Furthermore their attributes don't fit to theit skills.
And another point... There are still too less RNPCs. Before starting a game, I figured out how I want to play the game. I've read on some community-sites, that you should match your selfmade NPCs with the RNPCs who are waiting for me in the wastelands.
With the given RNPCs I am not able to play the game as I want, not so satisfying. There are always some skills missing I'd like to have in my party. For example I'd like to have all three speech kills (Smart ♥♥♥, Kiss ♥♥♥, Hard ♥♥♥) but then I don't have enough skill points to spend on other important skills.

I hope there will be a patch who changes it.

The combat system could have been much more interesting. It only contains very basic stuff and in most cases the AI isn't very smart. Sometimes enemies are looking for cover but it happens very often that they stand in front of you with no cover. Melee fighters are always rushing to your party, even it is very obvious they won't survive it. Enemies with pistols are also quite stupid. They run to you and try to shoot you, even if you have more guys alive. Riflemen and snipers are smart and take cover and try to get higher positions than you.

Anyway, it's a good RPG with many choices and possibilities. I'm playing it currently on Ranger-Difficulty (3rd difficulty of 4) and I must say, it's still pretty fair. Combat is challenging, but you always find enough equipment to patch your guys up.

The atmosphere very good, most RNPCs have unique dialogues which are quite funny. All the descriptions you get during the game are also so good. There is very much too read, but it's worth the time to spend with it.

So the points which deny a very good" or "excellent" are:
- too less RNPCs
- RNPCs with bad attributes and skill which are not matching the given attributes
- just basic combat system
- "bad" AI (for melle and pistol fighters)

Oh
date: and on ranger difficulty you don't want to miss your outdoorsman-skill. :)"

reviewText:
It's been a while since a game brought me in. Wasteland 2 is a proper continuation of Fallout 1&2 - a true post-apo world, dark humour, turn-based combat, freedom and multiple ways to solve quests. I had a feeling I play Fallout for the first time.

But it's a modern game, so it has great graphics (love the picture of NPCs!), modern controls, team management etc. The only dissadvantage is very large locations, sometimes it takes too much time to discover everything or run for a way out.

Great game, if you like post-apo, it's a must-have!

reviewText:
Wasteland 2 is a good game, but overall fell short of my expectations. The funny thing is that the mediocrity of Wasteland 2 reminded me how great Fallout New Vegas was and I finally finished my walkthrough of that game, rather than continuing with Wasteland 2. Both games attempt the same thing in so many ways, but Fallout just does it better. The writing, the quests, the immersiveness... Even though I actually prefer isometric RPGs to Fallout's ego perspective, Wasteland's implementation of it has a wide variety of shortcomings. The world feels much more static because environmental objects cannot be manipulated, the different areas are much smaller in size, and the overall level of interaction is much lower.

Other downsides to be aware of:
- AI is very dumb
- Percentage based skill checks lead to a lot of reloading (it probably would have been better to have a binary 100% or 0% chance).
- Balancing of different weapon types is off (melee based characters seem weak, assault rifle beats everything)
- Battles are not tactical enough (more types of cover would have been nice, more firing modes, more environmental interaction, better system for explosive weapons)

In spite of all this critique, I enjoyed the classic" feel to the game and the very post-apocalyptical setting that inspired the original Fallout. Thoroughly enyoable

reviewText:
Fallout 1 and 2 remain favorites of mine. While the FPS updates of Fallout 3 and Fallout: New Vegas were great in their own way, inExile's Wasteland 2 is the true successor" to Fallout's vibe and gameplay.

This makes sense when you realize the Fallout universe was created as an IP-claim-avoiding homage to the original Wasteland.

Many of the great people that worked on Fallout 1 & 2 have returned to make Wasteland 2
date: including great work from Chris Avellone on writing and design and the return of Mark Morgan's beautiful ambient music.\n\nIt's worth noting this is game is thematically dark
recommended: with far less of the goofy humor that started to undermine the Fallout series. There's swearing

date: but it's a nice change of pace from the current "hand holding" style of most modern RPGs. Actions have consequences

There are a couple dozen skills which makes your choices at this stage a bit difficult and I'd suggest you check out a community guide to them before diving in to help make sense of it all. If you'd rather NOT spend a solid hour develpoing a team you can use presets

reviewText:
I have too much to say, so...
Do you like Role Play Games?
Do you like freedom of choice and very involving story lines?
Have you ever played Fallout 1, 2 or Tactics ...and if you have, you liked it?

This is the best true-to-RPG-heritage I've seen/played/read about, with lots of decisions to make (both obvious and inventive). This is a game you can pick up and project yourself into the game, play it in your style in an open world where danger has become more common than anything else. This picks up where Wasteland 1 ended (I've never played WL1, but trust me, you don't need to). The universe is better than you would probably expect (thankfully this is an 18 title).

This is one of those games that you can and will pour hundreds of hours into, singleplayer, having one of the best experiences you've had - beautifully made.

Just buy it!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK...now this is the game. This is the successor to the grand father of cRPGs, the spiritual father of FALLOUT...This is Wasteland 2!
The game is still in beta (or early access, what ever you want to call it). It is also still suffering from optimization issues, bugs, and clunky game design.
HOWEVER, these things do not hinder the game. In its state, is is solid, and plays very well. It feels like a true port-apocalyptic game, and it can definitely stand up to FALLOUT of STALKER. The story telling is wonderful, combat works and feels great, the atmosphere is just perfect, there is a bit of humor and secrets, many new and unfamiliar enemies, andTONS of customization. You can tactically set up your team and develop them as they level up, or you can build your own character from the ground up. It is just overall a well done project.
It is still being developed, and new updates will be coming out for it. The UI will be fixed, it will be optimized, much more will be added...and in the end, this wonderful, promising stone will be polished to be one of the greatest cRPGs done.
I know, the price tag is a little steep. But, if you are willing to buy it, and if you are willing to put up with a (currently) incomplete game, and if you are going to commit yourself to giving back to the devs, then it will be a worthwhile purchase. Additionally, this is a great game if you loved FALLOUT (esp. the first 2 and tactics) and Wasteland.
Should you buy it? It depends, you might not want to, and you are certainly not being forced to. But if you do, know you are contributing to a constantly developing and promising sequel to a beloved game.
