reviewText:
Summary – 7/10 Good game for those who like post apocalypse setting, top down 3rd person point of view, large variety of weapons.  Buy when on sale for under $20.

Pro:
+ Post Apocalypse setting
+ Lots of decision trees, dialog options
+ Multiple ways to complete an objective
+ Interesting story (bringing law and order to a place of total anarchy)
+ Decent number of quests (about 60-70)
+ Nice unique maps
+ Dismemberment, melting on some kill shots
+ Easy to use UI
+ Humor and funny references especially of the 80’s throughout.

Con:
- Lacks the immersiveness of 1st person viewpoint games  (Fallout: New Vegas, Fallout 3)
- Can’t interact with most of the environment.  Almost all building entrances are blocked and using explosives won’t change that.
- Poor AI – just set up an ambush point on a map send out a meat shield to draw the enemies and kill them as they approach.  Works almost every time.
- Explosives so overpowered in combat.  They never miss even if your character doesn’t have a single point in explosives. Give meatshield a ton of STR (which equals HP).  Have enemy mob him.  He runs out then toss grenades.  Battle won. Rinse. Repeat.
- Game maps are fairly linear (except for Titan Canyon)
- Dull weapon/shooting animations (just one animation for all weapons)
- Non realistic skill (Toaster Repair (really!!))
- Poor stat optimization.  Intelligence > all.  Many stats just not important.
- Too many skills focused on just opening containers (open lock, tumbler, alarm, trap, perception) since you have to divide up skills amongst players to max them all quickly it means switching through multiple players just to open a container.  Pretty poor design.
- Every container is either trapped or has an alarm attached to it (or both).
- Few locations (Less than a two dozen maps in the AZ and CA zones)
- RNG on skills is not even close to what is listed.  50% chance of success really means 10% chance of success at most.  Use PF9 and PF11 constantly can waste 10 minutes opening a chest/safe not very enjoyable.
- Easily broken quests. Lots of reloading to complete a quest.
- No mods or modding community (lack of replayability)

Note my playtime means nothing as I have a small child now and often have a game running/paused on one monitor all weekend even though I may only play 15 minutes every couple hours when I have a few minutes to relax.  Probably only spent 25-30 hrs actually completing the game.

In general if you are a huge fan of Post Apocalypse games like me then you will enjoy this game.

Not too many bugs in the game just a few like:
- Examining ground that says something is buried but not allowing you to use a shovel or any other skill on the ground.  This happened 3-4 times.
- Trying to save after visiting a travelling merchant to offload junk.  Get a message saying “you are in combat and can’t save at this time”  Guess the merchants don’t like the deal they received hehe.
- Memory Leak (At least when you pause the game for 2+ hours and then unpause the game it moves slower than molasses. It’s a pain if you forgot to PF9 before hitting pause. (Use a liquid cooled Alienware rig as my main gaming machine and it’s a beast so they lag/stutter and huge decrease in frame-rate is due to a memory leak).


Though please note that it is not even comparable to Fallout: New Vegas with its fully interactive environment, open world, 1st person view, great soundtrack, number of factions and locations but for a budget/on sale game this is something to enjoy for awhile.  Still not sure why all the most valuable items (skill books) in a post apocalypse world would be stored inside toasters.  Also be sure to PF9 before using any skill then PF11 when it fails will allow you to open every intractable item in the game.  Also press “Z” a lot to find all intractable items.

reviewText:
It is hard to write a review about Wasteland II.

This game does many things in a other way, than many player expect it.
It is a slow game, it has tactical turn based combat, which slowes the pace of the game down.
It has beautiful written dialoges and this dialoges really carry the game, but you need to read them most of the time.
So this slows the pace of the game down again.
From time to time you will travel the world map, and just stare at your position marker for a time,

Overall this game is slow. ANd you need to play it in this slow aproach. Take your time. Read the dialoges, follow the story, make your decisions and shoot the bad guys - which arent that bad, if you really get them to know - most are just another type of crazy :D.

This game is well done, but it is not made for every kind of player.
I still recommend it.

reviewText:
I can't in good conscious recommend Wasteland 2 as a finished product. It's too lackluster and has a few major issues. It plays fine, and I will probably continue playing it even after I write this, but there's two main issues at the time of writing.
The first being off is the god for saken prison. Ran by raiders with no redeemable factors that turn people into slaves only be disguising them as workers. They do nothing good, everyone that you come across will say you can be the savior, march right up to the leader, and kill him, simple task, right?

Apparently not, once you get there you run into a plotwall. Two turrets at 4K health each(To put that in perspective, 20ish hours in my characters only have 125ish health). Okay, fine, just bring out heavy weapons. Wrong again, they have a stupid high intiative, and a stupid high amount of action points. They fired 5ish times each, doing 300 damage per bullet. Good luck getting your party through that.

Even if you *DO* manage to kill the turrets, there's apparently accounts of impossible-to-defuse landmines that 1 hit kill party members.

Why is this happening? I'm not sure, but if I had to guess, one of the team members working on wasteland felt so proud of their plot twist they decided to make sure everyone can only expirence the plot twist like that. So you just have to go 'welp, i know these guys beat and enslave you, but hes's got deus ex machina backing him so we can't do anything till the game says so'

The other issue is just hour 10ish. It becomes out-of-ammo gun-jam simulator. You won't have enough ammo to get into skrims, or if you do, you'll be cutting it close and it'll just be fustrating. Then when you do have ammo, your gun jams. A lot. I'm not sure how complex a double barrel shotgun is, but i'm pretty sure it's not prone to the amount of jamming it got.

Now for the nitpicky stuff. Somethings just outpace your levels, but that's fine, maybe I shouldn't be rushing through the content as fast as I was. Another issue is just not being able to interact with the world. There's a girl who's (perpetually) dying, constantly groaning into your radio, asking for some one named Elroy. You can find her, confront her. But even if you're the best doc of the entire world, you can't help her, only shoot her. It may sound super nit picky, but not even given the illusion of choice sucks. I couldn't try, I could only mercy kill.

There is good htngs, the game is close to being a perfect masterpiece.
Combat is actually alright, atleast mid game. Things start getting faster, combat is quick but a bit tactical. It could benefit from a few small tweaks. Flanking, some more cover options, and a change to friendly fire calculations(Not as bad as fallout 2. Damn it Sulik, give me that gun.)

The characters are alright, followers feel human as they comment on the scenery and situation where applicable, instead of being a silent moving turret. They have their flaws, they have their benefit, but not so much so they become a god send or dead weight.

Over all the game feels... unpolished. It feels as if I'm playing in a beta, which I'm not. If it gets changed, or the mod tools get released, I'm sure this game could be something fantastic. But at the moment it's simply okay.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Decent story, interesting world, mediocre dialogues. Relatively boring battles/gameplay. Decent sound and graphics, but limited customization and very ugly character models.  Would have fared better without the high expectations from the kickstarter. Close to a positive recommendation, but not quite: 5/10.

The sequel to the inspiration for Fallout... talk about high expectations. Add to this the fact that it was a super-successful Kickstarter project that promised to put the creative people back in charge of their own projects, and it's easy to see why so many hopes for the future of PC roleplaying rest(ed) on this game. I found it somewhat disappointing in many details small and large, unfortunately. Would I have liked it without the hype? I will never know. Does it matter for this review? No. A game that carries so much baggage needs to be reviewed with it in mind.

Story/World:
Meh. As so often, it is difficult to say anything without too many spoilers. The world is an... interesting place. Unlike Fallout, it places less emphasis on realism and does not take itself too seriously, allowing for some weird and fascinating factions and places, which are fun to explore. Unfortunately, while there are some gems, the size of the world means that no place has much depth and really catches your heart. Did I feel at home and connected to Ranger Citadel? No. Did I care that a lot of old acquaintances showed up, helped and died in the final battle? No. Did I really care for the epilogues for the places I had visited? No. So: While the game presents a varied and interesting world, it failed to pull me in.

Additionally, they sat a bit heavily on the predecessor (old characters, old locations, old stories that are repeated again and again) which I did not play, making it hard for me to get invested.

Dialogues were a mixed bag as well. Some good, but also a lot of repetition of the same pieces of information over and over again.

The roleplaying came down to a handful of choices (Do I help this person? Which of those two factions do I support?). My characters lacked, unfortunately, a character.

The main story is actually very short. Weird robots show up. Now go and fight them. It's nice and consistent, without plot holes, but the ending  not only digs out the Big Bad from part one, but also uses the Terminator reasoning for the nuclear war, which seems lazy.

Sound:
Nice enough, but could have been more varied.

Graphics:
I usually don't care too much about graphics, but some things really disturbed me here from the very beginning. Character models are ugly. What's more, there are a very limited number of character portraits, all of which are used as NPC portraits as well, so you quite often have two identically-looking people talking to each other. Finally, the descriptions of characters in the world very often don't match their portrait at all. Takes me out of the story.
That said, the maps are done with great care and are quite beautiful.

Gameplay:
Yeah... that was what almost made me give up on the game in between. There are a few minor things that bugged me (area map is a screenshot, allows no notes, shows no locations), but the big thing is the combat. This is where you spend most of your game. But the combat is pretty damn boring: There is a basic cover mechanic, but many places in which you will find yourself starting battles are devoid of cover at least for your group. Thus, many battles end up being about choosing who to shoot. Throw in some small-ish things like unclear sight lines/weapon ranges especially when the battle goes over two levels and the whole affair becomes less an intricate chess game between you and the (mediocre) AI and more a tedious excercise in mopping up without using too many resources.

Then there are the crates. And the safes. And the holes. And the toasters. Everything wants to give you items, which are absolutely necessary in the beginning and absolutely superfluous in the end. But if you're anything like me, you will STILL open the next safe - just in case of the very occasional plot-relevant item. Makes the game go even slower and becomes, at times, an excercise in quick-saving and quick-loading.

Finally, while the game throws loads of skills at you, there is no deep character building here. One weapon skill, one auxiliary skill (or three for the skill monkeys) per person, done.

In summary, while the game amused me and made me smile at times, it did not make me think and it did not make me care for its world or characters. At least one of those I expect from a roleplaying game. Thus: Not recommended.

Addendum: Reading it again, this review sounds exceptionally negative. It wasn't really meant to be; most of the issues I mentioned bothered me, but not as much as in other games. It's just that a lot of things that don't bother me too much add up to make this game pretty mediocre - maybe 5/10.

reviewText:
Right well... how to describe this game?

Its very much a spiritual sequel to class Fallout games people might better know than the original Wasteland its self.
You can create 4 party memebers(also able to recruit upto two more as the story progresses) stats are all important and in a way you want to have every skill in your six man party as you loose out a lot missing any. Lots of role play choices, some morality plays and a fair bit of humor. Story is engaging but slow as you can do alot out side/along side the story and it is of the classic grand scale of the best isometric RPGs but that is an issue for some. It has Honey Badgers but they are unrealistic in so far as being killable, so a small mark up and down there.

Now i'm over the twenty hour mark i'm still enjoying it, trying to do everything and find some treads from a robot to bust open a bunker, the lack of stealth to correctly setup an ambush exactly as i want is tough some times, but outside of that complaint game play is balanced and intresting. My knife weilding mexican is effective in meele while my assault rifle weilding Ms Deth may be higher damage the ammo she chews through can be a little short at times this balance feels just about right.

All in all a good rounded RPG that'll probally take 40-60 hours by the end with maybe a second play through, recomended for man, Badger or Robot.
